business.start.para: Mr SPEAKER(Mr Neil Andrew) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, why did you insist on the deletion from the referendum question of the word `Australian' from the expression `Australian President'? Is it not a fact that the Queen of Australia is not an Australian and that the Governor-General of Australia need not be Australian? Is it not also a fact that, under the terms of the referendum on the republic, the President of Australia must be an Australian? Why are you refusing to allow this absolutely central distinction to be properly reflected in the question to be put to the Australian people?

—The question that won the overwhelming support, by a vote of something like 140 to eight last night, of both sides of the parliament—and I think you even voted for it in the end—is the question which will go to the Australian people in November. It is a balanced question. It is a fair question. The proposition that you should use the adjective `Australian' in relation to the President without acknowledging the reality that it is inconceivable that any Governor-General of this country would now be other than an Australian is inconceivable.

answer.para: Every Governor-General of Australia since Casey was appointed in 1965 has been an Australian. It is inconceivable that the Governor-General of this country would be other than an Australian. And by a law enacted by the Whitlam Labor government, the Queen was designated as Queen of Australia. In those circumstances, in the view of the government it was inappropriate, as I described it yesterday, to be selectively patriotic or nationalistic to use the word `Australian' in relation to the President but to omit the reality that the Governor-General will always be an Australian. That is the reason why the adjective was taken out.

The government stands by the question. It has no intention of altering its position. And this parliament passed that by a vote of 140 to eight—an unprecedented measure of support, I might say, in the 3½ years that the government has been in power—and we have no intention of altering the question. That is the question which I want to see go to the Australian people on 6 November.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. How is the government hard at work creating more jobs for all Australians, particularly our young people? How is the government combating opponents of its policies who put special interests ahead of jobs?

—We on the government side of the House are interested in more than one job. We are interested in generating—as we have over the last 3½ years—tens of thousands of jobs for the Australian community. I am very proud of the fact, as is every man and woman on the government side of this chamber, that in the time that the government has been in office we have generated more than 400,000 jobs in the Australian community. We have done this in the face of fierce opposition from the Australian Labor Party in relation to virtually every measure we have taken in order to reduce unemployment in Australia.

answer.para: The Labor Party set about stopping us getting the economy right. The Labor Party tried to stop us reducing the deficit and creating a surplus. That has been one of the foundation stones of lower interest rates. The Labor Party opposed the family tax initiative. The Labor Party opposed taxation reform. The Labor Party opposed labour market reform. The Labor Party has sniped away at competition policy. The Labor Party has tried, in short, to sabotage every attempt that this government has made in order to reduce unemployment. Yet despite all that opposition we have succeeded in getting the lowest unemployment rate in Australia for 10 years. We also have the lowest level of youth unemployment, I believe, for the last 20 years in terms of those seeking full-time work.

The Labor Party has opposed our further attempts to protect the jobs of the young. The Labor Party refuses to support our measures in order to protect the jobs of young Australians. The Labor Party has opposed our attempts to reform further the unfair dismissal laws. The Labor Party, in summary, is an anti jobs party; the Labor Party is a pro high unemployment party. It not only demonstrated that in government but demonstrated it in opposition. I want to say to those who sit opposite and to the Australian people that, unless and until the Labor Party reverses its hostile attitude to the policies of the government designed to generate jobs in the Australian community, it will continue to be seen as irrelevant to the employment debate in Australia.

It is no accident that this country has lower unemployment now than for a period of 10 years. It is no accident that we are seen by the rest of the world as the economic strongman of Asia. It is no accident that our economy is the strongest it has been for more than three decades. All of that has been achieved in the face of a policy of obstruction and a policy of trying to defeat, delay and frustrate all the policies of the government which are designed to help the wellbeing of the Australian people. Despite the worst attempts of the Labor Party, we have succeeded. We have the economy on an even keel. The economy is growing strongly, jobs are being generated and there is a measure of economic optimism in Australia that nobody has seen for more than 30 years.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Finance and Administration. During your promotion of the second Telstra sale, why did you conceal the fact that you had instigated a secret probity inquiry into Credit Suisse First Boston, one of the coordinators of the sale? Haven't you undermined the integrity of the Telstra sale process, jeopardised Australia's reputation for financial transparency and misled the Australian people?

—I note that the honourable member for Melbourne last evening put out a press release relating to an issue concerning Credit Suisse First Boston and the trading of one of their arms in Japan. That particular issue has been reported in Japan and locally over the past several months. There is nothing new about that investigation; it has been the subject of some reporting in the media for some considerable time. Credit Suisse First Boston informed the government of investigations by the Japanese Financial Supervisory Agency into certain members of their firm in Tokyo at the time that the FSA commenced inspections, and they have continued to be cooperative and diligent in keeping the government informed throughout. As I said, it has been reported frequently in Japanese and international media during that investigation.

answer.para: In anticipation of the release of the findings, several weeks ago the government, as is appropriate, appointed former Chief Judge of the Commercial Division of the New South Wales Supreme Court Andrew Rogers QC as a probity adviser to review the findings of the FSA and other relevant material for any implications for the Telstra 2 share offer. I note that the member for Melbourne in the course of making some comments last evening continued to make some disparaging remarks about Andrew Rogers. You know there isn't an issue when they attack the messenger.

talk.start.para: —Yes, that's right.
—I suppose you didn't do it.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—You're attacking women again, are you?
—The Leader of the Opposition is not being aided by the Prime Minister or by members on his front bench.

—Can I go to the question of relevance, Mr Speaker: the minister was asked precisely why he had instigated a secret probity inquiry. He was not asked about the character of anyone conducting it. It would be interesting to know from him when he insti gated that inquiry and when he got to know about Credit Suisse First Boston's problem.
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. On the question of relevance, the minister is being entirely relevant and I invite him to continue his answer.

—I will continue in respect of the person that the honourable member for Melbourne asked me about, who was investigating as a probity adviser to the government. Whilst attacking this person, the honourable member for Melbourne failed to disclose that the New South Wales government only last year reappointed Andrew Rogers QC to the New South Wales Treasury Corporation. The New South Wales Labor government considers that person to be a fit and proper person, and he is entirely appropriate in this particular issue.

answer.para: The government expects a report from Mr Rogers in the near future, and it will not determine its views until it has that report. The government and I are committed to conducting the Telstra 2 share offer to the highest standard of probity and integrity, and we will not act without careful and mature consideration of the facts. I am not going to go to the knee-jerk reactions of the honourable member for Melbourne coming to simplistic conclusions on this particular issue about an incident in Japan. No advisers have been appointed for the Asia tranche at this time, and this particular issue, as I said, seems to be based by the honourable member for Melbourne on one week-old report in a Japanese newspaper.

talk.start.para: —I ask that the minister table the document he is reading from.
—Was the minister reading—
—It is confidential.

—I would like to add to the minister's answer. In the course of the honourable member for Melbourne's remarks about this—although he did not include it in the question—he has drawn critical comment on the fact that Andrew Rogers is married to a Liberal senator. That is quite despicable. I thought we were in the business of people having independence.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order on relevance. The Prime Minister in his remarks pointed out explicitly the fact that the honourable member for Melbourne did not mention the situation of the inquirer in the question he raised. So how can he be relevant? What we want to know and have not got an answer to is why he did all this in secrecy.

—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. The Prime Minister was seeking to add to an answer. I require him to be relevant to the question that was asked, and I invite him to add to the answer if he wishes.

—Critical comment has been made by the member for Melbourne about the fact that Andrew Rogers is the husband of Senator Helen Coonan, a Liberal senator for New South Wales. That is an irrelevance to his professional capacity, and you should apologise to the senator for having done it.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. My point of order is that the Prime Minister is not relevant to the question. It was about secrecy, about transparency and the government refusing to disclose—
—The member for Melbourne will resume his seat. I rule on the point of order that the Prime Minister is being entirely relevant.

—I remind the parliament that for all the time that Mr Justice McHugh has sat with honour and distinction on the High Court of Australia no reference was ever made when he was appointed to the fact that he was married to a Labor member of the ministry. I think the member for Melbourne owes Senator Coonan and Mr Rogers an abject apology.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, Australia's unemployment rate is at its lowest level since August 1990. What measures would be required to ensure that unemployment continues its downward trend, and what effect would any alternative policies which have been proposed have on unemployment?

—I thank the member for Makin for her question. Unemployment is one of the most critical issues facing the nation. I should pay tribute to the member because she has a well-deserved reputation in her electorate for the fact that she is a fighter for people who are unemployed, whether they are young people, mature aged or otherwise.

answer.para: There is no doubt that we have been pleased to see the success that we have seen in the last three years, with something like 470,000 jobs created since March 1996, compared to the 400,000 jobs that Labor destroyed when they were in office. How have we done this? We have done it by consistently advocating and implementing policies that genuinely make a difference, whether it is getting the budget back in order, further workplace relations reforms, getting interest rates down or helping small business. These are the practical things that have to be done if we are to create more jobs.

There is no doubt that, whilst 470,000 jobs is a good number in the time that we have been in government, this government is absolutely committed to its absolute priority to do more, to do better, to see more jobs created in the Australian community. There is no question also that in pursuit of that the government has a set of clear policies and reforms which we are working on seeking the endorsement of the parliament for. So obviously I was pretty interested when I heard that the Leader of the Opposition was finally going to make a statement about what Labor's policy might be on employment. We were delighted that he cancelled his overseas trip so that he could get around the country and formulate some real policies after the three years of vacuum that we have had so far from him.

But I have to say that my hopes were a bit dashed by his entry into the debate. He said in his speech, `Work incentives are approved'—this is what he wanted to ensure—`without cutting social security'. That is a bit of an interesting statement, because the day before he had actually put out a discussion paper that proposed cutting the dole for people who are unemployed, which was a consequence of his own policy, which for some reason he had barely seemed to understand. In fact, he was cutting social security benefits. When this policy was analysed during his own seminar, the shadow minister for employment by the Sunday was basically dumping it. That is an interesting development in itself.

What was more surprising was that the Labor Party held a seminar on unemployment, and the reason the Leader of the Opposition did not know that his policy proposal had been dumped by the rest of his frontbench was that he would not bother to turn up to his own seminar on unemployment. I do not know what he was doing, but he should have at least been taking an interest in the development of policy on his own side. More incredibly, after the whole idea had been dumped by the member for Batman, three days after this embarrassing episode, three days after it had been dumped by the shadow minister, the Leader of the Opposition was telling Carolyn Tucker of 4QR, `One of the ideas we are looking at is that part of your dole payment might be used as a job subsidy.' This is a proposition which has been advanced by the Labor Party leader and dumped by his own side, and he is still advocating that proposal.

talk.start.para: —I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. It goes to relevance. The minister was asked a question about the government's policy and whether he can guarantee the downward spiral of unemployment. Obviously he cannot, and he has not been relevant to the question at all.
—I noted the question as it was asked. The minister was asked about the government's policy and he was also asked about any alternatives. In that context he has been quite relevant.

—The simple point is that here we have the opposition claiming to develop policy and the Leader of the Opposition does not even turn up to his own seminar. He has now had the policy dumped by his spokesman and three days later he is back advocating it. I think the Australian public are entitled to know what exactly is the Labor Party's policy. The only concrete proposal that we actually had from the Leader of the Opposition was—wait for it—that he is going to have another discussion paper, another policy release in September. This is simply not good enough. The Leader of the Opposition is blaming the unemployed. The shadow minister is blaming employers. In both respects here we have Labor's hereditary peers with no idea of the circumstances facing unemployed people and no idea of what to actually do to create employment, using their numbers. And we have got another hereditary peer—No. 11 now; 11 hereditary peers—in the Senate. And what has been their approach so far to creating jobs? The one thing you have done is block every sensible proposal to actually create jobs. It is time you developed a policy.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Is the minister aware of comments by the Victorian Liberal Minister for Education, Phil Gude, who told last night's Four Corners program about literacy:

question.para: What [Dr Kemp] was clearly trying to do was to gain a profile on an issue, and I thought it was not cricket . . . to use the kids . . . in that way . . . I have found in my life that honesty has never got me into any trouble.

Does the minister also recall his press release of 23 April promising to publish `State and Territory Reading Data for Year 3' by 30 June this year? Minister, isn't the real reason that you have failed to meet your own 30 June deadline that the state education ministers have bypassed you and developed their own comparable tests rather than allow you to dishonestly manipulate their data?

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Education, Training and Youth Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —Australia today is engaged in a quite remarkable national effort to finally address the literacy problem that was left by the Labor Party after 13 years. When this government came to office, 30 per cent of young Australians could not read, write and spell at a satisfactory level. The Labor Party had nothing to say about that in office and it has nothing to say about it now. It is very interesting that, in the program that the shadow minister refers to, a program that went for some 45 minutes to an hour, there was not a single comment on that program on literacy from the Labor Party. The reason that there was not a comment is that there is nothing that the Labor Party has to say about literacy. It has no literacy policy whatever.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Speaker. The minister was asked a specific question. Why has he not met his own deadline of publishing the data by 30 June and why have the states bypassed him? That is the question.
—The point of order was a matter of relevance?
—Yes.
—I call the minister. The minister will respond to the question.

—The Commonwealth is engaged with the states at the moment in the implementation of the National Literacy Plan. All the states and territories have agreed to the national literacy benchmark. All the states and territories have agreed that they will assess, at the earliest possible moment, every child coming into school to see what their literacy needs are and, as a result of the Commonwealth leadership of the National Literacy Plan, this is now happening in every state and territory of Australia. Every state and territory of Australia has now committed itself to a process whereby every child in years 3 and 5 will be assessed to see what their literacy standard is against the national literacy benchmark. There was nothing at all like this attempted throughout the entire period of the Labor government.

answer.para: All the states and territories are now engaged in a process of assessing the preliminary results of the literacy tests given last year. The reading results were identified by an independent committee as being comparable between the states and territories, and that process is now proceeding. Every state and territory has committed itself to a process whereby every child is being assessed, including the Labor government in Queensland and the Labor government in New South Wales. All this is within the National Literacy Plan that the Commonwealth has established.

This government is determined that every child in Australia will have the opportunity to read, write and spell at an adequate level. We could not put up with the situation that we found when the Labor Party left office. If the member for Dobell were less interested in irrelevant rhetoric and more aware of what is actually happening on the ground and more aware of the concerns of parents, he would not ask such foolish and frivolous questions.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer advise the House of the success of the recent reduction in wholesale sales tax? What steps is the government taking to ensure that price reductions are passed on to consumers?

—I thank the honourable member for Fairfax for his question. The good news is that on 8 July this year the new tax system was proclaimed as legislation and 21 days later, on 29 July, Labor's wholesale sales taxes started to fall. The government is able to bring down Labor's wholesale sales tax rate of 32 per cent to 22 per cent and, as a consequence, we have already had, as a down payment on the new tax system, price reductions in relation to items like television sets, video players, stereos and cameras. Can I say, from this side of the House, how good it is to see Labor's wholesale sales taxes coming down and being abolished. We know that the Labor Party fought so hard for wholesale sales taxes but were unable to keep them.

answer.para: Members of the House know that I am an avid reader of regional and provincial newspapers. When I was reading the Queensland Times at Ipswich recently, I came across a story which quoted the Ipswich RT Edwards Store Manager, Brian McNamara, saying this:
I think it's a tremendous thing. It's great for the general public in terms of prices being more reasonable. It will boost businesses.
From the Northern Territory News , members of the House will be interested to know this:
Oasis Betta Electrical store, at Palmerston, owner Joe Fernandes said yesterday: "We have experienced an extremely busy day.
"Our most popular items have been rear projection television—we sold three in the morning—and hi-fi systems."
The West Australian , under the heading `Stores celebrate as tax cuts spur buyers', says:
Retravision WA chairman Geoff Kemp said the stores' biggest problem now was keeping up stocks.
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —This is Mr Geoff Kemp.

answer.para: Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —He is no relation. He is very literate, is Mr Geoff Kemp. He said:

answer.para: The floodgates have well and truly opened and we aren't complaining. We've already done 50 per cent more than what we would normally do on a good Thursday.
The Sunday Mail in South Australia said:
GST sparks sales boom.

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, charged with ensuring that price reductions are passed on to consumers, was active in ensuring that the first price cut from Labor's wholesale sales taxes was passed on. It found that 98 per cent of retail outlets had passed on tax gains to consumers. Five retailers who were found not to have done so are being followed up by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. There is a national inquiry telephone line to the ACCC which all Australians can ring if they believe there is evidence that wholesale sales tax cuts are not being passed on to consumers. I encourage Australians to do that. In the lead-up to the new tax system, those businesses that do not pass on proper tax cuts to consumers in price falls will be liable to penalties with fines up to $10 million.
This of course is the tax cut which Labor opposed. Presumably, it is now still their policy to reintroduce 32 per cent wholesale sales taxes.

talk.start.para: —That's right; it has to be.

—It has to be, because they are committed to wholesale sales tax—`a modern tax', according to ALP parlance; the tax that Labor fought so hard to defend. That is their policy. If they had any honesty, presumably they would announce when they would reintroduce the 32 per cent wholesale sales tax and on what items. We have had this whole false argument from the Australian Labor Party over the last year or so that they were only against taxes; they never actually had the honesty to tell you what they were really for. What they were always for was wholesale sales tax—the modern tax which is practised in Swaziland, Botswana and Ghana, and represents ALP thinking.

answer.para: The ALP, led by such progressive thought leaders as the Leader and Deputy Leader of the Opposition, stands for probably the most outdated, outmoded tax system in the world. It would be hard to think of a less progressive political force in relation to tax reform. Consumers know that to build a future for Australia we have to build a new tax system. They are beginning to see the benefit. This is the kind of reform which this government stands for, and we will continue to deliver it.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Do you recall telling this House on 12 May this year in answer to my question about the Princes Freeway between Melbourne and Geelong that:

question.para: The government has no plans to make any announcements in relation to matters that are not included in the budget for this year.

Are you aware of media reports this morning that the Commonwealth government has agreed to partially fund the upgrade of this road to enable an announcement to be made during the impending Victorian state election? In light of these reports, do you stand by your answer of 12 May, or will the Commonwealth government contribute to funding the upgrade of the Princes Freeway?

talk.start.para: —The first part of the question went to the heart of the answer that I gave last time. There is nothing misleading or in any way suspicious nor are there any points to be made from that answer. It was an honest one at the time. I am aware of a report floating around that seems to have emanated from an interview on 3AW. I have to say that no announcement has been made, no public announcement has been issued and there is nothing further to add. I do not know where that report came from.

—My question is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services. What measures is the government taking to ensure that rural and regional communities have access to basic services, and will these initiatives support jobs in the Riverina and generally in rural and regional areas?

—I thank the honourable member for her question. This government is particularly concerned about the challenges facing rural and regional Australia and about job opportunities for people who live outside our major urban areas at a time of enormous change. I believe that the efforts we are putting into improving the range of services available for people in country areas will bring real benefits to country people.

answer.para: Included in those initiatives are the transaction centres, that we promised during the last election with a funding envelope of some $70 million, and the objective of setting up such centres in several hundred small communities across Australia. We believe that the centres will make it easier for people to do business in country areas. It will mean they will have access to the services they need to keep doing business where they are rather than facing pressure to relocate to bigger centres or, worst of all, out of the bush altogether.

A few days ago we announced that in fact the first 22 communities to see rural transaction centres would now proceed. Seven communities are funded to go ahead straightaway to open up rural transaction centres. They are Eugowra in New South Wales, which is in the seat of the member for Calare; Urana in New South Wales in the seat of the member for Farrer—the middle bencher; Aramac in Queensland, in Capricornia; Dirranbandi in Queensland, and that is in Maranoa; St Marys in Tasmania in the seat of Lyons; Welshpool in Victoria in the electorate of Gippsland, and Gresford, which is in Paterson. There are a number of others—15 or so—that are preparing business plans, and they will shortly see rural transaction centres as well.
I must say the reaction has been absolutely terrific. The Border Mail commented on 23 July:
Urana, one of many small rural and Riverina communities battling a loss of basic facilities, now has a much brighter future.
The Eugowra Promotion and Progress Association has written to me, saying:

The community are delighted with the wonderful news that the federal government is to fund a rural transaction centre in Eugowra. Following the closure of Westpac Bank and National Australia Bank and the loss of other services in Eugowra, residents can now eagerly look forward to financial services again being provided through the rural transaction centre to be operating in our small rural town.

The other proposed services to be provided, for example Centrelink and Medicare, will also be most welcome. Our community and the Progress Association are most grateful to the federal government for making the funding available to set up the facilities of much needed rural transaction centres in places like Eugowra.

I think it ought to be recognised that quality of life issues such as access to decent health and education, and services of the sort that we are putting back with these initiatives, make a real difference in people's lives and in particular can influence them to remain living in, producing in and benefiting the nation in many far-flung rural, regional and remote communities.

I believe that these very worthwhile initiatives make doing business in country areas much easier and much more advantageous. I think that over time our approach will increasingly mean that the benefits of a rural life will be seen for the attractive options that they do present.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Does the minister still maintain that the government's petrol price deregulation should reduce the gap between city and country? Is the minister aware that, since this measure was put in place, the price gap has increased in almost three-quarters of New South Wales regional centres surveyed by the Australian Automobile Association? Minister, what are you doing to ensure that the country motorists do get a fair go?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I make the initial remark that I would be very reluctant indeed to take his data for granted. To assume that it was accurate I think in the first instance would be a very real mistake. The first point that has to be made is that world crude oil prices have been increasing rapidly in recent times after a period when they reached, in real terms and in historic terms, extremely low levels—the lowest levels for more than two decades. The price of the international benchmark crude, West Texas Intermediate, has risen from a low of a little over $11 in mid-February to well over $US20 at the beginning of August. That is an increase of more than 75 per cent.

answer.para: It is regrettable because we would all like to see fuel prices continue at those very low and attractive levels—probably in real terms the lowest they have ever been in recent months. No-one would like to see that more than I would, but we have to live in the real world. The fact of the matter is that, rightly, we price our oil at world levels in this country. It would be very unwise of us to pursue any other policy. As usual, Labor have attempted to blame us for that. I have seen one or two other people attempting to blame us for that as well. That is irrelevant; I think it is political opportunism and ought to be exposed for the dishonesty that it is.

I cannot help but close on this observation. We are the team in government that are doing something about the extraordinary levels of taxation on transport fuel in this country. They are the people who want to oppose it.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. People in my electorate of Forrest have welcomed the government's commitment to science and research for Australia's future. Is the minister aware of any response to the government's green paper on research and research training? Is the minister also aware of any alternative proposals which have been put forward on this issue?

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Education, Training and Youth Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Forrest for his question. The quality of Australia's science and research is one of our great comparative advantages in the global economy that is growing up at the present time. We cannot take that leadership and that outstanding quality for granted. One of the major purposes of the green paper on university research which the government issued was to put in place a funding framework for university research which will secure to Australian research environments the best and brightest of Australia's young researchers here in Australia and will make sure that the bright ideas that come out of Australian research will be commercialised effectively here in Australia.

answer.para: I am pleased to say that the paper has been recognised as a very important initiative by many of the leading people in Australian research. Professor Vicki Sara, the Chair of the Australian Research Council, said:
Taken together, the proposals in the discussion paper allow us to build a world's best practice research funding system.
The Chief Scientist, Dr Robin Batterham, said:

It is vital that we have a science and technology base that emphasises excellence, well-rounded training and the linkages across institutions and to end users. Dr Kemp's paper addresses all these issues and in my opinion makes some most appropriate changes to the existing system.
Tim Besley, the President of the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences and Engineering, said:
That the discussion paper's urging of universities to concentrate their resources in areas seen to be of future importance is very timely.
Professor Brian Anderson, President of the Australian Academy of Science, said:
The paper is a determined effort to put Australia's higher education research on a sounder footing.
I was very pleased to see the comment from Professor Barry Cunningham, the Vice-Chancellor of Southern Cross University, who wrote to me saying:

My preliminary reading indicated that it contains many appropriate and welcome options for consideration. Indeed, your statement that the paper offers a particular opportunity for regional universities seems to be very true.

The government's paper has been exceedingly well received within the science community. The government is listening to the discussion and comment on this green paper, which of course contrasts with the complete policy vacuum that exists on the other side of the House. There is no Labor Party policy for university research. The Labor Party's only proposal during the last election campaign was to cut research funding. By contrast, the government has put forward a positive set of proposals for Australian research to make sure that the best and brightest young Australians can find research environments here in Australia which will attract them back to this country, and that Australian science is conducted in an entrepreneurial climate which will make sure that the best ideas are effectively commercialised. This government has a policy; the Labor Party does not.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and concerns his denials yesterday of any knowledge of the request from the US military command in the Pacific for agreement to the attachment of Australian military officers to a possible peace enforcement operation in East Timor. Is it not a fact that these discussions took place in June and that the request was put directly at a very senior level, specifically to the Commander Australian Theatre, Air Vice Marshal Treloar? Didn't the Air Vice Marshal undertake to refer the request to top levels in the Australian government, and weren't you a specific recipient of the detailed report of these discussions six weeks ago? Minister, how do you explain your denials in question time and your subsequent statement claiming that you were completely unaware of these exchanges until you were told of them by your department last night? Don't you read important reports? Haven't you once again been caught out telling whoppers?

—First of all, this matter was not raised as you put it with the Australian government; it certainly was not raised with me. Secondly, it is true, as the Labor Party claim, that the cable, which you have apparently got hold of and which reports this conversation, was one of a number of cables that were directed to me. Honourable members might like to know that my department receives something like 186,000 cables every year, which is quite a lot, and 100,000 of them are directed to me. It will come as no surprise that no minister could read 100,000 cables—although I note that you can always tell when the member for Kingsford-Smith is reading, because his mouth is moving.

answer.para: Mr Beazley interjecting—

—Can the minister explain to the House the significance of the government's changes to interest withholding tax on corporate bonds? In particular, what impact will the changes have on home mortgage borrowers and small businesses in the regional financial capital of Parramatta?

—I thank the regional member for Parramatta, who is such a strong advocate of the interests of regional and rural Australia. On 29 June this year, the Senate at last passed TLAB2, a bill that included in it a provision to abolish interest withholding tax on corporate bonds. This has been an enormous success in Australian financial markets. I would like to quote from a report by Salomon Smith Barney, one of the largest investment banks in the world. It has a headline `Interest withholding tax gone—a new global era dawns!' It says:

answer.para: Removal of Australia's interest withholding tax is a major fillip for Australia's corporate bond market, and moves it closer to becoming more integrated into global capital markets. Removal is a major step toward a larger, deeper, more liquid domestic capital market. Up to a 50-fold increase in investor audience is possible . . .
It goes on to say:
Average spread reduction resulting from the . . . removal may range between 5-10 basis points, based on higher liquidity and lower transaction costs.

What does this mean for borrowers in Australian markets and particularly small and medium sized businesses? It means up to a 0.1 per cent reduction in the cost of loans. And that goes further, because if we create greater liquidity in the corporate bond market it means more money coming into Australia that can be lent at a cheaper rate to busines ses, to people borrowing for home mortgages and, particularly, to small business. The bigger the corporate bond market in Australia, the cheaper it is for Australians to build businesses, and that is good news for Australia.

That is a direct result of our tax changes—the tax changes which the Labor Party delayed for so long. Only at the last minute did they agree to pass the bill through the Senate. The impact is immediate, with up to $11 billion in issuance coming under the new regime and billions of more dollars coming on to the market immediately. In fact, Morgan Stanley has only recently—for the first time—entered the Australian corporate bond market with a $1 billion issuance. That is good news for Australian investors. And, best of all, it is good news for the battlers of Australia.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr BRUCE SCOTT
talker.role: Veterans' Affairs; Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I am actually the minister responsible for this area.
—He is the senior portfolio minister.

—Obviously the opposition were not listening. In answer to the question, we do not necessarily take for granted the figures that are issued as evidence from the other side of the House. We learnt that a long time ago. As the Minister for Defence said yesterday, we are reviewing the FBT reporting legislation to take into account the unique circumstances of our Australian Defence Force personnel and the circumstances under which they serve. For the benefit of those on the other side of the House, who are very slow to learn, for government benefits or payments like child support, there should be no inequitable treatment for Defence families due to their geographic location.

answer.para: The review will include considering how the reporting requirements apply to housing assistance provided to Defence personnel and certainly taking into account that, as military personnel, they must serve wherever the government demands. They are subject to frequent and compulsory moves by the Defence operational needs, which is very much part of our combat capability and our readiness to defend Australia and our interests. talk.start.para: —I direct my question to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Could the minister advise the House how the new SES funding model enables small schools, like the Warburton Christian School in my electorate, to serve the needs of local communities?

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Education, Training and Youth Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for McEwen for her question. I know how committed she is to giving all families in her electorate the right to choose their school. As announced in the budget, from 2001 non-government schools will be funded according to a measure of the socioeconomic status or level of their school communities. This is a much fairer system for funding non-government schools, which takes fully into account the capacity of school communities to pay. It is based on a process which links the addresses of students to collectors districts as identified by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. It is schools like the Warburton Christian School in the electorate of the member for McEwen which stand to gain from this model. It is perhaps worth making the point again that no school will lose as a result of this funding system.

answer.para: The member for McEwen has drawn my attention to a letter that she has received from the Warburton Christian School. I am delighted that the school acknowledges that the SES funding model will `enhance the choice of working class families'. The principal of the school, Mr Mike Dye, went on to say:
We wish to acknowledge your commitment towards the delivery of greater fairness and equity in funding in the non-government sector and for working families in particular.

Mr Dye went on to say that this new funding system will enable schools like his to better serve their community. This funding system that the government is establishing is in direct contrast to the Labor Party's attitude to school choice for working class families. The Labor Party's new schools policy was biased very strongly against the capacity of low income families to choose their school. It is only this government which has opened up the opportunities for every member of the Australian community to exercise a realistic choice of school.

The crux of the matter is that this government is committed to the strongest equity agenda that any government has pursued in education for a very long time. We are not only committed to getting every young Australian who can learn to read and write up to a satisfactory literacy level but also determined to give Australian families the right to choose their school so they can get the best possible education for their children.

Although the Labor Party jests about our efforts concerning trade, it is a very important matter, particularly for rural and regional people—our primary producers—in this country. As well as continuing to pursue and exercise our rights concerning the lamb issue in the WTO and the issue of exporting our beef to Korea, we are also exercising our rights on a bilateral basis. Recently the Thai government proposed an increase of approximately 80c a kilo on carcass import licence charges on beef into Thailand. We raised the issue with the Thai government and convinced it that that was not a good idea in terms of its obligations under the international trading regime of which we are all a part. That is just one example of our continuing efforts, in both a multilateral and a bilateral way, to represent Australia's interests in exports across the world.

answer.para: I was pleased to report that, with the help of Austrade, the Western Australian based Chiefton Management company has signed a $77 million contract to develop an industrial park on the outskirts of Mozambique's capital Maputo. This Western Australian company is investing overseas and bringing dollars back into Australia. The first stage of this park, as I say, is worth $77 million. It includes the site for an aluminium smelter that will be taking alumina from Western Australia, which again is important for Australia's exporters.

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It is difficult to imagine how anyone watching the performance of the House of Representatives this afternoon could be in any way impressed by the interjections that have just come across the chamber.
—I warn the member for Bruce.

—My question is to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. Minister, what is the government doing to help lamb producers in my electorate of Parkes and in other areas of Australia in the wake of the United States' dreadful decision to restrict the importation of Australian lamb?

question.para: Mr Adams interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I warn the member for Lyons.

—I thank the honourable member for Parkes for his question. Australia was of course dismayed by the decision of the United States to place tariffs and quotas on the importation of lamb into the US. We believe that decision was not soundly based. Australian lamb producers, in cooperation with their New Zealand colleagues, had developed a significant new market and had developed for themselves, without any kind of government subsidies or assistance, a niche in the US market which was providing good returns to Australian lamb producers but also offering a superior product on the US market.

answer.para: The Australian government has been forthright in objecting to this action at the very highest level—Prime Minister to President. We are following through with this process through the World Trade Organisation consultative process. We are seeking a ruling from the World Trade Organisation against the US action, but we cannot stand by and wait for the World Trade Organisation to respond. It is important that the Australian place in the US market be protected and it is important that we put in place the sorts of mechanisms that are necessary to support Australian exporters to the US so that they can remain commercially viable and intact when the tariff regime ends in 2002.

In negotiation with the industry, we have agreed upon the distribution of the quota. Some 16,300 tonnes of quota was distributed on 23 July, leaving around 800 tonnes of this year's allocation to be provided to new entrants or in special circumstances. In addition, the government has announced that it will be paying half the transaction levy applying to lamb sales in Australia. We are introducing a grant based program along the lines of the national pork industry scheme to help with market development and other upgrading in the Australian lamb industry. A lamb industry development advisory committee will also be overseeing this expenditure and supervising the quota arrangements.

These sorts of measures will help the Australian producer through this period, but that will not stop the Australian government from vigorously pursuing the illegitimate trade barriers that the US are placing in this regard. New South Wales farmers are currently protesting outside the US Embassy in Canberra. A large number of members on the government side, including the member for Parkes, joined them today in demonstrating our strongest opposition to the US decision. I call on the US government, even at this late stage, to review their decision and to make a decision that is responsible for any country that wants to be a leader in developing fairer trade around the world.

Miss JACKIE KELLY
talker.role: Sport and Tourism; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

talk.start.para: —I would like to thank the member for Wannon for his interest in women's sport. I know he has some outstanding female sportswomen in his electorate. answer.para: But our programs are not just about high performance. talk.start.para: — I have received a letter from the honourable member for Cunningham proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

interjection.para: The administration of the Defence portfolio by the Minister for Defence.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —At the outset one cannot help but remark that the Minister for Defence has gone AWOL without facing the charge. Let us hope that somebody is out there getting the security attendants in their new uniforms to rustle him up and bring him back in here to answer for the absolute shambles of a policy which he is trying to oversee within the Department of Defence. Once again in question time—as occurred yesterday—we witnessed Amateur Hour when the Minister for Defence, laughingly a cabinet minister, stood in this place and scoffed at tradition and at questions being put to him that went to the heart of the administration of an $11 billion a year Public Service department charged with the defence of Australia. The minister glibly said, in response to questions put to him on everything ranging from personnel matters through to security arrangements for Australia, `Well, everyone knows what the government's policy is,' and sat down to raucous laughter from his colleagues. Well, they must really think that Australia is just so well connected out there in the rest of the world that he can get away with that nonsense.

speech.para: Yesterday, the minister went on to say that he expected the highest standards of management from his department. Well, we expect the highest standards of management of his department from this minister. Yesterday we also saw reports that this man who oversights this department referred to senior personnel—and I understand the protocols of this place—as f-wits. We all know what that means. It is reported in the newspaper that this minister referred to senior people in his department in those terms. I find it incredible, but I can also understand why so many leaks are coming out of the Department of Defence. He really knows how to endear himself—the Minister for Defence—going around talking about people like that. But he has a bit of form, this bloke. When he came into government after 1996, he sacked his head of department. Now, of course, he is about trying to sack another bureaucrat, another head of his department.

The Barratt case raises some very interesting circumstances. I understand that, because of sub judice conventions and so on, we cannot go to the merits of the case or otherwise, but what we can do is point out some of the media commentary on this. It really is Days of Our Lives stuff. Mr Barratt was headhunted by the Prime Minister of this country and put into Defence after serving some time in Primary Industries. Because he survived a lemon hunt by Max `the Axe' Moore-Wilton trying to suss out those departmental heads that were no good and they reckoned he was pretty flash, he was given a performance based pay increase. Mr Moore, unfortunately, is a bit unhappy with him, but we do not know why, we do not know how long he has been unhappy with him. He has been distracted from all the duties he is supposed to perform as the Minister for Defence. We have the CDF, Admiral Barrie, saying that senior uniformed personnel have absolutely lost confidence in this minister. We have seen the CDF walking along arm in arm with Mr Barratt for photo opportunities—they are as one, and who is missing out of that little photograph? The minister. The minister is not there with his two senior people that run the defence department.

The minister is renowned for his sackings—it does not stop with departmental heads. He has gone through the Chief of Navy and his Assistant Secretary Acquisitions. I think Major General Hartley is in for the chop after today. Major General Hartley has blown the whistle on the lack of availability of medicos to serve people in the ADF—in times of war certainly but also in times of peace. We are talking about when they go on exercises, like Crocodile that is on at present, when they go to Shoalwater Bay and they are performing duties and training as soldiers, sailors and airmen. The only trouble is we do not have anybody to fix them up if they get crook or if there is an accident. But the minister said, `Don't worry. Everything's all right. I am assured that volunteers will be there at some stage down the track.' Maybe.

This botched attempt to remove Mr Barratt really does take on the parameters of The Bold and the Beautiful. The Canberra Times reported recently some of the details about how he went about sacking this person, quoting from an affidavit given by Max `the Axe' Moore-Wilton. It was fascinating stuff. Max said:

"I said to him, `Jesus Christ, the trouble with you blokes is you have no corporate memory. Barratt put up with years of this from the Labor Party. He has already been an ambassador and he hates Foreign'.
So you are trying to sack the bloke who is head of Defence, and you are going to put him in Foreign Affairs but he hates Foreign Affairs because he came from there once before.
The article continues:
"McIntosh thinks you might be interested—
this is Barratt—
in going to university in the US to learn about defence.

So Sir Malcolm McIntosh, who the minister wants to put in on a six months contract to look after Defence to sort out its problems—and only six months when it probably needs a five-year focus—has decided that the bloke who runs Defence at the moment needs to go to the US to a university to learn about defence. Do not ask me why, if he has got the sack, because he ain't comin' back. He is not coming back to Australia to run Defence. The article gets better. It goes on to say:
Mr Barratt's affidavit also quoted Mr Moore-Wilton telling him that [Foreign Minister Alexander] Downer—
and this is one of the other big three over there that we saw today, and they are pretty good—
"is collaborating in this because Ric Smith—
our ambassador in China—
is due out of China and there isn't a job for him in Foreign at the present time. The PM's office is also playing a hand in it."

Mr Barratt said he had replied that he had not the faintest interest in New Zealand, but "I might be tempted by Paris", to which Mr Moore-Wilton replied that "the trouble is that his mate likes it there".
Who is his mate? It is John Spender. John Spender is already in Paris and he is not going to come out. The article continues:
Mr Barratt said he had replied "well Max, people have to make choices. If I am to be put out to grass then the grass will have to be lush.

This is the farce we have in Defence at the moment. The minister is so caught up with worrying about his departmental head and giving him the flick that he cannot concentrate on the most important issues.

What are the important issues? Firstly, there was the birthday bash at the barracks for the Prime Minister. That was a big event. He had to worry about that because the minister trotted along with a few invited guests. We all remember this photo.

talk.start.para: —Look at the fur!

—Never mind the fur—he is illegal. Why? He is not wearing a seatbelt. He is in a Comcar and he is not wearing a seatbelt. That is against the law. Bob Hawke got into trouble over that. Will this minister? Maybe. But the other issues of concern in Defence at the present time run seriously and they run deep.

speech.para: With the Defence Reform Program, this minister is oversighting, supposedly, savings of $1 billion to be directed to the pointy end of Defence. What has he got so far? He has a force structure that nobody quite knows what it will end up at. People are bailing out left, right and centre. Why? They are unhappy, morale is low and then this government sticks a fringe benefits tax requirement on them.

talk.start.para: —He didn't know that.

—We have asked questions about it. I have to say that the shadow minister for industrial relations is dead right. I do not think that until yesterday the minister knew anything about the fringe benefits tax and the effect it had on the 43½ thousand—or nearly 50,000 now, but they want to get it down to 43½ thousand—serving defence men and women. He had no idea about the effect that might have.

speech.para: This minister has elevated a second brigade to 28-day readiness so that we have two such brigades. The money required for that—at least $200 million a year to keep it ready—is fine if we need it, but with the savings that are supposed to come from the Defence Reform Program that are not happening they are not redirecting that money anywhere. As we pointed out twice in the last two days, surgical teams are trying to provide capability—and Major General Hartley has commented on what that means.

The Prime Minister has made a commitment on FBT that no group would be worse off under any of the changed tax regime introducing the GST. This minister should know something about the present strategic environment that is out there. We know he has been to Bali with the Prime Minister to talk with the Indonesians, but I seriously wonder if he has turned his attention to things that are required in the strategic review that is under way that will lead to a white paper. The strategic review will be secret; the white paper will be published next year. When the last strategic review came out, two weeks later the Asian economy crashed and yet that strategic review did not even pick it. That had an effect on Australia's capability and the acquisition we need in terms of replacement of the platform for the Australian Defence Force to do what it is supposed to do—defend Australia—and decisions were being made on false premises coming out of that document.

There are also the questions of East Timor and ongoing peacekeeping arrangements in Bougainville. There is the question of continuing defence support for Papua New Guinea. Comments are being made about the minister not knowing that his department is generating intelligence reports and passing them on to Alexander Downer's foreign affairs department—and I bet he does not read them, and if he did he would not know what was in them—and telling them all about Indonesia and East Timor. That is military intelligence coming in that this minister does not know anything about. He then jumps up and down and says, `Oh, don't do that again! Don't do that without telling me! And you're not going to give any of those military secrets away without telling me!'

Who is running that department? When we start to talk about things like block obsolescence—that is, when we need to replace destroyers, F18s, F111s, patrol boats and all those things—who is going to make decisions on this? Not the Minister for Defence—the absent Minister for Defence who is not even here to answer the charge. He cannot concentrate because he is too worried about sacking Mr Barratt and trying to work out which option he should take.

We actually know. The way things are going there is another problem coming for him. We have already seen this. A couple of weeks ago, the minister proudly announced to all and sundry that a $2 billion contract for the new airborne early warning system has just been let to Boeing. What do we find out today? Boeing is being investigated by the United States Congress because it might be giving away secrets. We are in a partnership with the US and yet that arrangement is being investigated by the Congress to see how many of their secrets are being given away. This minister is presiding over $2 billion worth of public expenditure on some platform that we need. However, now questions are being raised over how successful that is likely to be and whether we are going to get all the information we need.

We could also talk about Olympic security or the reserves. If this minister actually got out of the Bushmasters or the photo opportunities being provided on the FFGs or something else and talked to his personnel, he would know that they are concerned about the future of the reserves in this country. People are not prepared to sign up anymore. The need for the reserves to be part of the general defence of this nation is increasing. As we keep raising our preparedness, as we keep increasing the availability of highly trained personnel to participate in all sorts of activities in our region, there is a strategic vacuum. There is a lack of regional leadership coming from this minister and, as a consequence, our international reputation is going through the floor.

This minister needs to do more than simply stand there taking salutes at base visits. He needs to be accountable. He needs to be responsible. He is required by the normal standards of this parliament to come into this place and provide answers to genuine questions being put to him by members of the opposition or to respond to newspaper commentary that even his own department's newspapers are putting out. Army and Navy publications are both raising issues about FBT and other concerns that they have at the moment.

And these are government controlled authorities—a bit like the old Soviet bloc, but they are even allowing letters to be published saying that the FBT impact is just horrendous. We have the office of the revolution in military affairs, which I have said also sounds a bit Stalinist, but that has been created in the department. That is fine, because it has a job that it is going to do. But I have to say that this minister is not doing his job. Yesterday in question time when a question was put to the Prime Minister about the confidence of the ADF in this minister, the Prime Minister after a glib response turned to the Minister for Defence and said, `You owe me a case of Grange for that.' The Minister for Foreign Affairs said, `It would be cheaper if you just resigned.' Dead right! As Barratt said:
The problem with John Moore is that he does not do his homework and he will not listen.

That was reported in the Courier-Mail on the seventh of this month. It is time not for Mr Barratt to go but for the Minister for Defence, who is on his last tour of duty, to probably think about taking the Wellington or the Paris option himself. This afternoon, though, it is time for this minister to come into this House to explain himself and to defend his handling of his department.

talk.start.para: —I have heard some pretty woeful presentations here, but that one really takes the cake. This afternoon I have been sitting here waiting to hear something of substance, but where is it? It seems that the member for Cunningham could not even remember what the topic of the MPI was; he never once mentioned the topic. He got up and spoke for 15 minutes and could not even remember what he had decided was going to be the topic for the MPI.

speech.para: But it gets worse than that. Let us go back to question time. We sat there waiting, thinking he was going to get on to defence, but it took 15 questions before the member for Cunningham could ask a question on defence. It is amazing. It is such an important issue that he cannot remember what his matter of public importance is about and he cannot even get a question up until the 15th question in question time today. When we look at the quality of the questions he put up it is no wonder he was so low down on the list. In the first question he tried to misrepresent the minister's answer from yesterday. If he does not believe me he can check the Hansard; he ought to have read properly what the minister's answer was yesterday before he tried to misrepresent it. When he got the next call his silly question asked the minister to tell him what happened in cabinet. Really and truly, he has been around a bit longer than that. If he was going to ask a serious question he would not be asking that sort of question.

The member for Cunningham then went on to ask some silly questions of the Minister for Trade. His last question rehashed a subject he had brought up yesterday—nothing of substance about defence or the importance of defence for this nation. Yet it is rather curious that, in the course of his address, he did admit at one stage—I do not think he meant to—that this minister has increased the state of the Defence Force's preparedness. In other words, serious things are happening, very important things are happening, and this government is really making them happen. Yet the member was so busy talking about the gloss and all the little newspaper reports he wanted to read that he never got into any substance about the importance of the defence of Australia and the fact that this government not only has a very good policy but also is implementing that policy.

It was just amazing that the member for Cunningham got up and read a newspaper article. It was suburban theatre antics. If that is all he can do—read a newspaper article and try to put all these wonderful theatrics in it—it is not a very effective presentation. You would have to say that it was a very superficial effort and one that his colleagues would be very disappointed with. If this is the best that the opposition in the parliament of Australia can do it is not only a great disappointment to the people of Australia but also an insult to Defence personnel, this parliament and the people of Australia.

We ought to get real. More than just talking and having these ideas rolling off the tongue—all the right words about the various things that are happening in Defence but never getting into substance—we really have to look at some of the important things. To get the record going properly, I will read from the newsletter that the Minister for Defence—the person that I think we are trying to talk about—issued in June 1999. In an `Overview of Australia's defence priorities' he says:
The defence of Australia has been a major priority of the Howard Government and continues to be so during our second term.
I say, `Hear, hear,' and anyone who has any interest in defence would fully agree with that. He goes on to say:
We are strongly committed to building a stronger and more secure Australia.
Again, that is what Australians want and expect and what Australians are getting. The article continues:
An Australia that is able to defend itself and able to take its place confidently in an uncertain world.
It is important to note those words. He goes on to say:
The government takes the challenge of rebuilding the nation's Defence capability just as seriously as it took the challenge of rebuilding the economy.
Note the word `rebuilding'—not `building'—because of some of the difficulties and problems we inherited from the previous Labor government. He goes on to say:
In fact, the Defence budget has been maintained in real terms for four years now—
There have been no cuts like under the previous government; we have actually maintained the budget in real terms—
and we propose to continue this level of commitment through the life of the forward estimates in this year's Budget.
Also, as the minister goes on to say in his newsletter:
We also are committed to obtaining the greatest value possible for each Defence dollar spent.

This is when we start to get serious about what this government is on about. We should make no apologies for the fact that this government not only expects high standards but it insists on high standards and insists that they be met in the defence department and in any other area of administration, but we are particularly talking about Defence today.

These very high standards are expected to be met by staff in the department as well as those who are out in the combat areas. Frankly, the men and women in the field not only expect this but deserve it. They deserve nothing less than the highest of standards. I would have thought that any reasonable and, indeed, any responsible opposition would have supported these standards.

talk.start.para: —We support the diggers, I can tell you.

—You ought to support a bit more. What about the high standards of the defence department? I think that the government has a very good record in the area of defence. It is one that we are very proud of and one that we are building on. Can I say that all of this in this term of parliament is due to the very good work being done by the Minister for Defence. The excellent work he is doing will mean that we have an even better defence effort than we already have.

speech.para: When we talk about the ability of the Minister for Defence, we ought to actually recognise what he has done as a minister and, most importantly, what he is doing as the Minister for Defence. The first thing is that he has demonstrated since we have been in government that he is a man who gets results. That is very important. Given the importance of the defence of this country, we have to have a minister of this sort of calibre. Follow ing some very good work done as the industry minister, he has now built on that as defence minister. One of the areas where the minister has really demonstrated his ability is in picking the best people to work with him. It is a very significant factor. It is something which many ministers on the other side who may have had ability often failed to do—to get people working with them and working for them who were the very best available. That is exactly what this minister can do. When I listen to some of the petty, nitpicking things that come from the opposition, I think they have completely overlooked this very significant fact.

The other point I would like to reinforce on the ability of the Minister for Defence is that he gets his portfolio issues through the cabinet. Again, that is a very significant thing. He then gets them through the government ranks and he gets them through the parliament. All of these are very important. When we look at things like the budget and when we look at the fact that the defence forces are now in a situation where the member for Cunningham admitted they are in a better state of preparedness, I think we have got to recognise that the minister has been doing that.

It is also important just to reflect a little bit on the legacy we inherited from Labor. The great concern that many people who really understand defence had about Labor is the drift that was going on in the defence forces through the lack of clear priorities. There is no doubt that the combat capability was declining. There is no doubt that the administration, the bureaucracy, was growing. Time and again we saw that equipment budgets were blowing out not only in cost but also on their time frame. When you look at all that and look at the number of times Labor let the defence forces down, and more significantly let the defence of Australia down, it is no wonder that people in Australia changed government. I think that in many ways it is a cheek of the opposition to come in here and try to raise this issue when they really have not got a lot to crow about in their own achievements.

When we look at the record on defence spending, what we see is that the spending promises were always kept for defence expenditure whereas, on their promise to increase, only 23 per cent was ever delivered. When we look at the question of combat capability, we saw ships being fitted out for but not with equipment—so leaving gaps. In other words, the ships were there but there were a few things missing, and if it came to actual engagement they were a little light on. But Labor thought, `We can defer that because we can make budget cuts and it does not look too bad.' We look at the some of the mismanagement. There were a couple of rusty second-hand ships that cost us the earth because of all the money that had to be spent to bring them up to a serviceable standard. We saw what happened with the over-the-horizon radar. What a shambles, what an embarrassment. We hear people talking about cost blow-outs and we look at what that cost us. We look at the run-down in the Army capability. We look at the units that were lacking equipment. We look at the inefficiency that was growing. It just went on and on.

What was even more disturbing, certainly to those who had a keen interest in defence, was looking at Labor's 1998 election policy. You would think Labor might have learned something. Having been chucked out in 1996, they might have had a look and thought, `Defence is pretty important. We had better have a good look at it.' As someone put it unkindly, the policy for 1998 probably took 30 minutes to write, five minutes to read and about 30 seconds to dismiss. What were they going to do? First of all, they were going to have an Anzac battalion. It sounded all right, but they had forgotten something. The New Zealand defence minister, Mr Max Bradford, said, `Hey, whoa,' so that one disappeared. The next thing was that they wanted to cancel the upgrade of the Hornets. That might have saved them a bit of money, but it meant this great gap because we probably could not get a replacement in under 10 years. And if we did not upgrade them then what were we going to do—keep running aircraft that were more and more out of date? As I think the member for Cunningham would know, Australia's defence is very much based on the fact that we have to maintain a technological advantage in the region. That was the second part of the election policy which disappeared without trace.

The third one was—this was a beauty—buy two more submarines. We all know the embarrassment with the submarines at the moment. They were going to buy a couple more. What about fixing up the ones we have already got? We have to admit that the state of preparedness of our submarines is a source of considerable embarrassment, particularly as the only operational submarine we have got is the old Oberon one. To keep that running, we have had to actually cannibalise parts out of one that is sitting in a park in Holbrook. It really is an embarrassment. I do not think the Labor Party would want to go into too much of the history of the Collins class submarines, because we know when those decisions were taken.

talk.start.para: —You've been dealing with them for three years.

—It is important to note who is fixing them up. This government and this minister are taking the tough decisions to fix up the problem, and the problem will be fixed. As the honourable member for Cunningham would know, this report is very significant and it will be acted upon. So it is important to note that this government is going to make these things happen.

speech.para: Labor were going to reinstate the Ready Reserve, but they did not quite say where they were going to get the money to run that. The last time they brought in the Ready Reserve, two battalions went west. Then they were going to build an offshore weapons range, but that was going to cost a heap of money, and we do not know where that money was coming from either. What that really said was that there was a lack of strategic vision and, listening to today's debate and the views put forward by the spokesman from the Labor Party, that strategic vision is still sadly lacking. It is sad because we are talking about something that is very important for Australia. It is very sad that defence, which is such an important issue for all Australians, should be reduced to this level by the opposition.

Clearly, we want to see defence forces that really have high standards. We are making those standards. It is disappointing that the opposition will not support those efforts, but I am proud to be able to stand up here and say that this government and the Minister for Defence are really doing a first-class job in improving the standards of our Australian defence forces, improving their readiness and, most importantly, ensuring that the defence of Australia is being improved so that we can continue to live the lives that all of us so dearly want. talk.start.para: —Firstly, let me say to the member for Wannon that I am sorry you have been asked to carry the can for someone whom you need to apologise for. speech.para: I am also sorry for the member for Wannon because, pal, you were sold a dump. talk.start.para: —Where is he now?

—Why won't he come into this place? Why won't he come and defend himself? I say to the member for Longman, who I understand is speaking next, that you were a serving officer; you understand the importance of these things to Defence Force personnel.
—The member for the Northern Territory will address his remarks through the chair.

—He will understand, Mr Deputy Speaker, that his former colleagues in the defence forces are standing back and saying, `We have lost respect for this minister. He is a shame on this government. We have lost respect because of his lack of sincerity. We have lost respect because of his lack of intelligence, because the bloke's a dill.'
