I have to say to the member for Longman and to the member for Wannon—and I am not quite sure what the simile is but there must be one—that you have been given the greatest dump on earth. Not even you have any respect for this minister.
—Cannon fodder.

—Is that the description I am looking for? You are absolutely cannon fodder. I do not know if there is any promotion in it for you, but I have to tell you there is a vacancy coming up soon. He has gone AWOL, he is not in here to defend himself and he is not here to advocate his position.
—Give us substance.

—You want to hear about substance. I will tell you a bit about substance: this minister is incompetent. I have been a member of this parliament off and on for 10 years and I can say to you that the concerns being expressed by the defence forces about the malaise in the Department of Defence and the lack of leadership by this minister are unprecedented.

speech.para: I have had representations from personnel from all three forces, from every rank, expressing their concern about the lack of leadership of this minister—his lack of authority, his lack of knowledge, his lack of commitment and his lack of understanding of the strategic imperatives of the Defence Force. He does not know, does not care and does not understand. Defence staff are rightly upset at the wiping out of benefits that compensate them for the unique hardships and transient nature of service life. We are not talking about lurks and perks here—and you know we are not talking about lurks and perks. We are simply talking about the benefits that help families survive while they are doing their jobs. The Top End is a focal point for Australia's defence strategy, and already it is extremely difficult to recruit qualified personnel and to attract ADF families there.

We have heard about the specialist surgeons. We have a 28-day ready for 1 Brigade in Darwin. Possibly they are going to be deployed somewhere or other in the near future—or possibly in the longer term. But, if they are deployed tomorrow, they cannot take a medical team because there is no—

talk.start.para: —Rubbish.

—`Rubbish,' he says. I can tell you it is not rubbish. They would not be able to take a medical team because there is not one currently available. The minister acknowledged as much here in this House yesterday.

speech.para: I have had serving personnel come to see me about this, and I have to say to you that they are concerned by the perfidy of this minister who has a responsibility to represent and reflect the needs of these 50,000 Australians. He has failed to represent their interests in cabinet, contrary to what the member for Wannon has said. He has failed, either as a direct result of indolence, ignorance or malevolence, to comprehend the tragic and negative impact of his own government's policy on ADF personnel.

The morale of the ADF is being continually and severely undermined by his incompetence and by the implications of the ineptitude of the minister and the Howard government in coming to terms with the inevitable operational impacts of their absurd policies. Do they comprehend that separation rates from the defence forces will magnify by 10 or a hundredfold? Thousands of defence personnel have indicated they will leave the defence forces if this FBT thing is not fixed. What will that do to the operational readiness of the Australian Defence Force? It will wreck it. What capacity will we then have to recruit new people to come and fill their roles? What possibilities will we have to recruit those people in time to train them up to the operational standards that you, as a former serving officer, would require of them? You know, I know, that we are right. The minister has been totally irresponsible.

talk.start.para: —Where is he?

—He is not here. We ask that question again: where is he? Why isn't he here? Why is he AWOL? Why doesn't he come here? Because he is worried about his preselection for the seat of Ryan. He knows there are 150 new people on the branch books in Ryan ready to roll him. So, instead of being occupied by his job as Minister for Defence, he is preoccupied by the branch stacking in his own electorate which is designed to knock him off. Do you know what I say to those branch stackers? I say, `Good on you. Get rid of the bloke because he is an incompetent.' He is an absolute incompetent, and it is about time the Prime Minister took his role seriously as the leader of this government, as the erstwhile leader of this nation—erstwhile responsible for oversighting the work of the Minister for Defence. Why doesn't he pull him into order? Why doesn't he pull him into line? Why doesn't he send him into this chamber to make sure that he defends himself? Because of that, I move:

speech.para: Let us just answer some of the questions that have been put here this afternoon. The first one is about medical officers and their availability. The charge has been that, if the 1 Brigade, which is based in Darwin, had to go overseas tomorrow, they would not be able to take a medical team with them. I am advised that the Chief of the Defence Force says that the ADF has an appropriate medical capacity to support the ADF deployment in regional contingencies. So if the Chief of the Defence Force says that, where do you lot get your information from? From the back of newspapers as always. You do not actually deal with any facts. You deal with rhetoric and rubbish, and it is about time you dealt with facts. There are enough medical facilities and medical staff for the defence forces.

For the benefit of the member for the Northern Territory, I was a serving officer. I served with 2/4 RAR in Townsville. Do you know what we had as a medical officer under a Labor government? We had a gynaecologist. Do you know how many women there are in 2/4 Royal Australian Regiment? Zero—not one. But the Labor government administration saw fit to provide us with a gynaecologist. A really top effort. Well done. Congratulations to Beazley and his mates who were of course running the show then. That is how much the Labor Party know about the medical profession and what is needed. I will let you in on a little secret: there are not too many infantry soldiers in our Army that actually get pregnant.

Now let us move on to Boeing and the announcement that the minister made recently about the AEWACs. On 10 August, an article appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald—it is good to see that you are up on your literacy and can actually read—which suggested that Boeing had a problem with the American Defence Department. I can assure you that, as far as this government is concerned and the contract that we have entered into, there will be no problem whatsoever in delivering those services to Australia. That is what should be important to the opposition, to the wider community and the defence forces. Those aircraft will provide a very much needed capacity for Australia's defence. The matter of public importance today is about substance, and all we have had is rhetoric from those opposite. We have had nothing about our capacity to be able to defend our nation, which is what the defence forces are supposed to be about.

Yesterday, the Leader of the Opposition asked a question. He said, `. . . at a time when the government has just doubled the size of ADF units on 28-days combat alert.' This minister announced that, by 1 July this year, the Australian Defence Force would be able to double its capacity for ready, alert soldiers. In other words, 1 Brigade in Darwin was going to be brought up to 28-day readiness. I thought at the time that that was a very ambitious task.

I was in 1 Brigade back in 1979 when we decided to bring 3 Brigade up to such a standard, and it is exceptionally difficult to do. A good friend of mine is currently the commanding officer of the 5th/7th Battalion and, as the minister has already informed this House—and I am pleased to reiterate—that they have managed to do that and it means that Australia's Defence Force capacity has been greatly boosted. That did not happen by accident. That did not happen under 13 years of Labor. That happened under the member for Ryan, the Minister for Defence, in this Howard government. That is what managing defence and administration is all about: having combat forces that are able to meet the defence needs of this nation.

I have just mentioned that we do have the medical forces that are necessary—the MOs—and we have the new Boeings coming on line for the AWACs. Now we can talk about the Defence Reform Program. The shadow minister stated in his address earlier on that he did not know where the savings were going to come from. In this financial year, 1999-2000, it was forecast that there would be a $455 million saving to defence which could go into the sharp end—that is, people who actually carry weapons and actually make a difference at the front. In fact, we will be $67 million ahead of that plan. They are the facts—unlike the rhetoric and rubbish that we cop from the other side.

The shadow minister also said that there were no cuts to defence under the previous Labor government. I questioned him across the chamber. I said, `No cuts?' and he said, `No, not one; none at all.' The fact is that whilst they were in government, they promised growth in defence spending of 4.5 per cent in 1984-85 but they did not deliver it; in 1985-86, again 4.5 per cent but they did not deliver it; and 3.8 per cent in 1986-87, but they did not deliver it.

talk.start.para: —Just have a look at the real growth.

—They did not deliver it. It is like me saying to you, `We're going to give you some extra money to buy capability next year, the year after and the year after that,' and then you make plans to train your soldiers so that they are at the highest levels of competency and then, when in government, you let them down. You pulled the rug out from under their feet. You did not just do it for one year; you did it right through from 1984 to 1991. In 1991, you promised two per cent and again you provided zero, zilch, nothing—not a cent. That is the sort of commitment that the Labor Party showed Defence in 13 years. You can shake your head all you like—the facts are there.

speech.para: I was actually a serving member of the defence forces from 1979 through 1988. I had to endure the disgusting depletion of our resources by the Labor Party. We had a situation where you have two men to train 10 soldiers to use two machine guns—two M60s, which quite often went off when they were not supposed to because they were that badly worn. And you talk about morale! That is what sends morale down the tubes—when soldiers are not game to point the rifle in the right direction because they are not sure whether it is going to go off at the right time.

Let us get to the major programs. JORN is an over-the-horizon radar. It has allowed us to detect movement in the sea-air gap to our north. It was a brilliant piece of strategic thinking. Let us look at the administration, since this is what this matter of public importance is about. When over 80 per cent of the money was paid out in that contract, it would be logical to presume that you would have about 80 per cent of the product delivered. Not under the Labor Party. Under the Labor Party, around 25 per cent of the product was delivered for an 80 per cent cost. And did it work? No; it did not even work. What do those opposite have to say now? They have all gone awfully flaming quiet, haven't they? They go quiet when they get something of substance thrown back at them about what their incompetence did to the Australian defence forces and our capacity as a nation to defend ourselves.

Let us turn to submarines. The submarine saga has been going on for many years. Let me just talk about the combat system, since we have only a couple of minutes left. I will quote from a report entitled Report to the Minister for Defence on the Collins class submarine and related matters. At page 10 it states:
The combat system is at the heart of the issues associated with getting an overall favourable outcome for the Submarine Project.
It goes on to say:
Although known about earlier, the problem was first seriously highlighted in 1993—
when the Labor Party was in government—
but the opportunity was not then taken to make fundamental changes in the configuration of the system or in the choice of subcontractor.

The report goes on to say that this litany of errors and poor administration basically led to the fact that today Australia has such a poor submarine capacity that, if it were needed to send off the submarines, the lives of our submariners would be put in danger. talk.start.para: —Before I commence my remarks on the Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1999 , I acknowledge the presence in the upper gallery of students and teachers from Brooke Avenue Public School in my electorate, who I am sure, like all of us, are very interested in matters affecting education in Australia.

speech.para: This bill abolishes the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, commonly known as NBEET, along with the Australian Language and Literacy Council, the Employment and Skills Council, the Higher Education Council and the Schools Council. It retains the Australian Research Council, although we were advised in the long awaited research green paper that the government wants to establish the ARC under its own act. We can be grateful for some small mercies because in the earlier drafts of the research green paper that were leaked late last year there was some doubt about what role the ARC would be left with. There was also some suggestion that the entire peer review process for awarding research grants would be completely undermined. We welcome the fact that the initial proposals by the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs have been dumped by the government and we look forward to the ARC being placed on a firm footing under its own act.

NBEET was established in 1988 to provide advice to the government on issues relating to education and training as a unified advisory mechanism outside the department. It was seen as an important component of the program of reform in employment, education and training. The then minister, John Dawkins, told the House of Representatives during the second reading of the legislation establishing NBEET:

The central purpose of this Bill is to enhance and streamline advisory structures in employment, education and training in a manner consistent with the high economic and social priority placed on these activities by the government.

Unlike the Hawke and Keating governments, the Howard government has given no priority whatsoever to education and training issues. In that sense, it is no surprise that the Howard government would regard a body like NBEET as being a target for termination. NBEET initially comprised a board to report directly to the minister, and four advisory councils: the Australian Research Council, the Employment and Skills Formation Council, the Higher Education Council and the Schools Council. In 1995, the Australian Language and Literacy Council was added to the structure, while the Australian International Education Foundation Council is in fact a committee of the board. Neither the board nor its councils have had any program delivery role, unlike previous advisory structures such as the Tertiary Education Commission and the Schools Commission. The Australian Research Council, however, makes recommendations about the allocation of research funds.

A specific value of NBEET lay in its ability to examine issues on a cross-sectoral basis, at a time when the traditional barriers separating schools, vocational education, higher education and labour market programs were being pulled down. The direction of recent discussions on such issues all seek to reinforce the importance of developing cross-sectoral perspectives. Let me give four examples: firstly, the convergence of general and vocational education; secondly, the nature and importance of employment related key competencies, articulation, credit transfer and recognition of prior learning both within and between sectors; thirdly, how to enable people to follow `pathways' through different parts of education and training institutions to achieve the combination of skills and knowledge which they need; and, fourthly, the emergence of the often discussed concept of lifelong learning. All of these examples serve to reinforce the importance of developing and receiving cross-sectoral advice to the government.

The revolution in methods and technologies for delivering education and training is also contributing to the blurring of traditional divisions. Final year high school students can now undertake university studies as part of their school program, while many vocational courses can now be or will be able to be delivered in workplaces and schools, rather than only in TAFE colleges. I recently had the privilege of visiting Casuarina Senior College in Darwin. It is great to see the number of course options which students at that college are now able to choose. It is a fascinating example of a school which is making sure that the resources it has built up over many years are available not only to the students but also to the parents at night, thus ensuring that adult education is advanced in their local community.

The issue of the need for cross-sectoral perspectives was taken up in submissions to the Senate inquiry into this bill's predecessor—the government's first attempt to abolish NBEET—the Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1996, which never completed its passage through the parliament. In a submission to that inquiry, Professor lan Chubb, Vice-Chancellor of Flinders University and a former Deputy Chair of NBEET, said:

If some relationship between employment, education and training is assumed, then I believe a minister will need some body or other to integrate the often conflicting advice that will come from the various interest groups and to turn it into policy advice.
Professor Chubb went on to say:
I have seen no good reason put forward for the abolition of NBEET.
Nor has the opposition seen any good reason put forward for the abolition of NBEET. Mr Peter Laver, a former chairman of NBEET, told the Senate inquiry:

One of the benefits of the national board's structure has been the confederation style, where six councils basically report through a board to the Minister. This means that the implications of various pieces of advice are fully considered by putting it through the board so that the cross-sectoral aspects are accommodated prior to the advice being forwarded to the Minister and tabled in Parliament.
Mr Laver also said:

The other thing that I would have to say about the board is that in terms of providing advice—I have been associated with other government advisory bodies in the manufacturing industry and in science and technology and in rural areas—NBEET is quite a cost-effective way of doing it. The cost of running the national board compared to its output is a pretty good investment.
Mr Laver's views about the effectiveness of NBEET were shared by Professor Ken Wiltshire, who conducted the review of the board, which reported in February 1994. The report concluded:
It can reasonably be stated that NBEET has fulfilled the bulk of the high expectations which were held for it six years ago.
The executive summary of the Wiltshire review talks in the following way about the changes facing Australia:

We still do not have, in this country, a clear enough understanding of, and a better capacity to address, the crucial linkages between the nation's economic performance, its employment parameters, and the implications for the role of the education and training sectors.

These challenges face all nations in the approach to the next century and millennium, but Australia is better positioned than most, with a portfolio grouping aligned to these dominant themes, and an independent body capable of marshalling the requisite knowledge and expertise . . .
Again quoting from the executive summary of the Wiltshire review:

The themes which should be the challenge for NBEET in its second era are intersectoral and international, for it will be policy advice of this kind on which Australia will depend and which any vision of this nation's future will encompass.

In the face of this advice from the Wiltshire review, the coalition took to the 1996 election a policy to dismantle NBEET, with no reasons given and, more importantly, no structure to replace it. One of the first things the Howard government did on coming to office was to prepare legislation to cut itself off from independent advice from a body with almost a decade of corporate knowledge about the importance of linking together employment, education and training issues. The 1996 legislation, however, retained the Higher Education Council, whose role it has been to provide considered advice to the government through the board on directions, priorities and funding issues related to higher education.

The Higher Education Council also had the important responsibility of monitoring the impact of HECS—the Higher Education Contribution Scheme—on participation in university education. It has done this through a series of reports tabled in parliament. In its sixth such report, published in March 1992, the NBEET board said:
The Board noted the results of the Council's commissioned research on the impact of HECS on the participation of disadvantaged groups in higher education.
The Council has concluded from the research that HECS [as it was in 1991], has little effect on the decision of the educationally disadvantaged groups identified in the research.

So in 1991, the research which NBEET had carried out, the work carried out by the Higher Education Council, indicated that HECS, as previously introduced by the former Labor government, had little effect on the decision of the educationally disadvantaged to participate in higher education. The educationally disadvantaged groups examined in the council's research included students from low socioeconomic backgrounds, rural students, students from non-English speaking backgrounds indigenous students and single parents.

It is interesting to compare the advice provided in March 1992 to the 12th and most recent such report from the Higher Education Council, which looked at outcomes for 1996 and 1997. The report lists the coalition's major cuts and changes to higher education, which were announced in 1996. It states:
Clearly, issues such as these are beyond the scope of this report on 1997 activity, but will be covered in future years.
This is the advice that was provided in 1996. Let me repeat that:
Clearly, issues such as these—
that is, the cuts that this government made in funding for universities and the increases in HECS—
are beyond the scope of this report on 1997 activity, but will be covered in future years.

If this bill is passed, these issues will not be examined—an outcome for which the coalition may well have cause to be grateful, because the information we have to date about the impact of increased HECS charges and a radically reduced repayment threshold is that these changes have significantly impacted on participation in higher education. Australia-wide, applications for enrolment have fallen by 3.3 per cent in 1997, and a further 2.7 per cent in 1998. This year, they have recovered slightly but are still 4.8 per cent below the level of 1996. And that is overall, with no information about specific groups such as those included in the Higher Education Council's surveys.

So it is no wonder that the Howard government wants to kill off the Higher Education Council before it has a chance to deliver the bad news: the information that we need to know how much damage has been done by this government's cuts in funding to higher education, by this government's increases in the charges for university students, by this government's decision to lower the repayment thresholds for people who build up a HECS debt. That is why this government wants to stop the Higher Education Council delivering any bad news in the form of detailed information about the extent of the damage done to access and equity in higher education in Australia.

The council's commissioned report, The effects of the introduction of fee-paying postgraduate courses on access for designated groups, published in 1997, concluded that fees do have a deterrent effect on postgraduate enrolment by some equity groups, pushing them towards HECS based enrolment. Under the Labor government, fee paying postgraduate places were balanced by broad availability of HECS places as well. This has changed completely under the coalition, with a fall of around 40 per cent in Commonwealth funded postgraduate course-work places, as a direct result of the coalition's $840 million cuts to university operating grants.

The 1997 Higher Education Council report also raised the issue of cuts to university operating grants, noting that, to the extent that universities have fewer resources, they have less capacity to undertake measures to improve equity and access. Since that report, universities have felt the impact of the major funding cuts announced by the Howard government in 1996.

Late last year, the Higher Education Council finalised a further report on postgraduate access in the new environment of vastly expanded fee paying. For some reason, that report has not even been published. It has, in fact, disappeared without trace—further evidence, if any were needed, that this government is determined to shut itself off from information about the impact of its short-sighted, damaging policies and to deny the community the benefit of independent evidence of the damage this government has done in higher education. More broadly, this is a government that is totally closed to new ideas. We now have a federal minister for education whose contribution to policy development has been zero, whose efforts have been concentrated on implementing a narrow ideological agenda, but who is unwilling to visit a university campus, and who steadfastly avoids contact with education interest groups and spokespeople who might challenge his views or provide a different perspective.

Unfortunately, the most recent budget—despite being labelled an education budget by the Prime Minister—was yet another lost opportunity and another demonstration of the government's failure to comprehend the fundamental importance of education and training. The government's so-called education budget concentrates additional school funding disproportionately in the non-government school sector—talking about need while ignoring the clear needs of government schools—and yet it makes yet another attack on higher education, axing the Merit Based Equity Scholarships Scheme and cutting $16 million from the Innovation Program. For TAFE there is nothing.

So in a budget that the Prime Minister claimed would be an education budget we have the abolition of the Merit Based Equity Scholarships Scheme, we have the latest cut in the operating grants for universities and we have no resumption of growth for TAFE. We have a government that does not provide a significant increase for funding for public schools while providing a substantial increase in federal funding for non-government schools. My real worry is that the Prime Minister might actually think an education budget is when you give a massive increase in funding to non-government schools—an increase which is 21 times, on average, that given to students at government schools. How can government members sit back knowing that, for every extra dollar that went to students, teachers and staff at government schools, $21 went to students in non-government schools? Labor make it clear that we support extra funding going to needy private schools; we support extra funding going to improve the quality of education in non-government schools. But we have to balance that by providing not only significant increases in funding for private schools but also significant increases in funding for public schools.

talk.start.para: —We did.
—The member interjects and claims that there was an increase.
—It will increase with the GST.

—The member interjects and claims that a GST will deliver a significant increase in funding to public schools. I simply suggest to the honourable member that he talk to the teachers and to the staff at schools in government schools in his own electorate to know that the GST is not going to be the answer to schools' difficulties in funding. In many cases, the GST will create an enormous additional administrative burden on schools right round Australia, be they public or private. It is the honourable member who will have to answer to the parents of children at his own local schools—government and private—who will be hit by the lost income that gets spent on implementing the GST in schools in his own electorate. So my real concern is that this Prime Minister might actually think that an education budget is a budget that continues cuts in federal funding for universities across the country, that fails to deliver any growth funding for TAFE, that abolishes the Merit Based Equity Scholarships Scheme for disadvantaged young kids, that does not provide the balance in extra funding for government schools and non-government schools.

speech.para: So these decisions prove the government has greater need than ever before of advice from a body like NBEET, because improving children's opportunities at some schools while reducing access to vocational and higher education reflects a blinkered, distorted view of educational experience. Lifelong learning and a properly educated and skilled population begin with quality schooling, followed by access to well-resourced post-compulsory education and training institutions.

A sensible government understands the interaction between the sectors and the need for articulated pathways. Through this bill, the Howard government has shown us that not only does it not understand the concept of linkages but also that it does not want to understand, it does not want to listen, it does not want to know. As far as NBEET is concerned, the damage is done. The corporate knowledge has been largely scattered; the personnel have dispersed; and the board exists practically only in name.

Soon after the coalition came to office, the predecessor of the present Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs wrote an extremely ungracious letter to the Chairman of NBEET, setting out arrangements for the winding up of the board. That letter failed to acknowledge that NBEET had achieved anything. We believe this government has a record of seeking to silence independent organisations that disagree with government policy. I have to say that this government will be the worse for the loss of that independent advice. Therefore, I move the following second reading amendment:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1) is of the opinion that education and training are of fundamental importance to Australia's social and economic well-being;
(2) notes that many of the emerging issues in employment, education and training are cross-sectoral in nature;
(3) expresses great concern that the body charged with providing independent, cross-sectoral advice to government on these significant issues has been dismantled by the Government;

(4) calls on the Government to establish immediately an independent review of the impact of its changes to the Higher Education Contribution Scheme, one of the roles previously undertaken by the Higher Education Council; and
(5) notes the commitment of the Australian Labor Party, when returned to government, to re-establish a structure to provide independent, cross-sectoral advice on education and training".

talk.start.para: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

—I rise to speak in support of the original Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1999 , not the amendment moved by the member for Dobell. The bill seeks to do a number of things. As the member for Dobell correctly pointed out, it seeks to abolish the National Board of Employment, Education and Training and its subsidiary councils—these being the Australian Language and Literacy Council, the Employment and Skills Council, the Schools Council and the Higher Education Council. In 1987, under the chairmanship of Charles Holton, a task force report delivered to the then Minister for Employment, Education and Training, John Dawkins, recommended that there be a rationalisation of advisory structures in the employment portfolio. It has nothing to do with not understanding or not wanting to understand higher education or anything of the sort, as we have just heard.

speech.para: One consequence of the establishment of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training was a loss of what were seen to be the positive attributes of the Schools Commission and the Tertiary Education Commission, from whose abolition it emerged. Firstly, their membership was largely representative of the sectors with which they dealt. Secondly, they were responsible for program administration and, consequently, had larger staffs and a greater capacity to set their own research and reporting agendas. Thirdly, the statutory conditions under which they operated had given them greater scope for independent action.

Governments of the day—and at the time, federally, that was a Labor government—and ministers in particular sought advice which bore some relation to budgetary strategy, as any responsible government would. The new advisory arrangements were established by the Employment, Education and Training Act 1988. The critical features of the act were: firstly, a national board to report directly to the minister on all related employment, education and training issues, taking into account any written directions or guidelines from the minister on the government's broad social, economic and budgetary policies; secondly, four advisory councils would report to the board; thirdly, the new board would have no responsibility for program delivery, which would be left entirely to the department; and, fourthly, community based membership of the board and councils.

The Employment, Education and Training Amendment Act 1995 added the Australian Language and Literacy Council to the National Board of Employment, Education and Training structure—and the council had been operating as a committee of the board for several years. That is where all this was at at the time of the change of government in 1996. The government's 1996 higher education policy indicated an intention, as was always intended, to wind up the National Board of Employment, Education and Training—a measure which I would suggest was coveted by the previous government—whilst maintaining the Higher Education Council as an independent body reporting directly to the minister.

In June 1996, several months after the change of government, the Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1996 was introduced to implement the election policy but it was not passed. Nonetheless, the board and the three councils wound up in response to a request from the then minister. The Higher Education Council and the Australian Research Council have continued to operate, with the board's activities being confined specifically to those councils.

The Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1999 abolishes not only the National Board of Employment, Education and Training but also the Australian Language and Literacy Council, the Employment and Skills Council, the Schools Council and the Higher Education Council. The Australian Research Council will continue and will report directly to the minister. In the light of the recent release of the green paper, that is something that I suggest to the House is highly desirable. Its membership will continue unchanged. Whilst the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee recommended that the ARC provide broad policy advice to the minister through the Higher Education Council, it nonetheless recommended that the ARC report directly to the minister on the distribution of grant funding and policies relating to its programs.

The opposition, through the member for Dobell, has made a number of points, most if not all of which need some refutation. There is no reason whatsoever on a scholarly basis to believe that the abolition of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training will reduce consultation in any way and it will certainly not reduce independent advice. What it will do is close desks in bureaucracy, possibly to open a few more in the classroom.

From what the member for Dobell has said, the opposition also has some interest in how the government will consult with other interest groups. The National Board of Employment, Education and Training, as I said, was established by the previous government, of which the member for Dobell was, I understand, a proud member. Times and funding mechanisms have changed and so too must the consultative mechanisms. The board and councils have already wound up, as I pointed out to the House, with the exception of the Australian Research Council. If expert advice is required in this area, as in so many areas of government policy direction, expert task forces can be established on an ad hoc basis. For example, we can rely upon the advice of the Business/Higher Education Round Table. I would not dare criticise its composition or its work.

I am sure that the member for Dobell would not criticise the advice that the National Council of Independent Schools Associations would give to government—or that of the Primary English Teachers Association, the National Catholic Education Commission, the Australian Primary School Principals Association or the Australian Secondary School Principals Association. Are these not all sources of wise and well-informed advice to government?

We also have the centres for higher education research and development in Australia. The Australian National Training Authority also plays a pivotal role in, amongst other things, distributing vocational education and training funding to the states and institutions. The Australian Council for Education Research also does that. These and so many other organisations are, to some extent, funded by governments in one form or another and they provide a consistent and reliable source of advice without needing to maintain the National Board for Employment, Education and Training.

A number of existing representative bodies, some of which I have listed, also advise the government on issues that were once covered by the National Board of Employment, Education and Training and the four councils being abolished. Bureaucracy is very important and advice to governments of a high quality is particularly important. We need always to be asking ourselves whether maintaining any kind of board, statutory authority or, indeed, part or all of a government department actually serves the interests of not only the sector but, most importantly, the beneficiaries of it who fund it through their taxes and who ultimately should benefit from it.

Finally, the ARC will not only report directly to the minister but it will promote informed public debate on research in Australia. As the green paper on higher education research and research training actually sets out, it envisages quite a significant role in policy directions for the ARC—for which it has my full support.

Turning to some of the other points that were made by the member for Dobell, Labor, when it was in office, at times promoted higher education as the one and only definition of excellence in education. I felt that, for almost a decade, many young people were of the view that, if they did not achieve a university education and a degree, they were in some way of less value to their families and society and that, even if they came out of university with two degrees, they were in some way inadequately trained. Seventy per cent of Australia's secondary students who did not go on to university could at times be forgiven for feeling that there was less of a place for them in Australian society.

The comments that the member for Dobell made about HECs and about how changes to HECs have discriminated against the interests of those seeking higher education fly in the face of reality. The reality is that, when the government changed in March 1996, only 15 per cent of students in higher education institutions in this country came from the bottom 25 per cent of income earning households. By contrast, 30 per cent came from the top 25 per cent of income earning households—with an average income then of $84,000 a year. Whatever one's definition of social justice is, I would not consider that to be my definition of it. In other words, whatever the previous government was doing to try to deliver equitable social outcomes, it was not succeeding. In other words, the taxes of blue-collar workers throughout the country were being used to fund the education principally of people who come, in many instances, from electorates like the one I am privileged to represent.

In some cases, if not many, teaching and learning in formal education took place outside the context of real life situations, activities and problems. It is essential in my view that both higher education and in particular vocational education and training take place in the context of their application. The pathways from school to university under the previous government for vocational education and training were frequently disjointed. The Dusseldorf Foundation, for example, in March last year when it published its report, Australia's youth—reality and risk, pointed out a few facts which might provide some discomfort to the Labor members of the House. It said:
We need to move from youth management to youth development.

It identified marginalised young people as being the unemployed, those who are not in the labour force or not studying and those who are in precarious part-time employment. It identified the need in particular to address the problems of early school leavers. It also argued for an increased emphasis on schools to industry programs, as a consequence of which we now have the Jobs Pathway Program, which is a schools-industry partnership program, and schools, in many instances, acting as brokers. For example, $12 million was made available to them for the Jobs Pathway Program.

The Dusseldorf Foundation identified that, in 1999, this year, 15 per cent—or 187,000—15- to 19-year-olds were neither in part-time work nor in education. Of these, 70 per cent had not completed year 12. For every young person looking for work, at least one was locked into marginal activities fairly consistently for up to three years. By age 19 there had been no higher education or vocational education and training undertaken by those who had been unemployed for, in many cases, at least one-third of the time since leaving school. The report went on to say:
The key indicators for young people in leaving work during the 1990s either show no improvement or deterioration.

In fact, the key indicators for young people in learning and work during the early to mid-1990s show either no improvement or, as I say, deterioration. Youth unemployment in 1996 was no lower in real terms than it was at the beginning of the decade. Year 10 retention rates had fallen below 1990 levels. Year 11 was below the 1991 level and year 12 had fallen to the 1991 level. Those not completing year 12 were identified as being more likely to enter part-time work unlinked to study than year 12 leavers. That essentially is the picture with which the Howard government was presented in March 1996.

One of the assertions made by the member for Dobell is that enrolments in higher education are declining. Since the introduction of HECs by the Labor government in 1988, the number of enrolments in higher education in Australia has almost doubled. If there has been any slowing in the rate of application for higher education positions in Australia, it owes more to the substantially increased funding made available for new apprentice ships and traineeships under this government and to programs which enable people to undertake vocational education and training as distinct from pursuing higher education and a degree. As I said earlier, young people were studying for degrees when, in their hearts, they were uncertain about whether they would have a job when they were finished and whether the degree was relevant to their personal interests.

Some of the other points need to be refuted. Firstly, in this budget this year—1999-2000—the government is committing over $11 billion per annum over the forward estimates for education and training. The budget saw an increased funding of $870 million for education over the next four years. This budget of over $11 billion includes approximately $5 billion for schooling, $4.2 billion for universities and $1.6 billion for vocational education and training at TAFE and through private providers. This year, direct Commonwealth funding to government schools has increased by 6.8 per cent or $115 million over the previous year.

The point that is lost in the debate, if you can describe it as debate, between the opposition and the Howard government on funding for public schools is that they are called state schools traditionally because they are funded by state governments. The Commonwealth government is not the primary funder of public schools; it is state governments. From memory, I think only 12 per cent of state school funding actually comes from the Commonwealth, but that proportion that is provided by the Commonwealth increased this year by 6.8 per cent. The government has also undertaken reforms to raise literacy and numeracy standards in the early years of school, extending it to secondary level with additional funding of $130 million over the next four years for early and middle years. Therein lies another point that ought to be made. I see that a recent survey found that those who purport to represent the interests of parents in state schools, or public schools, are actually out of step with the people they purport to represent, that over half of the parents surveyed actually disagreed with the policies being espoused by those representing P&F representative organisations.

Australia's students and teachers are going to benefit from $77 million in the quality teacher program over three years to update teacher skills. And so on it goes. In terms of universities, there is another $93.3 million increase over the previous forward estimates, bringing funding to a total of $288 million over three years, and strategic partnerships with industry research and training grants will be allocated another almost $60 million funding to forge stronger links between industry and universities, bringing it to $162 million over three years.

One of the other points that I think ought to be made which is perhaps more of a philosophical nature is that in undertaking these reforms, in abolishing the National Board of Employment, Education and Training and undertaking the other reforms which are included in this bill, we need to reflect upon what is actually the purpose of education. One of the debates that we have not really had is whether education increasingly should be seen to take on a purely utilitarian view or whether on the other hand education should be about learning for life, about education itself. One of the concerns I have is that, increasingly, young people are pursuing training as distinct from education. I say that as a person who was trained as distinct from educated. One of the most compelling speeches that I have read on this was given, not surprisingly perhaps, by Professor David Penington to the Melbourne Winter Conversazione for 1995. I will just quote a couple of things from that address. He said:

The rapid changes that are occurring in the world of work mean that vocational education must increasingly be accompanied by general education. Otherwise, graduates will be trained in skills which will fast disappear and they will be left with little capacity for adaptation and change.
He went on to say:

Control of education to an undue degree by central government in terms of detailed prescriptions of a uniform kind, whether these be national curriculum frameworks or uniform indicators of performance for all institutions of higher education, carries profound dangers. Unless the diversity of human potential is recognised and adequately catered for, not only will individual young people be the losers but the future development of society itself will also suffer.

It is time for countries such as our own to rethink their approaches to education in order to achieve what he described as the proud Confucian tradition of Asian nations in respect for teachers and for education. If we do not, he warned, we could be left far behind. I speak strongly in support of this bill. It is a move in the right direction. It reduces complexity of administration and increases consultation.

talk.start.para: —In talking this afternoon to the Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1999 , it is my view that the bill is about accountability, independent advice and a judgment made on the importance of public debate. I say that because of the close link between those who do poorly in education, those who do poorly in the labour market and the one in nine Australians who live in poverty. These very facts make it clear that governments do not have all the solutions. This is precisely why they need independent advice.

speech.para: It is for that reason that the shadow minister for education, the member for Dobell, moved a second reading amendment this afternoon. It raises some fundamental issues. I specifically refer, firstly, to acknowledgment by this side of the House that in our opinion education and training are of fundamental importance to Australia's social and economic wellbeing. That is why we have a view, as we move forward to a new century, that the debate ought to be about Australia being a knowledge based society, one that fundamentally acknowledges and supports and invests in our future as a leading nation which regards education and training as being of paramount importance. We then go on to make this important commitment—if anything a reaffirmation of what the Australian Labor Party committed itself to in the lead-up to the last election. This commitment is set out in point (5) of the second reading amendment moved by the shadow minister. It states that when returned to government we will re-establish a structure to provide independent cross-sectoral advice on education and training.

It is for that very reason that today I want to discuss the sort of work that some of these groups have undertaken in the past and why it is so important for the Australian community that there ought to be a source of independent advice on such a fundamental issue as education and training. I want to also suggest that the government may have a particular interest in doing these organisations over. When you look across the range of portfolios that exist under the current government, you see this is not the only source of independent advice that previously existed that the government has gone out of its way to undermine, to white-ant and to remove. I believe politicians ought to acknowledge that they do not have all the solutions, that there is a case for independent advice, and that, if anything, the best policy actually comes from debate and a willingness by independent public servants and a network of organisations that offer that independent advice to actually challenge you on the policy front. That is what I believe the organisations that are being abolished by this bill actually sought to do in days gone by.

Mr Deputy Speaker, as you, I and the Australian community know, Australia's No. 1 economic and social problem is unemployment. That is intimately linked to the debate this afternoon. The budget and the $20 million squandered on buying the GST make it clear that it is not the government's priority, but that does not change the reality. The fact is that unemployment is the biggest economic and social problem we face and, despite what the Treasurer and the Prime Minister would have had us believe in question time today, we have not made enough progress. Yes, unemployment today stands at 7.2 per cent, but the Prime Minister failed to mention to the House today that, since the current government was elected in March 1996, the participation rate in Australia has actually fallen by almost one per cent. That has been a major factor in reducing the unemployment rate in Australia.

The Prime Minister also failed to acknowledge, when he talked about the strength of the Australian economy today, that he in actual fact inherited a very strong economy. I read with interest a speech by the Prime Minister at a function in Newcastle, just a couple of Fridays ago, about some very famous Newcastle identities, one of whom was a fellow by the name of Maurie Rudd, a leading trade union official in Newcastle and a major representative of iron workers involved in the steel industry and related industries. On reading that speech, I found an acknowledgment by the Prime Minister that 18 months ago he was not sure or confident that the Australian economy would weather the Asian storm but that he was pleased that we had weathered the Asian storm.

The reason we have weathered the Asian storm, despite some mismanagement by this government and the fact that it slashed and burned in its first couple of budgets and made it far more difficult for us to perform, is that this government actually did inherit a very strong economy. The fundamental changes were made in the 13 years prior to 1996. The major changes that went to make a modern-looking economy, which included significant investment in education and training, were what the Prime Minister inherited.

For that very reason, when we talk about the issue of unemployment, we should also face up to the facts. Yes, we have 7.2 per cent unemployment at the moment and, yes, the participation rate has actually fallen by almost one per cent since March 1996, but more importantly—and this is of fundamental importance—on the basis of the economy that the Prime Minister inherited we should be talking about an unemployment rate of five per cent or a little bit more at this time.

It is interesting to acknowledge that was not only the view of this side of the House after the 1996 election but also the independent view of the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs which at that time—despite an endeavour by the minister to suggest that five per cent could not be achieved—acknowledged very publicly that we were on target to achieve an unemployment rate of five per cent. So when we talk about the issue of education and training it is important that we associate with it the question of how we perform as a nation, whether or not the economy is functioning well and whether or not we are actually making enough progress on the employment front.

To us on this side of the House, that is important when we are talking about these issues, because we believe that the issue of education and training or lack thereof is the single biggest cause of poverty and material hardship. But, even more than this, it is important because it can give to or deny people, our fellow citizens, a crucial means of self-worth and personal dignity. That is what one's fundamental achievement on the education and training front is about, because one's achievement on that front also determines to a large extent one's opportunity in life. It determines the nature of the job that one might be able to achieve and also one's capacity, in a rapidly changing economy, to maintain a reasonable level of employability.

That is what the new debate is about. It is not about the sense of security that previously existed in many jobs because of the nature of employment that existed in a range of different industries in days gone by. The new debate is about knowledge. It is about investment in education and training, which is fundamentally linked to one's employability over one's working life. That is why, in this context, we must always be willing to ensure that we are challenged by independent advice—from organisations such as those that will be abolished by this bill—to make sure that we get it right on the education and training front. We must do that so we get it right when it comes to ensuring that we do our best to ensure that throughout people's working lives they have a capacity to maintain decent employment opportunities because we have invested in a fundamental way in their employability.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you—and especially those on the other side of the House—might wonder why we so significantly relate this issue to the question of unemployment. The unemployment problem is not a simple one. It goes to a number of issues. One of the most consistent relationships that you will find over time is that between educational outcomes and the chances of unemployment. The Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business has said that he is not interested in new and creative solutions to unemployment. I am pleased to say that the Labor Party is, always has been and always will be interested in creative solutions to reduce unemployment in Australia.

That is why we want a debate about ideas. We do not want, as the Minister for Employment Services would have it, name calling and pointing the finger at the unemployed and those in depressed suburbs or regions who actually find it very difficult to get a job at this point in time. It should be a debate about ideas, not about name calling and pointing the figure. That is why, when we listen to what the community has to say, we understand that the analysis, the questions and the debate come before the answers. That is where some of the research by NBEET and the Schools Council in particular fits in. Their work, I believe, is an important part of the broader literature on the link between educational and labour market disadvantage. That is what it is about when you talk about employability. That is what it is about when you talk about someone's self-worth and someone's capacity to get a decent life through a capacity to get a job. It is about overcoming educational and labour market disadvantage.

What this research shows is that those who struggle in the labour market are those who have struggled in the education system. And it even goes beyond this. We must ask why people struggle in education. Not surprisingly, one finds that outcomes in education are largely driven by individual environments. Parents, peers and other personal and social support networks all affect educational outcomes in a fundamental way. Ultimately, it is these educational outcomes that largely determine labour market prospects.

NBEET and the Schools Council have played their part in this debate. The Labor Party in government did not always like the advice of these organisations, but we were prepared to at least be challenged and to consider their independent advice. That is what the strength of government and leadership is about: acknowledging that you are open to debate and new ideas. It is therefore disillusioning that people charged with public responsibilities—as are this Prime Minister and minister for education—want to shy away from such a debate. Why is the government so scared of this debate? Why is it so keen to silence these organisations? Clearly, it is because the government does not think it needs independent advice. It thinks that a narrow ideology will deliver the real world explanations and solutions. Is it because these organisations are committed to decent principles of social justice, and the coalition has as much faith in the word `social' as it does in the words `union' and `collective'? Of course it is hard to believe in social justice if you think there is no such thing as society or a sense of community.

This Howard government wants to silence these organisations because when these organisations look at the facts and analyse the evidence they come to conclusions that shake the coalition government right to its philosophical roots. They spell it out: society is more than the sum of its individuals. The truth is that our environments matter; our educational opportunities matter; where we live matters; what types of jobs our parents have matter; and what industries exist in our regions or our suburbs matter. You need the facts and the independent advice to actually work out the solutions to overcome those barriers that are getting worse in the Australian community. The gap between those who have and those who do not have is actually widening because of the inability of this government to admit that there is a need for further action and for new solutions.

The fact that we depend on others and that others depend on us is more than the starting assumption needed for us to develop practical solutions. It is the very basis of a just society. What the government must understand is that incorporating a social dimension makes the policy development task much more difficult, and it is easier to ignore it. To actually incorporate the social dimension is a challenge to those in government.

When experts analyse a problem and find that the explanations for poor educational and labour market outcomes are complex, you must begin to acknowledge that simple solutions are not enough. Broader acceptance of the fact that solutions to unemployment must take into account the influence of schools, families and communities—the support systems that surround us every day of our lives—would be a critical step forward in the government's approach. It is unfortunate that this government is not prepared to acknowledge the importance of support systems, for when narrow individualism is all you have you continue to tear at the nation's social fabric. This is evident to all but those who are not prepared to look.

The fact that today we have 680,000 people unemployed—and that is an understatement of the problem—suggests that governments have failed to appreciate this. That is why Labor is committed to a comprehensive approach to improving educational outcomes and reducing unemployment. Complex problems require solutions that are well thought out and subject to independent scrutiny. On this side of the House, we welcome that scrutiny. In developing solutions we must recognise the links between economic outcomes and the social context. We must recognise how the education system affects the labour market, and we must have the research that tells us what is going on, not just our own view but independent research at arms-length to government. We need research that is factually based and capable of challenging the government about new solutions. We must all recognise the vital role that education plays in shaping our individual and collective futures. Labor is clearly prepared to listen to independent advice on these issues; the coalition government is not.

As shadow minister for employment and training, I am interested in whatever the facts, analysis and independent advice throw up. Labor is interested in and committed to developing real and workable solutions. Compare that approach with the coalition's approach to this bill. The bill, in truth, puts the nail into the coffin of these institutions that were exceptionally important in providing independent advice to government. The truth is that the government buried them long ago by gutting them of resources. In a democratic society neither the facts nor different opinions, especially when they are informed opinions, are dangerous. We should cherish such an approach to government.

If we choose to, we can listen to each other, learn from each other and seek to understand each other. It is unfortunate when a government fundamentally misunderstands what education, knowledge and the pursuit of understanding can do for us. When governments discard independent advice they discard the accountability that is central to our political system. It is the sort of action that too often lets this government masquerade social injustice as mere misfortune. It is the sort of theme unfortunately pursued all too often by representatives of this government's front bench as they walk away from real debate and from an endeavour to engage the Australian community in a debate about finding real solutions.

I simply suggest in conclusion that Australia deserves better than this bill. Australia wants to and should be a knowledge based society—a society that is prepared to be challenged and a society that expects that in government we support independent advice and challenges to our ideas. This bill continues the government's process of ripping out any sense of independence of the Australian Public Service. The government is gutting it. They put political clowns in key positions as secretaries to departments and then dismiss them willy-nilly if they do not like their advice. When it comes to engaging others in the broader community—parents or unions or community organisations or representatives of educational institutions—the government says, `No, we are not interested in your advice; we know better. After all, we've got a minister for education, Dr Kemp, who can write a book.' He has written a book, but he is not prepared to think about independent advice and to be challenged.

I challenge the government to revisit today's bill—to reaffirm independence of government and the need for independent advice and analysis. The Labor Party again gives that commitment. On re-election, we will re-establish a structure to provide independent cross-sectoral advice on education and training. The Australian community deserves that.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1999 . I could not agree more with the shadow minister that education and training are very important. Unfortunately, though, Labor's results with regard to unemployment give a lie to this assertion. I simply cannot believe that the shadow minister opposite is criticising the 7.2 per cent level of unemployment that the coalition has been able to achieve. The Labor Party in government were responsible for the highest postwar level of unemployment of 11.2 per cent. The member for Batman said we should be looking at five per cent. Along with `the cheque is in the mail', another one of those great myths of the 20th century is, `The Labor Party was on target for its 14th year to achieve that.' Fortunately, the Australian people had a say in that and Labor are now enjoying the opposition benches.

speech.para: I will now speak about the bill specifically. In its 1996 policy statement on higher education, the coalition undertook to abolish the National Board of Employment, Education and Training and to establish independent councils to advise the government on higher education and research. This bill marks the beginning of that process. That policy entitled `Quality, Diversity and Choice' recognised that the existing administrative structure of advisory boards introduced by the Hawke Labor government in 1988 was cumbersome, unwieldy and not attuned to the policy directions of the coalition. Under the Labor Party structure, which this bill seeks to abolish and replace, the Australian Language and Literacy Council, the Australian Research Council, the Employment and Skills Council, the Higher Education Council and the Schools Council all reported to the minister via the national board.

While superficially this may have seemed a good idea inasmuch as it provided the minister with some sort of grandiose plan and big picture strategy, it was a recipe for dissension and pettiness, as the various interests and causes felt that their arguments, recommendations and perspectives were being filtered by the overarching national board. There was, as there is now, a feeling that the national board exercised too much power and influence in recommending preferred priorities to the minister and the government. As the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs made clear when introducing this bill, the coalition has a policy of ensuring that policy advice from all of the key areas flows directly to the minister. The need for a board which filters this advice is obviously redundant.

I believe that the education, training and research community will welcome this bill, as it allows them via the new structure to present their views directly to the minister and the government. This represents a very significant breakthrough in providing a higher and far more relevant standard of advice for the minister and the government. Thus this bill will abolish the national board, the Australian Language and Literacy Council, the Employment and Skills Council, the Schools Council and the Higher Education Council. The Australian Research Council will continue to be an independent council reporting directly to the minister. It is the government's intention to create more independent councils which will report directly to the minister, and this bill flags that future creation. The Australian Research Council will continue with its membership unchanged and will report annually to the minister on its operations. That report will be tabled.

The minister and the government are to be congratulated for this move, which not only introduces a new level of accountability and transparency but cuts the stifling and divisive red-tape procedures of the national board established by Labor. Members of the new councils will be able to more clearly focus on their relevant responsibilities and not be distracted by unwanted intrusions, censorship and potential direct meddling by the national board.

While the coalition's policy document was entitled `Quality, Diversity and Choice', it also included the notion of flexibility in obtaining that advice. We can only wonder why Labor did not want specialist advisory bodies to report directly to the minister when a critical aspect of formulating policy is an uncensored and vigorous public debate.

Under the coalition's policy, to encourage this healthy open philosophy there will be the flexibility to establish expert ad hoc task forces to advise on specific issues as they arise, and of course there are the many existing representative bodies which can and will give the government advice on issues previously covered by the national board and the four councils which are to be abolished.

It is appropriate, within the general policy context that this bill partially addresses, to consider the greater matter of diversity and choice in education. Australian parents are increasingly adopting a marketplace ideology and are shopping around before choosing their children's schools. They are making decisions about choice not only between school sectors—government or non-government—but also within sectors as states abandon government school zoning.

Of non-government schools, religious affiliation is most often the overriding consideration for school choice. Other considerations are whether the school is co-educational or single sex and the travelling distance from the family home. Smaller school sizes are also an attraction, with growing evidence that many problems of students in schools are less acute in smaller schools. Other criteria include a school's academic performance and discipline policy.

The coalition government has been a staunch supporter of the right of Australian parents to choose the most appropriate schooling for their child. Educational choice is seen by the government as the capacity of parents to choose between schools in the government sector or to select and/or establish a non-government school. The government's abolition of the new schools policy—or, as it is more commonly known, the no schools policy—which placed restrictions on the establishment of new non-government schools, was the first demonstration of the coalition government's commitment to supporting freedom of educational choice. The new model of funding non-government schools is another step, with one of its stated goals to give low income families greater access to the school of their choice.
In the ministerial statement launching the new funding model for non-government schools, Dr Kemp stated:

Parental choice has prompted quality in schooling, and ensures that Australian children receive an education which reflects the values of their community. Non-government schools are a living reflection of the breadth of our community.

As early as 1973, the Interim Committee for the Australian Schools Commission, in its landmark report, Schools in Australia —known as the Karmel Report—acknowledged the value of diversity and high standards that it saw present in non-government schools. It also supported the right of parents to educate their children outside the government school sector. Since the publication of this report, research and official government statistics have continually reinforced the perception that students from non-government schools have better educational outcomes than students from government schools. According to a report released in March this year in the Australian School Monitor , non-Catholic private schools increase a student's chance of graduating from secondary school by 21 per cent and from university by seven per cent. The raw data from that study shows that 36 per cent of government school students graduate from year 12 compared with 68 per cent of non-Catholic private school students, and 31 per cent of the latter complete university compared with 12 per cent of government school students. Results from the 1996 National Schools English Literacy Survey, reported by the Sydney Catholic Archdiocese, point to similar outcomes for primary school students, with Catholic school students performing above the national average.

It would be remiss of me not to say at this opportune time that the Catholic Education Office in Rockhampton, which also services my area of Mackay, have asked me to pass on their heartfelt thanks for the support the federal government has given to their schools. They wanted me to personally thank the Prime Minister for the outstanding support that the coalition has given to Catholic schools in my area. Many of those Catholic schools are in needy areas and parents are not able to give the support that parents in other areas are able to give. The increased federal funding has been of significant assistance to those schools.

Some argue that the new diversity in educational choice, with 146 new non-government schools approved for Commonwealth funding in 1997 and 1998, is a threat to Australia's social cohesion and egalitarian tradition. Counters to these concerns include the acceptance and consideration of the multicultural composition of Australian society and a reflection of a system responsive to the concerns and demands of parents.

It certainly seems that outcomes achieved by state schools across Australia are behind those achieved by the private and Catholic school sectors. Nobody is suggesting that this is because the brightest and best students have abandoned the state school system; nor, as I have said, is it a matter of socioeconomic disadvantage, since many of the Catholic Church schools choose the most needy areas in which to set up their schools.

Retention rates for students in the non-state sector are consistently higher. In 1998, across the nation government schools achieved a 65.7 per cent retention rate to year 12 while the non-state sector had a rate of 84.8 per cent. The fall-off in retention rates occurs in years 11 and 12, the two critical years that really determine a student's career path and direction if higher education is to be an option. At the end of year 10 the retention rates for both systems were above 95 per cent, but the slump in the rates for the state system after that grade was appalling.

On the general subject of retention rates, there has been a steady decline since 1992 when an impressive 77.1 per cent of all students stayed to year 12. In the three following years—1993, 1994 and 1995—there was a very worrying fall to 72.2 per cent. This decline happened at a time when the percentage of school-age children at government schools declined.

Clearly, parents are opting for the non-government sector if and when they can afford it. It is no secret that Labor Party members, who champion the cause of the state system both in and out of parliament, do not wait a second to enrol their children in non-government schools when their income permits it. I recall that recently the Premier of Queensland, the Hon. Peter Beattie, was asked where his children attended school. Significantly, he declined to answer the question. However, I am charitable and see this as a manifestation of a strongly emerging trend by parents across the spectrum to send their children to schools that provide the best opportunities. I would like to say at this juncture, in defence of state schools, that they take all comers. Every student is accepted and that needs to be taken into account when looking at the results and outcomes they achieve. This does not mean that there are not state schools and teachers who work with professionalism and enthusiasm to equip their students for life. There are certainly many outstanding examples of this, but nationally the results are disappointing.

In 1996, there were 9,630 geographically isolated schools in Australia, both primary and secondary, which were eligible for funding under the Commonwealth's Country Areas Program, known as CAP. States face greater difficulties in staffing isolated schools than in staffing schools in capital cities or other urban areas. Student participation in education in isolated areas often requires additional time, effort and commitment on the part of students and their families than would generally be the case in an urban community.

Generally across Australia, secondary school completion rates have been lower in rural areas than in metropolitan areas. In the 1980s there was roughly a 10 per cent difference in year 12 completion rates between urban and rural students. By 1994 the difference in completion rates between urban and rural female students remained the same, but the recent national decline in school completion rates has been far greater for boys in rural areas than for those living in the city.

Rural students are also underrepresented in higher education. In 1996, their share of student enrolments was around 18 per cent. Rural students' share of commencing enrolments has declined steadily since 1991 when it was 19.6 per cent. Students from isolated areas comprised only 2.1 per cent of com mencing students in 1996. The limitations of post-school options for geographically isolated students has been reported by a number of states, with decreasing local options for employment and limited options for post-secondary education without moving to a capital city or other large urban centre being the major concerns. The lack of post-school options is also seen as contributing to the decreasing number of senior secondary students.

These concerns were reinforced by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report, Bush Talks, released earlier this year.
