It reported that rural drop-out rates were double those in the city and that the percentage of rural young people taking up tertiary studies was continuing to decline. For those of us who believe in rural and regional Australia, this is very disappointing news, as is the lack of opportunities for young people in areas outside the metropolitan cities. Government needs to address this most serious matter and ensure that students from rural areas are given every possible encouragement to continue their education. As our minister, though, has started, I have no doubt that he will finish. The bill that is before the House is one that I commend and support.

talk.start.para: —As the recent budget made clear, this government's vision for education is limited to cutbacks and to punishment. A quick look at the last budget confirms that this is the case. Government school kids were punished and given a paltry $10 extra per year while their private school counterparts received $210 extra per year—$10 for 70 per cent of school kids and a favoured 30 per cent get $210. Universities received less for teaching, and the government's own university equity scholarships were scrapped. TAFE, the sector on which we fundamentally depend for the provision of lifelong learning opportunities, received no growth funding at all. The key to our future competitiveness—research and innovation—was dealt a blow, and its share of GDP will fall from 0.78 per cent in 1995-96 to 0.63 per cent in 1999-2000.

speech.para: But you do not have to actually take the word of the opposition—the word of our side of politics—to expose this government's and this minister's lack of vision on the question of education policy. Indeed, as referred to in question time today, one of his principal critics is the Liberal Minister for Education in Victoria, Mr Phil Gude, who has said about the performance of the federal Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, amongst other things:
Literacy is our highest priority and, despite Dr Kemp undermining the previous collaborative process, we are determined this important process goes ahead.
And:
He ought to do the right thing . . . own up to the fact that he's manipulated the figures in a most dishonest and disgraceful fashion.
He has also said:
It is a debate that has hit the public arena as a result of political grandstanding by Dr Kemp.

Education policy under this government is not about vision. But despite its lack of vision for education, this government does have an agenda for education: to give the minister an unfettered ability to punish and to blame anyone and everyone except himself and this government for the problems in the education system.

This minister knows that he does not have any answers, but he wants to make absolutely sure that he and he alone gets to pick the scapegoat for the problem. Today it might be the teachers unions, tomorrow it might be the student unions or, even more fashionably according to yesterday's newspapers, it might be the so-called poorly performing schools. The minister wants to be able to do that free of the scrutiny of independent and expert advisory bodies. He wants to be able to do that without being subject to criticism from those with the credentials to proffer intelligent and perceptive criticisms. When you do not have a vision for education, what you absolutely do not want is independent expert advisory bodies blowing the whistle on you and letting people know that you do not have that vision.

Indeed, at base, that is the purpose of the Employment Education and Training Amendment Bill 1999. This legislation is about ensuring that those bodies, which could expose by their advice and their reports the huge holes in this government's approach to education, do not exist anymore. Stripped to its essence, this legislation is about burying the able representative bodies this government has, in effect, already killed. This legislation is really about burying the corpses of those bodies which have already been killed by executive action—by stopping funds and appointments.

There is no other justification for this legislation. One can read the minister's second reading speech time and time again—it does not take very long to read; it is a nice short one—and not find any real justification for this legislation. That is because the justification that really underpins this legislation is something that he would not want to put on as public a record as Hansard. The real purpose of this legislation is to silence critics and to silence possible sources of alternate advice.

So how does the legislation go about that process? This bill abolishes the National Board of Employment, Education and Training—commonly known as NBEET—and its councils. It does maintain—and at least this is one point of merit in the bill—the Australian Research Council. But, in abolishing NBEET and its councils, this bill overturns a 40-year tradition of having in this country independent and authoritative bodies in the education area from which to draw advice; that is—if I might put it like this—a conservative tradition, one started off by a conservative government and which ranged over 40 years. This bill basically gets rid of 40 years of independent and authoritative advice.

What could be a justification for that? I guess a justification for that could be that the government had looked at NBEET and its councils and said to itself, `They're not doing their job.' That could be a justification for this legislation. But when you turn to the facts and actually look at them, does that justification ring true? Does it hold up? I do not think so. I do not think the facts support any claim that NBEET or its councils were not doing their job. In dealing with this point, I turn to the 1994 Wiltshire review of NBEET which found:
The actual record of NBEET, in terms of measurable output, has been impressive by any yardstick.
The review goes on to state:
There would be few comparable research organisations in the country which could match the NBEET productivity/equality record.

The Wiltshire review also provided us with numerous examples of NBEET's work which has been recognised externally as having a significant impact on the education debate in this country and on education policy. I turn briefly to some of those quality publications and reports which have been generated by NBEET and its councils. From the Higher Education Council, which up until this bill reported annually on the impact of the higher education scheme, we had the document Achieving quality (in higher education). From the Schools Council, which was charged with the responsibility of advising on primary and secondary education, we had the document Australia's teachers—an agenda for the next decade. From the Employment and Skills Formation Council, which advises on matters relating to TAFE and employment, we had the document The Australian vocational certificate training system. From NBEET itself we had the document Fitting the need which highlighted the need to address the `big picture' resource issues across all education sectors.

So the government is completely unable to maintain the claim that NBEET's demise has anything to do with a failure on its part. On the contrary, the government is fully aware of this fact and has instead adopted a strategy of death by starvation and has simply refused to appoint new members to NBEET and its councils. What is almost wearying about this process is that we have been down this path before. The government tried to go down this path in 1996. It tried then to abolish NBEET and it presented a bill to this House in order to do so.

It should be noted that the bill we are dealing with today contains a worse proposition than the 1996 legislation. In the 1996 proposal the government was going to keep the Higher Education Council. That was used among the education constituency and community, which ought to include all of us, as a central selling point for the government's claim that accountability and independence would not be eroded. In the bill before us, the Higher Education Council, which was the primary source of advice under NBEET on general higher education issues, is also to be tossed aside. It is to be thrown on the scrap heap along with the other councils deemed to be no longer relevant to the government's agenda and from which the government does not want to see scrutiny, proposals and expert independent advice.

In 1996, the bill that was introduced in this House was the subject of a Senate inquiry. Specifically, the Senate Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee inquired into the Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1996 as it was then proposed. It is worthwhile recapping some of the principal findings of that Senate inquiry because the committee's very perceptive comments apply to the bill before the House today. The Senate committee found that the `overall thrust of the evidence received by the committee'—that is, the Senate committee—`argued for the importance of portfolio advisory mechanisms being independent and publicly accountable.' Further, the committee found that `the requirement for independence ensured that government departments and agencies did not monopolise the advice available to the minister.' That is, the minister would have the benefit, when making very important decisions, of very diverse advice from diverse communities; the minister would not be captive to the bureaucracy or to narrow sections of advisory structures. Instead, the minister would have available a full range of advice.

Indeed, taking that imperative to get the fullest and most comprehensive advice, the Senate committee recommended that the reports arising from whatever advisory structure eventuated be tabled in the parliament within 15 days of their receipt by the minister, so that advice could be available to parliament generally. So concerned was the Senate committee about the implications of the government agenda as it then was in 1996 that the committee went further and suggested that any future alternate advisory framework be expedited to fill the void left by the abolition of NBEET. It was basically saying, `If you are going to do away with this advisory structure, make sure that you put something else in its place as soon as possible. Don't leave yourself, as a minister, as a government, without the wider sources of advice, without independent sources of advice, without authoritative sources of advice.' In 1996, the government did not in any way outline what, if any, alternate structure was proposed had that bill gone through. In today's circumstances, where we are dealing with this bill as it is presented to this House, that same criticism remains as strong today as it was in 1996—and that is, what next, what else, where to from here, where are we going to go? All those questions remain unanswered.

The submissions before the Senate committee also focused on the important cross-sectoral role played by NBEET. Independent of government, independent of lobbyists, NBEET could consider the implication of advice to the minister across all sectors. It could synthesise and balance out competing claims from the various constituencies and sectors in education. As we are all aware, the education system in this country—dealing as it does with the education of our very youngest children right through to the adult education sector, our university sector and our drive to create lifelong learning opportunities—is such a complex sector, with its many parts, that it is obviously going to provide advice to a minister from its various bits. There needs to be a balancing out, an overall view. If you are going to get an authoritative view, you really need to be considering what each sector is saying, how the sectors relate to each other and what is best for the sector overall. That is, of course, a principal role that NBEET has played in advising government. Yet, despite the Senate committee's focus on that as an issue, the government has studiously ignored the impact of the single coordinated framework for advice on employment, education, training and research policies and programs.

The Senate inquiry also highlighted concerns over the shift to a greater reliance on departmental advice, not only because the department has a very specific role in terms of delivering government policy but also because it has difficulty—again, I quote the Senate committee—`gaining cooperation from the full range of agencies from which the department itself sought information in order to monitor implementation of policies and initiatives'. So there was an issue about gaining the best possible cooperation across the sector.

Examples of the need to keep yourself as close as possible to the sector and of the role that an advisory structure like NBEET and its councils can play—the role that is already lacking because, in effect, NBEET and its councils have been killed by slow starvation—have already been provided by Leigh Tobrett, the Director of the Office of Higher Education in the Queensland Department of Education. It concerns the issue of the government's approach to the overenrolment of universities last year.

The government—abstracted as it is from the day-to-day process of the higher education sector here in Canberra, not out there at a university actually dealing with the day-to-day process—claimed when the overenrolment issue came to light that `universities were poor at managing their enrolment processes, had strategically overenrolled to get their hands on the subsidy for overenrolment offered for the first time by the government, and that it was a sign that the sector was overfunded'. This is what we were told by someone who was on the ground or in better touch with the on-the-ground issues than this government:

A quick reality check with the sector would have developed another view on that issue, and save the Minister an irritated and hostile response from the sector which in the long run is bad for both parties. That over-enrolment was an outcome of a genuine concern about the punitive action if targets were not met, at a time when the impact of second semester enrolments was still being tested, and planned resource cuts of around 17 per cent loomed large on the horizon.

That is a small example—not an unimportant example—of the type of problem happening out there on the ground in the education sector—the distance between what is happening out there and what government can build. It is that kind of distance that NBEET and its councils—independent as they were, cross-sectoral as they were, expert as they were—helped to bridge. By starving NBEET and its councils to death, the government has put itself in the position—it certainly will be post the passage of this bill—where there is no effective structure to bridge that gap.

Anybody who looks at it closely would have to conclude that that is very bad public policy which is not going to drive our education sector forward in the way that we as a community would like to see it go forward, given how convinced I think Australians are of the fundamental and pivotal role played by education in our society and increasingly played as we work within a more globalised economic setting.

To summarise what is wrong with this bill and why it is bad public policy, let us again count through the points. It is bad public policy because, firstly, we need quality literature in the area of education and a source of that will be lost without NBEET and its councils. We need quality, authoritative reports. We will not have them. Secondly, we need independent bodies—independent of government and the bureaucracy—to be analysing the sector and providing advice upon it. Thirdly, we need cross-sectoral bodies, bodies that are across the complexity and breadth of the education sector, can look at all of its parts and also, very importantly, can look at the whole. Fourthly, we need expert bodies which are close to the ground, in touch with the education community, the education constituency, reporting on the problems, needs and issues as they see them day-to-day as they go about their work.

Each of those reasons, I would have thought, would have convinced a government that this bill represents flawed public policy. Unfortunately, we have not convinced the minister of that. As I said at the outset, I think that is because the minister is in the business of centralising to himself all power in relation to the education sector. I suspect the motive for doing that is that he does not want the actions of himself as minister and this government in the education sector to be subject to scrutiny, to balance, to independent oversight and to independent bodies having a look at what he is doing. He wants to be in the blame game. He wants to pick the victims. He wants to tell us what is going wrong and we know for sure that it is never going to be him; it is always going to be someone else. The day after the budget, in its editorial the Australian stated:
The poor provision for higher and further education in Tuesday's federal Budget laid bare an incomplete thought process.
We can only speculate how bare and incomplete a thought process we are now going to get, given the contents of this bill.

talk.start.para: —The Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1999 seeks to amend the Employment, Education and Training Act 1988, to abolish the National Board of Employment, Education and Training—NBEET—and its subsidiary councils: the Australian Language and Literacy Council, the Employment and Skills Council, the Schools Council and the Higher Education Council. All these councils and NBEET have had a long history of providing quality reports and quality scrutiny and advice to governments. This bill also seeks to amend the act to retain the Australian Research Council, which will report directly to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. At least we can be grateful for the fact that one of these councils is going to survive the minister's assault.

speech.para: This is the Howard government's second attempt to abolish NBEET. The 1996 legislation did not progress through the parliament. The difference between this and the 1996 legislation is that the Higher Education Council is also a casualty of the minister's knife, slicing into the councils that have operated independently in our country, looking at the education, training, skill and employment needs of Australians. We might ask why the minister has gone down the path of deciding to abolish the Higher Education Council when previously he had decided that maybe it did have a role to play and that he would leave it in place. I would like to argue that the reason he is abolishing that council is that he does not like what it is saying. It is the same old story: if you do not like the message, shoot the messenger.

The 1992 report looked at the impact of the government's HECS policies in 1991 and it showed that there was no impact on socially disadvantaged students. Unfortunately, the 1997 report was not quite as convincing in what it had to say. It indicated that government policies were impacting on socially disadvantaged students. There had been a drop in enrolments and, generally speaking, all the indicators that were in place showed that this government's policy was attacking those people who needed the most support to be able to attend university and gain an education, to be put on the same footing as other students who came from a more socially advantaged background. The 1998 report, which was looking at this issue in a little bit more depth, has been lost. Where it is no-one knows. Hopefully it will turn up, but I suspect it will not turn up whilst this government is in power.

The Howard government has really had a vendetta against universities and those students who are not socially advantaged. They have cut the operational grants to universities and they have reduced the HECS repayment threshold. Even the changes that they have made in the area of youth allowance have impacted on students attending university. I have a son and daughter who both go to university, and I have only to listen to them and their friends talking. They worry about the huge debt they are incurring. They know that the policies that this government has put in place are affecting their ability to obtain education. A number of their friends whose parents are unable to support them have had to leave university and get jobs. Some of them are able to attend on a part-time basis, but overall this government's policies are biting and affect the most disadvantaged students.

I think their policies are having the effect that the government want; they are making sure that it is only those people who have money, who are wealthy, the so-called elite—their friends—are the ones who can access university education. Even before the last election, when I was out doorknocking I came across a young woman who complained bitterly to me about the way she was having to pay back many thousands of dollars because of the changes this government had made to the HECS repayment threshold.

University education should be there for everyone. It should not be there only for the wealthy and the elite. It should be something that ordinary Australians and ordinary Australians students who attend public school can access. I really do not believe that is the case with this government. The Howard government's 1999 education budget directed dollars to students attending private schools. They received 21 times more money than public schools. This means that those private schools, particularly those elite private schools, are going to have greater resources. They are going to advantage those students attending those schools: they will have more computers; those students interested in sport will have greater access to elite sporting programs; and all the time the gap between those who are socially advantaged and those who are socially disadvantaged will get bigger and bigger.

This is this government's idea of cross-subsidisation: subsidise the wealthy private schools at the expense of the public schools. I have grown up with the concept that you help those people who need assistance, those in greatest need. But this government says, `If you have got money, if you are advantaged, we will give you a bit more.' Students who are attending public schools are disadvantaged by this government's policies. Then they are disadvantaged by the impact of this government's policies when they attend university. Once again, it is making education affordable and accessible only for the wealthy. Abolition of the merit based equity scholarships has been a further step down the path of supporting those who have at the expense of those who have not or those that are more socially disadvantaged.

The minister is closed to any new ideas or anything that is different from his own ideas. He has pushed through his ideas relating to student unions and pushed for voluntary student unionism. Even his programs that look at literacy and numeracy are about testing rather than about actually improving the literacy and numeracy skills of students. The minister and, I am afraid, the Prime Minister are both idealogues. They are trapped in the 1950s and they cannot get out. This government is an antieducation government, a government that supports only organisations, groups, boards or councils that support its points of view, its doctrines, its ideology.

That is why NBEET was doomed. NBEET was a body that offered independent advice and had independent, new ideas—something this government objects to. You must fit inside the box, you must be philosophically correct, you must lack innovation, you must be controllable. If you are not, you are out, you are cut, you are abolished—it is the end of you. And that is the problem with NBEET and its councils. The councils had community representatives. We all know what this government thinks about community representatives. Its attitude is: `We don't want the community to be involved. We don't want the community to have a say. We don't want any of those ideas to sneak into a report to the government.' Otherwise, it may actually have to look at them or consider them. It wants people it can control. Therefore, what do you do? You abolished the board and its councils.

NBEET has been effectively abolished for some time, because this government has failed to appoint new members to it, and it has been retained only in form and not as an operational body. Yesterday we had the republic debate, when once again the government showed that it would not accept the views of anyone that did not agree with it. The Prime Minister was hell-bent on making sure that he presents a question to the Australian people that is in line with his ideas and that provides him with the best opportunity to get the result he wants. He totally ignored the recommendation of a bipartisan committee. Today we have the government introducing legislation to abolish an independent board and independent councils. It is very much the way this government operates. You have to agree with it, you have to follow its ideology, or else you are out. So yesterday it was the report and the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on the Republic Referendum; today it is NBEET.

I support the amendment moved by the shadow minister, who is committed to a whole-of-life cross-sectional approach to education. He recognises the importance of a knowledge and skill based society. We must have a cross-sectional approach to education, training and employment. We live in a changing society where education, training, skills and employment needs are paramount. We are looking at very different types of issues in these areas from those we looked at in the past. We are looking at the need for accreditation, credit transfer and pathways. Even school education is very different from the way it used to be. You have students who are involved in vocational education where part of their schooling is done within the traditional classroom, another part of their education may be done at TAFE and another part of their education may be obtaining skills out in the work force.

Our education system, our approach to learning, training and developing skills must be able to encompass this. But I am afraid that this government does not feel that way. That is why it is abolishing the board. That is why it is going to abolish the councils—cost-effective bodies that provided advice to government on education and training for a number of years. The government does not want advice, because it is caught in its ideological warp. Australians are being disadvantaged and left behind because of this government's approach. Governments need independent bodies that can stand back, review policies and make recommendations for new policies and new initiatives. They need to get advice from bodies other than the departments, and they need to get ideas that go outside their own cabinet, their own party room, But this government refuses to do that. You need to look at what works and what does not work. You need to recommend new strategies to meet the needs of our high-tech society. If we do not do that, Australia is going to be left behind. And that is what this government is doing: putting Australia in a position where it will be left behind the rest of the world.

Unfortunately, this government is so tightly locked into its ideology and its 1950s view of Australia that it continues to attack those programs that do not match its philosophy. We have seen the Jobskills program go. We have seen changes to apprenticeships that are disadvantaging young Australians. The Jobtrain program, a skill based program that provided training to people in areas that were identified as areas of need, has gone. LEAP, a program that was designed to help young Australians get skills and formal qualifications while getting experience working on the job, has gone. What has it been replaced with? Work for the Dole. It is a narrow approach that is designed to say, `If you are getting any sort of assistance from the government, we want you to go out and work and pay for it.' It is not about getting skills, it is not about getting education and it is not about getting training.

This government stands condemned for its failure to deliver the programs that will meet the educational and training needs of Australians, a failure that is leading to a society where Australians lack the skills they need to find employment in a highly technical, knowledge based society. The amendment moved by the shadow minister would assist Australians to meet the challenge of the new millennium—something that John Howard's 1950s style government cannot do and something that attacks on independent bodies like NBEET and its councils will not achieve.

speech.para: It is well to remind ourselves that the Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1999, which is before us, abolishes the National Board of Employment, Education and Training—NBEET—and four of its five councils. The Australian Research Council will be retained and will report directly to the minister. The issue for us is what this means for education in Australia. The abolition points to a new method of advising the government. It is clear that the government's preoccupation with outcomes has led to the demise of a holistic approach to issues. The replacement is a fragmented model that denies the opportunity for various interests within a policy area to work together to develop a coordinated approach and to reach a consensus of opinion on policy issues.

I will refer specifically to the Schools Council. The purpose of the Schools Council was to provide advice and information as requested by the minister, by the national board or on its own initiative on primary and secondary education in Australia. The membership of the council was broadly based, with representation from the government and non-government school sectors, teaching unions, businesses, and community and parent organisations. Abolition of the Schools Council means that no mechanism is now in place to bring together representatives from all the key sectors and organisations with an interest in school education to formulate independent advice to the government reached through a consensus of opinion by all interests.

The advice mechanisms the government now has in place are therefore not holistic. They are one-dimensional, fragmented, ad hoc and formulated on an issue-by-issue basis without consideration for the totality of the school education environment. It is worth noting that, in its submission to this year's budget, the organisation so often maligned in this place by the minister—the Australian Education Union—called for the establishment of a schools advisory council as a principal forum to advise both the Commonwealth and state governments on national schooling policy.

The demise of the Australian Language and Literacy Council has had a similar impact in the area of advice to government on literacy. The role of the ALLC was to provide advice to the minister on priorities, strategies and targets for the development and implementation of the Australian language and literacy policy. Its membership included representatives from educational institutions, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations, linguists, educationalists and industry.

There is a certain irony, given this government's asserted focus on literacy matters across the spectrum, that it has no peak industry body to advise it in this area. As with the abolition of the Schools Council, there is no longer a body that can provide what I regard as a holistic approach to providing advice to government on literacy matters. The problems caused by this vacuum have been further exacerbated by the government's cut in core funding to Language Australia, which now has to rely on project funding for its survival. The purpose of Language Australia is to coordinate and undertake research, conduct professional development and produce and disseminate information about language, literacy and multicultural issues.

That is particularly relevant in the context of the Northern Territory. You would be aware, Mr Speaker, that the Northern Territory has a very diverse population, is multicultural and multilingual. More than half of the schools and a quarter of its students are located in remote areas and suffer severe disadvantages. School-age children comprise 25 per cent of the population. That is more than in any other state or territory. Indigenous students comprise 34 per cent of the total student population of 40,000.

Mr Speaker, you will recall that, during a previous session of this parliament late last year, I asked a question of the Prime Minister on bilingual education which he refused to answer. I took umbrage at his lack of response and I was quietly, although not without some verbal resistance, evicted from the chamber. I took no pride in that, Mr Speaker, but it was a sign of my frustration and a demonstration of the frustration that many of my constituents feel about the response of this government on issues to do with literacy and language and in particular on the issue of bilingual education.

That frustration is ongoing and we have not had an adequate response from this government on the issue of bilingual education. Indeed, it is still an issue which is causing a great deal of concern in many Aboriginal schools around the Northern Territory and within the Aboriginal community and education fraternity generally. You may be aware, Mr Speaker, that the Northern Territory government's unilateral decision to axe bilingual education for Aboriginal students was believed by many to be inexcusable and to not have a valid basis. It has caused enormous anxiety. I am paraphrasing there the words of Chris Sidoti, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commissioner. He was speaking after hearing submissions from the Yolngu people at the Yirrkala school near Nhulunbuy. Mr Sidoti had said there that there was concern about the loss of bilingual education programs and that it was swamping his national education inquiry. I want to quote what he had to say:
The message that we are getting loud and unequivocally from Aboriginal people is that they want their kids to be fluent and literate in English and in their own language.
This he told the Canberra Times on Friday, 14 May this year. He went on:

It is not a rejection of the importance of English. On the contrary, they are saying that they want English skills of a higher level than present because they see the English language as being the only passport into the world of most Australians.

I am acutely aware of this concern and of the frustration and hurt that is being felt not only by Aboriginal students but also by their parents and their communities at the failure of not only this government but also the Northern Territory government to respond to the legitimate requests to have this program reinstated. There is currently an inquiry under way in the Northern Territory being undertaken on behalf of the Northern Territory government by a former Senate colleague of ours, Bob Collins, who was, as you would be aware, Mr Speaker, a former minister in the Labor government.

It is very hard to describe, in a way which this parliament will understand, the enormous concern that Aboriginal Territorians have for this issue, but this concern is shared by those who are involved in providing education to them—not only in the government school system but also in the non-government school sector. It is worth pointing out that some of the loudest concerns have been expressed by the Catholic system. In the context of the government system, I visited communities such us Yuendumu and Willowra where people demanded the right to be able to give their views to the minister of the day in the Northern Territory and to have me express on their behalf their views to this parliament.

I was left in the position last year, Mr Speaker, where, when I asked a question of the Prime Minister, which was then deflected to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, not only was he unable to answer the question but his arrogant response left me with little option but to raise my concerns forcibly in this place. The sanctions which were applied were no doubt legitimate, but I make no apologies for raising that issue and I make no apologies for continuing to raise it. I say to the government and to the minister responsible for education that, when he is blithely talking about his achievements and what his government's policies are, he ought to pay some credence to what the communities around Australia, and particularly in the Northern Territory, are demanding of him and his government as well as the government of the Northern Territory. They ought to be aware that this issue of bilingual education is regarded by Aboriginal communities right throughout the Territory as non-negotiable. It is not an issue about which they have a choice.

It is not just a question about improving literacy in English, it is a fundamental issue about cultural maintenance, and that seems to have bypassed this parliament, or at least this minister and this government, because if they had an interest or an understanding they would be demanding that the Northern Territory government immediately reinstate the program. If the minister is not able to do that, then he should be making funds available so that these programs are directly funded in the Northern Territory, and the Northern Territory government is bypassed. That is possible. Indeed, when the Labor Party is re-elected to office I will be advocating that course. It seems to me that we have to be able to respond to the wishes of the community. I note that the minister is prepared to respond readily and quickly to the demands of the non-government school sector, yet in the context of the demands of the government school sector it is as if their pleas fall on deaf ears. They have certainly fallen on deaf ears in the context of Aboriginal bilingual education in the Northern Territory.

It is also worth pointing out that this week in the Northern Territory the Australian Education Union is boycotting the transmission of MAP, multilevel assessment program tests, until the Northern Territory government restores the bilingual education program. The MAP program is to be administered to year 3 and 5 students throughout the next two years. The tests have been in the Northern Territory for the last 15 years.

This week teachers throughout the Northern Territory are considering whether or not they will be administering the MAP test and have threatened that they will not administer it. They will be reporting back to their organisation this week after meetings in Tennant Creek, Nhulunbuy and Katherine on Thursday and Friday. But the union is expecting to hear back from the Northern Territory government, who are jumping fast. The union has had meetings yesterday and today with Northern Territory Minister Adamson, who in the context of a hierarchy of dills around Australia is probably the biggest. The Northern Territory government has said it will come back, possibly tomorrow.

Action is being taken because of misuse of MAP data to discredit the bilingual education program. The teachers also want an undertaking that the information be confidential to each school community, which was certainly not the case with the bilingual education decision and the decision to close Traeger Park School in Alice Springs. It had been used publicly as an excuse to knock off the bilingual program and to close the Traeger Park School. They also want an undertaking that the information will be confidential to each school community, which has certainly not been the case. The benchmark data is used in reporting to the Commonwealth, which is used by the Commonwealth to determine the funding which goes to the Northern Territory.

The union, rightly, wants a guarantee for the number of positions involved and the resources available to the bilingual education program. It is very clear that this MAP data has been misused in the past, and it rightfully wants guarantees that it will not happen in the future. The Northern Territory government illegitimately compared bilingual and non-bilingual education schools when they have enormously different factors involved in their assessment, not the least of which are their geography and the nature of their school populations. It is a completely illegitimate use of the MAP data to use it as a reason to close the bilingual education program. They used the same data to close the progressive Traeger Park School.

These things are happening today. It seems that the Northern Territory government is only worried about the outcomes in Aboriginal schools when the data received from them is concerned with raising money from the Commonwealth. The system-wide programs in the Northern Territory have not been used properly, and it is clear that the data which is being collected on behalf of the minister here in this place is being used to discriminate against certain schools with regard to their achievements. Students who are not achieving up to standard will suffer, and there is no benchmark test or program in place for the allocation of extra resources to address these needs. The minister here has said that it is the schools' responsibility, that they will get as much each year as they require to get all students up to scratch. The fact is that this has not happened.

We hear a lot in this place, and I have heard outside this place, about issues to do with community development and the role of training and employment. Fundamental to all of these things, to improving the community benefit, to improving the social capital of this country, is a foundation in education. I will not have time tonight to talk about education in remote and rural Australia and for isolated children but I would like to, because they too have been disadvantaged by decisions of this government and the Northern Territory government, and I am sure by other state and territory governments. What is clear in terms of the resources that are required to provide people with the basic skills, whether it is literacy and numeracy, social skills or whatever, is that a large proportion of the school population outside of the major metropolitan areas is missing out. So obviously when they go and compete for jobs in a tight labour market they do not have the skills required not only to get the job but also to get into the most basic foundational education program in a post-school environment, in a pre-vocation program.

Is it their fault? Is it the community's fault? Invariably it is not their fault. Invariably it is the fault of governments, who have the responsibility to allocate resources and to respond to community wishes and community demands. But also invariably, and I might say almost as a matter of course, governments nationally and at a state and territory level do not adopt this strategy. If we are to improve the educational outcomes and therefore the employment outcomes and promote industry development on a regional basis, there is a fundamental requirement for us to accept and understand that regions across Australia differ, that states and territories have different demands and that within their boundaries those demands differ. We have to accept that we need to address those demands in a way which achieves the outcomes which are best suited to those particular communities and regions. We have not come to grips with that, and it is clear, given the way in which bilingual education has been addressed not only by this government but by the Northern Territory government, that there is no prospect of them coming to terms with those demands in the near future.

I say to this government and to the Northern Territory government that the best way to improve the educational outcomes of these children and other children throughout the Northern Territory and indeed Australia is to understand and respond to their community and regional needs. If you do that, you will divert resources that, in my view, need to be diverted away from other areas and focus on the areas of greatest need. That is yet to happen. I am hoping that at some stage this minister and this government will come to terms with their responsibilities, although I am sorry to say that I doubt it will ever happen. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This has been a wide-ranging debate on education policy, as it deserves to be. Through the Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1999 the government is trying to abolish the primary sources of independent advice that it receives on education. That of course is regrettable, but at least it provides an opportunity for opposition members to provide advice to the government on education policy. Education has always been important to the goals outlined by the member for the Northern Territory—social cohesiveness, social tolerance and social capital—but more than ever education policy is coming to the centre of economic debates. Education is becoming increasingly important in public policy, particularly economic policy. This in turn has been driven by two major changes in the economy, indeed by an economic revolution.

speech.para: The first change relates to the way in which things that were once made by muscle and machine power are now made much more by brain power. The second revolutionary change refers to the mobility of the economy, the fact that companies can make their products anywhere and try to sell them everywhere. This is a very different set of economic issues and events for policy makers to consider. At their heart, the heart of both mobility through new information technology and the importance of brain power, is the overriding significance of education and the propagation of knowledge. These are the central themes now for not only a good society but a strong economy. It is what Kim Beazley has so beautifully described as `Australia's aspiration to become a knowledge nation'.

In fact this recognition of the importance of education policy is even starting to trickle down to the other side of politics. I note that in recent months the Prime Minister has been breaking the habits of a lifetime by actually bursting into some rhetoric about the significance of education and the development of knowledge. But of course talking about knowledge based industries and knowledge economics is a different thing from understanding them. It reminds me a bit of what Paul Keating once had to say about micro-economic reform. These days you can walk into any pet shop and you will find the resident galah talking about education policy.

I think it is regrettable that the government is abolishing the advisory bodies led by NBEET. This is not a time for governments to narrow their advice on education policy. In fact, they need to broaden their advice to consider the ongoing debates and indeed some of the confusion about what good education policy might now entail and, in turn, what good education policy can do for the strength of economic outcomes. It is not a time for narrowing; it is a time for broadening advice and taking a far wider perspective about education policy. To fully understand knowledge as an economic input is not an easy task. Peter Drucker, the US guru, has pointed out that economists are still waiting for an Adam Smith or a David Ricardo of the knowledge economy; that is, someone who can cut through the new economic disciplines and the new economic events and make sense in theory of the importance of knowledge to the economy, to make sense of where we should be headed with education policy.

The new economy based on knowledge is very much different from the old economy based on commodities. Knowledge is subject to increasing economic returns; commodities are subject to diminishing economic returns. This is an interesting idea—that knowledge actually increases the more it is used. The more someone learns, generally the more they want to learn, whereas in the normal understanding of economic events when you use a commodity or an economic input its worth and its value will diminish as it is used. Knowledge is the opposite. The more it is used, the more its importance and its value grows. So it is a fundamental rewriting of one of the old laws—diminishing economic returns—that you would find in every schoolboy's textbook. So too knowledge is a mobile input to economic events, commodities tend to be much more immobile.

Knowledge displays many public good features; that is, everyone can use it and no one person's use of knowledge stops others from using it. Commodities are much more a private good where use is much more exclusive. Knowledge opens itself up for niche production and niche consumerism in the economy, whereas the old base of commodity production was much more in tune with mass consumption and mass production. Knowledge is very much unpredictable. It is about problem solving. The old commodity based economy was more predictable; it gave rise to a whole generation of economic planning ideals.

The point I am making is that the move to a knowledge based economy is a total rewriting of economic theory. It is a total reunderstanding of the way in which education policy might apply to economic outcomes. So this is not a time to narrow down the advice available to the government. The government should be broadening its economic policy advice to take account of new growth theories in economics, to take account of all these fundamental changes in the economy and to try and link sound education policy not only to good social outcomes but to very important economic outcomes. It is not a time for narrowing. The whole focus of education policy needs to change in tune with the new economic focus.

My preliminary reading of this, if I can explain it in one concept, is that governments need to start thinking about the economy in terms of inputs, and the most important input is education and knowledge. The generation of ideas, innovation, the invention of new commodities and the marketing of new concepts are all fundamentally important goals for economic growth, but they rely on inputs to an increasingly unpredictable economy. The old style of industry policy was very much focused on outputs. It was very much focused on outcomes, the idea being that industry policy could manipulate market outcomes, that you could throw in a subsidy, a tariff and a bit of protection, prop up profitability and that would impact indirectly on employment outcomes.

The whole economic focus has fundamentally changed. Those industry policy and industry planning ideals have been blown apart in the new economy and they need to be replaced by a whole new approach, a whole new methodology in not only economic policy but education and research policy. We need to focus, first and foremost, on inputs to the new economy—the inputs of learning, the inputs of knowledge propagation and the inputs of research—and on the environment by which people will innovate and invent. That of course leads one fundamentally to strong conclusions about the need for competition policy for open and competitive markets.

In the new knowledge based economy, markets are the best place to settle outcomes. The best role for government is to fashion inputs, to build up the education resources of a nation, to build up our knowledge investments and to improve our research base. These are all the valuable inputs that a wise government would develop for a knowledge based economy. Unhappily, the Howard government has done exactly the opposite. The sorry tale of this government's performance has been fundamental cuts to education, training and research—exactly the opposite of what national economic policy requires at this delicate time in our economy's transition to a knowledge base.

I make these points not really to dismiss the importance of old industry policy but just to point out that it is so outdated and old-fashioned as to have become totally redundant. Was there ever an industry plan which anticipated the Internet? Has there ever been an industry plan which anticipated a new industry? I have read a lot of economics and education policy in my time and I am yet to find one. This, of course, points to the fact that these new knowledge industries are so unpredictable. In fact, they cannot be forward planned; they cannot be planned at all. We are talking about technologies that are not yet invented, industries that are not yet conceived and jobs which have not yet been conceptualised. How can government know what the market is going to do with these knowledge based industries more than the market itself does? How can government plan against an uncertain future when the technologies, the industries and the jobs are still unfolding in practice? The market knows these things best because it deals with these disciplines on a daily basis. Government is in no position to know these things or to plan ahead and fashion policy around them. If industry policy were a problematic task in the old economy, it is a mission impossible in the new economy.

I make these points out of my concern for some of the misuse that the government may be making of the Ralph review. This idea that you can use business taxation policy as a new way of manipulating economic outcomes in knowledge based industries is a fantasy. To introduce capital gains concessions, to open up tax avoidance on a major scale and to have capital gains rates below corporate tax rates is a foolish policy because government cannot pick winners in the knowledge sector. Government cannot plan ahead for the new technologies, the new industries and the new jobs. Only one part of the economy can have any chance of understanding these ideas: the market based disciplines that deal with them on a daily basis.

So what are the right inputs? If government cannot plan ahead for economic outputs and outcomes in the new economy, what are the right inputs? The great discipline, the great policy imperative, is to fund people, not profits. The important thing in education research policy is to fund the smart people, the researchers, the personnel, who are going to develop the new ideas and the new knowledge that will drive forward the new economy. They are the people who are needed to generate and create the wealth in the first place upon which the market might commercialise good ideas and turn them into marketable products.

So the main discipline is to fund people, to fund the best and brightest of Australia's researchers. We should have a great national effort to identify our best undergraduates and deliver to them portable research scholarships that keep them in Australia working on their ideas and their research in this country and developing the knowledge base that will drive the Australian economy and Australian society forward in the coming decades. Fund people, not profits. Create the knowledge first and allow the market to commercialise these new ideas and new products as only the market can.

Again, this just exposes the absolute folly of putting tax expenditures into capital gains cuts while we have not got a growing research base in Australia. We are losing our best researchers and our best people to countries overseas. Our first spending priority as a parliament and as a nation must be to our people to fund the skills, the insight and research of Australians and grow our research budgets, not cut them back. This government is totally misguided in giving a greater focus to the Ralph review than the green paper on research. It has its priorities upside down. We need to grow the research quantum in Australia and we need to deliver the portable research scholarships for the best and brightest of our undergraduates as they move into postgraduate research work.

I mention this research issue not just out of national concern but also as a regional concern in Western Sydney. There is often speculation as to what portable research scholarships would mean for those universities outside the so-called `great eight'. What would it mean for a university like Western Sydney? My belief is that all universities can develop a research specialty. All universities should have the capacity to do the things and research the things that they do best. For the University of Western Sydney this is now a critical goal. You do not need to be in the great eight in Australia to do research well. If you build on your strengths and on your specialties, you can in fact build an international research reputation.

Our universities now are very much positioned in a global environment—talk of Internet degrees and massive exchanges of students on an international scale. Universities now need to pitch themselves and their performance to the global learning environment. For the University of Western Sydney this is a critical goal. It has been for a decade or more our great hope, the great inspiration, for our region that our best young people can go on and get a university education where they live. They do not have to trek down to the centre of Sydney as some of the old-timers like myself had to do in the 1970s and the early 1980s.

But the University of Western Sydney needs to be more than a great hope and a great inspiration; it needs to be a great performer. It needs to move on to its second stage of development beyond hope and inspiration and into hard-nosed performance. On the research agenda it needs the staff to build up an international reputation. What can it do well in Western Sydney? My belief is that it can develop a research reputation using our great social laboratory. If you had to take any part of Australia—and I would even speculate any part of the world—and look for diverse labour market conditions, diverse urban geography, diverse social and economic outcomes, cultural diversity, the impact of globalisation, the information revolution, the new labour market, issues of community and social capital—a whole melting point of all these changes—it would be Western Sydney. If you had to take one part of this country, and indeed the whole planet, which had a real and diverse social laboratory in which to study these things, it would be the suburbs of Western Sydney.

The natural resource for research at the University of Western Sydney is our own region. That university should be building up the specialties for social and economic research related to all those issues. It can do that by specialising and by using the one resource that will give it an international reputation. Of course, an international reputation brings with it extra public and private sector support and that, in turn, builds the university.

In recent decades we have seen so-called junior universities like Wollongong and Newcastle build up over time: they start out small, they specialise and build up expertise, research and teaching capacity, and now they are the great improvers. They are leading the improvers handicap when you look at the league table that comes out every year on Australia's universities. The University of Western Sydney can do the same. It needs to move into its second phase of development and build up those particular research specialties.

In the time left to me I would like to talk about some training issues, because they too are relevant to the way in which this government is narrowing its policy advice. I mentioned earlier the unpredictable, very fluid nature of the new economy. This is one of the great tasks for training policy. How do we anticipate technological change? How do we mould training packages around the inevitability of workplace restructuring? I believe Australia needs to move its training agenda from patch-up labour market programs to pre-emptive training.

We have a worrying habit that we get serious about training initiatives only once people have been unemployed for 12 months. Only when they have really removed themselves from active labour force participation does the federal government at any stage seem concerned at all about their prospects. That patch-up job is a lot harder once people have been so long out of the work force, because the longer someone is unemployed the more likely they are to remain unemployed. The training and the social costs of getting them back into work of course grow exponentially. We need to move to a pre-emptive training agenda. We need to have training programs and training funding that allow low income, low skill workers to anticipate or at least work with technological change in the workplace and not be retrenched in the first place.

A good model for this is Singapore. Singapore is not an antibusiness economy, but it has a levy that it places on all businesses for low income, low skill workers. The government collects the pool of money and the companies have to tender back with training programs that help the low income, low skill employees. This has the advantage of helping the company. It has the advantage of improving corporate investments in training, particularly for low income, low skill people. If you look at all the training outcomes, it is the middle to high income earners who will get the money, either out of their own pocket or the company's pocket, to do the training that keeps them economically successful. It is the low skill, low income workers who get left behind and ultimately go on the unemployment queue.

We need to move pre-emptively against that. We need to establish a scheme that pools corporate and public money and allows the companies to tender back on the training program and put in place all the training in the workplace that will upgrade the skills of their low income workers. As the technology changes in the enterprise, the workers are uplifting and improving their skills, staying with the business and avoiding the curse of long-term unemployment.

On this agenda there is also a corporate responsibility with regard to disabled workers and older workers. It is possible to calibrate this corporate contribution to give very strong consideration to training of disabled workers and older workers. If companies are not willing to do that, then governments should put the money into training disabled and older workers who already have been made unemployed. So there are corporate as well as governmental responsibilities that can improve Australia's training outcomes.

Many more things need to be addressed in education policy. I sometimes feel I could go on all night about these things—middle school crisis, the disadvantaged schools program and changes to the school funding initiatives. I have touched on research and the new economy tonight and I have touched on training initiatives, but I do say to the government that it should reconsider the narrowing of its policy advice. Now is the time to broaden and work out the whole revolution of not only economic policy but education policy that needs to be built into all the public programs in this nation.

talk.start.para: —I would like to begin by thanking the government speakers, the member for Bradfield and the member for Dawson, for taking part in this debate, and also the member for Dobell, the members for Batman, Lawler, Shortland and the Northern Territory; and it is always interesting to listen to the member for Werriwa.

speech.para: As the member for Werriwa has said, as it turned out, this was a very wide-ranging debate, so I will remind the House what this bill is really about. The Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1999 amends the Employment, Education and Training Act 1998 to abolish the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, or NBEET, and four of its councils: the Australian Language and Literacy Council, the Employment and Skills Council, the Higher Education Council and the Schools Council. The Australian Research Council and its membership will continue unchanged, and it will operate as an independent council providing advice and will report directly to the minister. The bill also makes minor technical amendments to the act, removing definitions no longer required under the act, removing schedule 1 and retaining the position of director to service the ARC. The bill also includes transitional provisions providing for continuity of membership of the ARC, the councillors and the committees which it assists.

The member for Dobell has made a number of claims, which I will refer to. One claim was that there was no good reason to abolish NBEET. The member for Dobell may not realise that the board and councils being abolished in this bill have already wound up their work and only the ARC is currently working on advice to the minister. There are ample existing representative bodies to give advice to the government on issues which were covered by NBEET and the four councils being abolished. These cover all sectors of education. In addition, as specific issues arise, the government can establish short-term task forces to advise on specific issues. In line with the government's intention to create more independent advisory bodies, the ARC will now provide advice and report directly to the minister and take responsibility for promoting informed public debate on research in Australia.

There were also claims made about the falling number of postgraduate places. In fact, postgraduate places are rising, and the government is committed to ensuring that opportunities for all Australian students continue to increase. Universities' projections indicate that the number of student places will grow between 1996 and 2001. The focus on undergraduates means that more people than ever before are receiving their first opportunity for higher education. As I said, the total of all domestic postgraduate places is rising, with universities forecasting a 10 per cent increase by 2001. Postgraduate fee-paying student places have increased by almost 50 per cent since 1996. The number of research student places continues to rise. Universities project a 7.6 per cent increase between 1996 and 1998, and a further 11 per cent increase is forecast to 2000. The member for Dobell also made comments about the education budget.

talk.start.para: —What education budget?
—The member for Dobell's interjection demands the question: what Labor policy is there on education? From their amendments, there is obviously something, and that is to find another NBEET-like body—

speech.para: Mr Latham interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Werriwa lost a few policy points at the last election, and they have not been replaced. The truth is that the government is committing over $11 billion per annum over the budget and forward estimate period to develop stronger, vibrant education and training sectors into the new millennium. This budget sees increased funding of $870 million over the next four years—not that one would have known that from listening to the opposition debate tonight.

speech.para: The member for Dobell has moved amendments, but that is an attempt to recreate an NBEET-like body, and the government of course would seek to listen—as I think the member for Werriwa hinted was a good idea—to advice from many different sources. The impact on HECS got a mention, and I remind the member for Dobell that the number of people from disadvantaged groups is increasing steadily. Essentially, HECS remains as it was when Labor introduced it—a scheme that enables people to attend university and defer the cost until they have a reasonable income level.

The member for Lalor made some comments about funding to government schools, and they were also inaccurate. I remind the member for Lalor that government schools get 85 per cent of their public funding from state governments and 15 per cent from the Commonwealth. Non-government schools get 18 per cent of their public funding from state governments and 37 per cent from the Commonwealth. The really important point is that all state governments are overwhelmingly in favour of government schools, but no-one claims that state governments are opposed to non-government schools for this reason. When all sources of public funding are taken into account, that is, Commonwealth and state—and I do hope the member for Lalor is listening to this—governments spend, on average, $5,600 per government school student. The same figure for a non-government student is $3,500. For students at wealthier schools, this figure can be low as $1,500 per student.

The member for Werriwa has been interesting in his discussion of education policy again tonight. I agree with him that muscle power is giving way in many instances to brain power, that mobility is important, and that education and knowledge must be propagated. These are challenges for policymakers. But, having heard this from the member for Werriwa, we would not want to limit our advice from NBEET. It is not time for narrowing; it is time for increasing and receiving advice from a wide range of sources, and that is exactly what the government is doing. Partnerships are being formed between governments, industry and educators, which of course is what is so important for our young people in an ever-changing world.

The member for Werriwa has also made comments about research. He must be making a glowing endorsement of the portable research grants which are recommended and proposed in the `New knowledge, new opportunities' government discussion paper on research and research training which was released on 30 June. I hope that has clarified some of the issues. Again, I thank those who have taken part in this debate.

talk.start.para: —I have never seen the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs move so quickly. Did you see how quickly he left the chamber? He was desperate not to be given an opportunity to speak at the table and actually debate this piece of legislation, the Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1999 , that he has introduced into the House. The reason the minister has flick-passed this legislation to the member for Adelaide is that this is, once again, another piece of legislation where the minister is seeking to deny the people who know something about education having an input into this government's decision making processes.

speech.para: During this debate the government has made a number of outrageous claims. First of all, the parliamentary secretary representing the minister for education made the claim that, under the Howard government, HECS is basically unchanged from the HECS that was left by the former Keating government. I say to the representative of the minister for education that obviously she does not understand that there have been massive increases in HECS fees for students. The students at university today know it is the Howard government that has massively increased the charges that they are hit with every year they are at university.

What is even worse than the higher fees that the government has placed on those students who are making the effort to study at university is the government lowering the repayment threshold at which students start to repay their HECS debt. Under the Labor government it was based on average weekly earnings of $27,000 or $28,000 a year. People had to earn that each year before they started to repay their HECS debt. Under this government, that threshold has been dropped to only $21,000. Under this government, more and more part-time workers and part-time students are finding it almost impossible to make the effort to go to university without being hit with the requirement to repay the HECS debt as they go. At the same time they are trying to pay off a housing mortgage and look after their families. These are the people who are hardest hit by this government's unfair and inequitable changes to the HECS system. For the Howard government's representative to get up in this chamber and claim that HECS is basically unchanged demonstrates that they are out of touch. The Howard government and the minister for education do not understand the damage that they have inflicted on higher education in Australia.

In deciding to abolish the Higher Education Council, the government denies itself the opportunity to hear dissenting views and to learn about the damage that is being done by these changes to HECS. It denies itself the opportunity to learn how many students from low income backgrounds, from non-English-speaking backgrounds, from remote communities and from indigenous backgrounds will be less able to afford to go to university because of its changes. The government is denying itself the opportunity to listen to independent research and to hear from people who actually know what is happening in the community. In deciding tonight to abolish the Higher Education Council the government is refusing to listen to these alternative viewpoints.

The representative of Dr Kemp, the minister for education, said in the House tonight that under this legislation the government will hear more opinions and will consult more widely—by abolishing the very body that gives advice to the government about higher education issues. The way we are going to find out about the damage that is being done by the increase in HECS is to abolish the very council whose job it was to investigate the damage that had been done by HECS. As my colleague the member for Port Adelaide has said on many occasions, under this minister for education you feel like you are living in 1984. You feel like you are hearing newspeak.

talk.start.para: —Kids used to be able to read in 1984.

—You go back to fixing up the Western Australian forests. Go and ring up a few more constituents, Wilson. You did a good job on the weekend. The point we make is that the government has demonstrated in this debate that it just does not understand the damage it has done to higher education across the country. It does not just stop at the minister for education, I am afraid to say. When the Prime Minister of Australia said, the week before the last budget, that he was going to bring down an education budget, there were a lot of people around the country whose hopes were raised. They thought that maybe John Howard would see that he has made mistakes in cutting back funding for universities. They thought that maybe he realised it was time that Australia invested more in education.

speech.para: People's hopes were raised the week before the budget but, when the budget was brought down, what did it do? There was to be another year of further cuts in the operating grants for universities. There was to be another year with no growth funding for TAFE. It was to be a year when the government abolished the merit based equity scholarship scheme, the scheme that gave kids from low income backgrounds and from remote Australia a chance to get a scholarship to go to university. It was an education budget where the government decided to give $21 to private schools for every dollar it gives to government schools. The government has failed completely to provide a fair balance in funding for schools across Australia.

Labor believes that we should be investing more in Australia's schools—our government schools, our public schools and our private schools—because that is the only way we can make sure we lift the quality of education that kids are getting in schools right across the country. My worry is that I think the Prime Minister did believe that this was an education budget. In his terms, an education budget is a budget that cuts funding for universities and does nothing about TAFE. It is a budget that provides an unfair system of extra funding for private schools while ignoring government schools, and it abolishes those merit based equity scholarships. That is what the Prime Minister thinks is an education budget. That is what will doom this minister for education and this Prime Minister for the decisions they have taken.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —It was a big day for defence today. Here we have another piece of legislation dealing with some important issues in the Defence Force and the Minister for Defence is not here—he is still AWOL—nor is the junior minister, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, here—he will probably come in. Anybody who knows anything about it on the government side seems to be absent tonight.

speech.para: Mr Laurie Ferguson interjecting—

talk.start.para: —We will see whether that is the case. There are some important issues in the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1999 which we are dealing with tonight. It is not often that legislation dealing with defence issues comes before the parliament and gives us an opportunity to talk about some of the important issues facing the ADF at this point and to consider changes that are necessary to ensure that ADF personnel are treated appropriately in a variety of circumstances. This bill seeks to implement a process for urine drug testing of members of the Australian Defence Force who are involved in combat or combat related duties, as well as establish associated disciplinary measures by amending the Defence Act of 1903. This is necessary because for some time the ADF has had a no-drugs policy. That policy requires the relevant service authority to initiate disciplinary or administrative action against any member of the ADF found selling, possessing, dealing in or administering an illegal drug. The administrative sanctions include termination of appointment for officers, discharge from the services for non-officers or reduction in rank.

speech.para: This is not a new measure. In fact, the decision to commence this process was taken during the tenure of the former Labor government. In September 1993, the then Chief of the Defence Force directed that a urine testing program be implemented across the ADF. The proposal entailed a UTP of samples from randomly selected ADF members, testing for narcotic substances. The testing program was going to have an emphasis on personnel from operational basic training establishments. That is quite appropriate.

We hear much about drugs in sport. We hear much about drugs in the workplace. Quite clearly, if anybody is in a working environment, whether it be as a runner or a swimmer or in the workplace as we would traditionally know it, then obviously we want to ensure that occupational health and safety considerations are foremost in an employer's mind and indeed in the minds of employees.

Individuals in the Australian Defence Force find themselves in a special circumstance, as we have been trying to point out to the Minister for Defence over the last couple of days. People in the Australian Defence Force train for particular tasks which are dangerous and intense and require people to work in very difficult conditions. Obviously, we need to ensure that those people are at peak condition. Through testing procedures, in terms of fitness we actually are achieving that, although to some extent the fact that these fitness regimes have been put in place and used to weed out some people from the Australian Defence Force perhaps is not the consequence which was intended as part of that process. The urine testing program which we are talking about here ensures that people are fit in the workplace environment. Quite obviously, it is vital for our ADF personnel to be clean and able to perform the high risk tasks which are part of their everyday working environment.
