This initiative was supported by the then Minister for Defence back in 1993, Senator Robert Ray, and the Minister for Defence, Science and Personnel, Senator Faulkner. However, it was not able to be implemented without legislation because concerns were raised by the Privacy Commissioner and the Attorney-General's Department. That same year, legislation was drafted to implement these recommendations but did not get introduced into the parliament before the 1996 general election. It is regrettable that it took three years from when the decision was taken to do something about testing, having to go through a minefield of bureaucratic red tape and through the processes of satisfying people's concerns about privacy and other legal constraints imposed by the Attorney-General's Department.

Those on the other side may well echo the usual chant which they continue to throw up: `You had 13 years to do something about this.' We did have three years to do something about it; that is true. It is now 1999. The present government has also been in government for three years and this legislation is only now being introduced so that this testing process can take place.

The Australian Defence Association and the Armed Forces Federation of Australia support in principle a drug testing program but, as I understand it, do not have a specific position in respect of the legislation which we are debating tonight. A general view expressed by both the ADA and AFFA is that any drug testing program should apply equally to all uniformed personnel, irrespective of their duties, considering that in time of combat all ADF personnel may be in combat or combat related areas. Clearly, it is a matter of balancing occupational health and safety concerns with concerns about civil liberties of ADF members, but like the initiative launched under the previous Labor government, this program would specifically focus on combat and combat related personnel. That is a very important point which needs to be made at this time: we are talking about combat personnel who are combat ready and have a degree of readiness to perform appropriate tasks. It is part of the no-drugs policy which certainly the ADF has in place and which is supported obviously by the government and certainly by the opposition.

I would like to turn now to the next issue contained in this legislation, which relates to the transfer of senior officers to the reserves. The bill itself seeks to allow certain officers to transfer to the reserves when their term of appointment ends. It is designed to hold on to skilled and experienced senior officers once they leave active service, by making transfer to the reserves easier. And I have got to say that the way some of the senior officers in the ADF are falling over under this minister, there are quite likely to be a number of positions available which these people would like to be able to slip into. Hopefully, this legislation, Minister, might give them that opportunity. At present, an officer who wishes to move to the reserves has to retire or be retired from the relevant service and then seek to be appointed to the reserves. Given that the reserves are part of Australia's armed services, this is a somewhat administratively cumbersome approach and I endorse the fact that the government is trying to do something about it. The provision is restricted to service chiefs and senior officers engaged on limited tenure promotions. I want to say, in respect of this concept of senior officers being transferred into the reserves, they are probably going to be needed.

I say to the minister opposite—the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence—and say to him quite genuinely, that this question of the reserves is a real problem at the present minute. I try to offer some comment to you in the spirit of bipartisanship, arising from some recent visits which I, my colleague the Shadow Minister for Defence Science and Personnel and members of the caucus National Security and Trade Committee experienced in the last couple of days. Last week we had the opportunity to visit both Brisbane and Townsville and speak at length with people in the Australian Defence Force. The week before, my colleague the shadow minister and I had the opportunity to visit Rockhampton and to meet specifically with people from the reserves and to talk about the sorts of concerns they had.

I might say, Mr Deputy Speaker Hollis, that you as the Deputy Chairman of the powerful Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade would be across this issue yourself. The issue about senior officers being able to transfer into the reserves is relevant and important. There is a vacuum being created, regrettably, because of government policy in one area, which I will come to in a moment, but also because for some reason—and people in the reserves will tell you this themselves—there is not quite the attractiveness out there in the broad community for people to pursue a military career, whether it be in a full-time capacity or in the reserves.

An interesting statistic which the minister knows, I am sure, was put to us last week when we were travelling around: proportionately more of the people who sign up for the reserves, and indeed the armed forces, come from Queensland. There is something about Queensland; there is something about the concept of Queenslanders that fits very nicely in the ADF. The minister would be delighted about that, I am sure. Maybe that is why he and his senior colleague, both from Queensland, have been given responsibility for defence issues.

But we were informed that the sorts of people being attracted into the reserves these days are people who are unemployed or students. There are some business people who clearly want to make a contribution, but we have been led to believe, and I think it is pretty close to the mark, that whilst this may be the case, unfortunately the number of those sorts of people wanting to get involved is starting to trend downwards. Perhaps they see that the excitement, the conditions of service, or whatever, that are necessary are no longer appropriate to them. But I suspect that, more importantly, it is tied to two other issues.

One, as I said, is a policy issue: it goes to the decision taken by your ministerial colleague, the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, to tie in leave for reservist activities and so on and to reduce that as an allowable matter under awards. That is having a significant effect. It is having a significant effect for people now getting released from work to be able to participate and to train for the Australian Defence Force reserves. I am sure the minister would agree that it is no longer appropriate these days to run a reserve force like it is Boy Scouts or a branch meeting of the National Party or the Labor Party, where once a month or once a week on a Tuesday night you go along to the local hall and you do a bit of drill and that is about the extent of it. In terms of our broader strategic environment and in terms of our force structure, there is unfortunately going to be a greater reliance upon and need for reservists to play an active role, particularly now as the government has got a second brigade on 28-day-ready deployment. We have to look at ways in which those reservists can be encouraged.

It was put to us that it is very difficult for small businesses. For instance, a watchmaker or somebody in a jewellery shop, I think it was, had a number of employees and each of those, because they liked the lifestyle, was in the reserves. But as the small businessman himself said, `I can't afford to give all these employees who belong to the same reserve regiment an opportunity to just leave for a period of three to four weeks at a time to go off on training exercises, because who is going to run the shop when I am not there?' So it becomes a real problem. This question of the allowable matter, which, as I said, the minister's colleague unfortunately has been able to put through, has created an incredible difficulty for people who perhaps would like to serve. I say to the minister, if he can convince his colleague Peter Reith to introduce amending legislation that will make it possible for employers to give reservists time off for military service, particularly in the light of the increased role for the reserves in respect of the requirement of bringing the first brigade to 28-days readiness, I will give you this commitment in this place tonight that we will support it 100 per cent, because it is an important issue that needs to be addressed.

I say this in fairness to the minister as well. I know that the government is looking at this whole question of reserves. I know that the Prime Minister has been lobbied about this and has taken an interest in it, and I know that the minister and his senior colleagues have asked for a full and thorough review—of the reserves and how the system might work—to be provided to the government. We would welcome that. We would welcome an opportunity to perhaps make comment on any of the suggestions that come forward from a review of that nature. We certainly have some views about the way the reserves are currently structured. We have some views about the Ready Reserve. We have some views about the way in which the importance that is now placed on the reserve as an important element of the way the ADF operates needs to be fully considered by the government of the day. We would like to think that we have heightened readiness because, under the Defence Reform Program, there is still a process whereby people leave—and are meant to leave to get it down to a manageable force structure that the government believes is going to be appropriate for the circumstances today. The rotational necessities associated with people going in and out of those 28-day readiness organisations is significant for the reserves themselves to play a real part. So we would like to think that that is an opportunity the government might be looking at as part of this review.

As far as the senior officers being able to be transferred into the reserves is concerned—absolutely. You cannot lose corporate memory. When these people who have reached 20 or 30 years of service and are occupying the senior positions in Australia's Defence Force leave—they might be admirals, be generals or whatever—we should provide opportunities for them to continue their very valuable contribution to the defence of this nation by passing on those skills to people within the ADF. That can be done of course through the reserves. There are needs to be addressed here. They are needs to be clearly looked at around the country. We do not want to see a whole bunch of well-meaning people get together on a Tuesday night, do a little bit of drill, maybe learn a little bit about military history—and then go and spend a couple of hours at the pub. That is really not what reserves are all about. They are an integral part of the Australian Defence Force now and will be a growing part of the Australian Defence Force.

The other issues contained in this legislation are minor administrative and technical changes to a variety of defence related legislation. The legislation seeks to extend the time limitation for the laying of charges from three to five years under the Defence Force Discipline Act, following recommendations of a Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee on the crash of the RAAF Nomad aircraft. I might also say to the minister that of course the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee recently handed down a report on military justice which, I suspect, may have some interest in this as well. Whilst not suggesting for a moment that this minor amendment about time limitation in any way should be altered as a result of that, I do think that the government should keep this issue under review and have a look at the recommendations in that joint committee report. I thought it was quite a thorough report, having been a member of the committee for a brief time and having participated in some of the work that was done. That report is relevant to the issues before us.

This Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1999 also endeavours to make minor wording correction amendments to the Defence Force (Home Loans Assistance) Act of 1990 and the Defence Legislation Act (No. 1) of 1997. The minister will know that over the last couple of days this issue of Defence Force housing and other fringe benefits has been the subject of some questioning in this place by us. The reason this has been done is the widespread concern which we were made aware of by spouses associations, by serving men and women themselves and by any simple reading of Army, Navy or Air Force magazines regarding what people consider to be an unfair attack being mounted upon their conditions of employment in the ADF by the Australian Taxation Office.

It concerns an interpretation of legislation under the better tax system—or whatever the government calls its new tax system legislative program—which would see the value of fringe benefits, whether in housing or whatever, grossed up so that this would appear on group certificates. People say, `Why not? Every other element of the work force should be treated in the same way.' I have to say that the Labor Party does not have a problem with that philosophical position. We do believe that benefits other than those in cash form should be accounted for on group certificates, as should any other allowances or ways in which governments contribute—whether it is through the tax system, the social security system, the education system or whatever. However, that said, in terms of the Australian Defence Force, I think a very clear argument can be made that these people are not like others in the work force. These people sign up. They are sent to different locations around Australia—quite often not because they choose to do so but they know they are in the Army and that is expected. They are on call 24 hours a day. They do not have access to the same justice systems that we do in the context of the normal work environment. They do not have access to all the other things which people normally associate with awards or with conditions of employment—whether they be under the government's own preferred system of work contracts between employers and employees. As a consequence of that, we now find that there is an attack being launched by the Australian Taxation Office. I know—and I think most people in this place who have taken interest in this would know—that General Peter Dunn has made submissions on behalf of the Australian Defence Force to the tax office. I think those submissions are also being directed towards the government. Again, I say to the minister: we would be only too delighted to lend support to a legislative change which sees the Australian Defence Force excluded from what we consider to be punitive measures under the fringe benefits tax reporting mechanisms.

It is probably an unintended consequence. It is probably something which people did not want to happen. Certainly, this did not happen under Labor. We introduced the fringe benefits tax, but Labor quarantined people in the ADF from that tax. We did so in recognition of the special place that these people have in the Australian work force—for want of a better description—and because of the role they play in the defence of this nation and because of what they have to give up.

I do not think the Minister for Defence comprehends the strength of feeling about this issue. I would be surprised if his colleague on the other side is not more aware of this because I know that he gets around a fair bit and talks to people in the Defence Force. Minister Scott, you need to get the ear of your senior cabinet colleague and tell him to start reading a few of the letters to the editor in the magazines that I referred to earlier. Tell him to get out of the Bushmasters and off the bridges of the FFGs and to start talking to the people—the sailors, the privates and, importantly, the spouses of these people. He will get an earful.

I know that you have had an earful, Minister, but the Minister for Defence should listen to what these people have to say. It is critical for these people. The feeling runs so deeply that we have had women say to us, `If my husband gets moved again and this fringe benefits tax regime comes in, I tell you what, he is going to be going and we're out the door because we can't afford to live like this anymore.' People have an expectation that fairly low paid people who serve in Australia's Defence Force should not be subject to this punitive regime.

We do not think they should be either. We never did and we never will. There are special cases here. We say, and we always will, that they should be quarantined. I hope that some of the reviews that the minister has referred to will address this issue. I see by the sly grin on his face that he is probably going to make some announcement about this in the next couple of days—and I hope he does.

talk.start.para: —Another review.

—No, I do not want a review. I would like to think that this minister has the opportunity to talk to the Minister for Defence and say, `Get back into the cabinet room and see if you can convince Mr Reith and Mr Costello that the Defence Force needs some special consideration in this.' We would certainly support them. If you do not do something about it, I am afraid we might have to do something in this place or in the Senate.

speech.para: I conclude where I started. The legislation is timely although, in the broad scheme of things, the basic thrust of what it seeks to do with drug testing through urine analysis in the Australian Defence Force has been around for some time. The transfer of senior officers to the reserves is a timely measure which will bring invaluable experience to the reserves. The reserves are something that the government needs to consider very carefully. Because the main defence policy in this nation is enacted in a spirit of bipartisanship, we would certainly like to assist the government in any discussion on these sorts of issues so that a common position can be adopted. As I said, purely from a strategic point of view, from a force structure point of view, the reserves are going to play an even more critical role in the ADF as time goes by.

Finally, fringe benefits tax legislation is one of the major issues facing our Defence Force personnel at the moment. It is an issue which I know the minister is acutely aware of. I hope his senior colleague, the Minister for Defence, is also acutely aware of that after the last couple of days and that between the two of them something can be achieved to alleviate the burden on people who, at the end of the day, are serving their nation. They deserve recognition for the sorts of conditions under which they are expected to serve the nation.

I think Minister Scott knows that Darwin is not exactly the greatest place in the world to be in the middle of summer. Because of our strategic environment, we now have another brigade on 28-day readiness. We have Air Force units and Navy units there as well. That really is at the pointy end of the defence of this nation. Special consideration is necessary for people in those circumstances. After all, this is the government that says it stands up for families. Defence Force families need support. We are quite prepared to give that support. We are quite happy to lend support to the government in its endeavours to try to redress what we consider to be some very difficult circumstances at the present time.

talk.start.para: —In addressing the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1999 today, it is plain that we are discussing the defence of Australia. There are 25,000 different defence facilities at 400 discrete sites around Australia. Some 4,000 troops are located at Townsville, which is one of the larger bases, along with their dependants. Defence people have a very large impact on our communities and they fulfil a very important role in the defence of Australia. For example, when it was decided to establish a greater Army presence in the north, they set out to move a total of 2,285 troops, plus 2,600 dependants, to Darwin. The management of our armed forces is absolutely crucial. What is important is the way we go about it, the monitoring of the processes and ensuring that what we have is quality and not merely quantity.

speech.para: This bill takes us down an important path. The Navy, Army and Air Force are well known for the degree of rigour that goes into their training and for the degree of rigour that applies to their lifestyle. One of the main provisions of this bill is the introduction of drug testing of the urine of defence personnel. To ordinary civilian Australians that kind of testing might seem to be something which is reserved for athletes or people like that. However, we are talking about a highly specialised group of people—people who have a difficult job to perform in which there is no margin for error. It is very important that they function at their best. The introduction of this kind of testing is very important.

Other provisions of this bill include allowing the chief of the Army and the chief of Navy to delegate their powers to retire officers and to terminate the appointment of officers down the line to ranks as far down as Brigadier in the Army and Commodore in the Navy. It also allows very senior officers on limited tenure promotion to transfer to the Army or Navy Reserve. It also includes amendments being made to the Defence Act 1903 and the Naval Defence Act 1910. The Supply and Development Act 1939 is to be repealed because it becomes redundant. Because of the ongoing processes of corporatisation, contracting out and competitive tendering, the need for that particular act has ceased. Under the old system, that particular arrangement provided an option for contractors to be employed. Obviously, we no longer need that as a mechanism to employ contractors.

In fact, a measure of the impact of the contracting out process is apparent at RAAF Base Amberley, which is in my electorate. The whole evolution of defence in my electorate is having a big impact on the development of Ipswich. First it began with the contracting out of maintenance on F111 aircraft, and that is not fully complete yet. That has brought Boeing on site and it is having a huge impact. Over the next five or 10 years Amberley is expected to double in size in terms of the number of people to be based there. The contracting out is providing a core of new skills and new learning. Coupled with the development of the University of Queensland campus at Ipswich, we are getting into some real opportunities for high-tech skills development that were not there before. This all comes about as a result of contracting out. If we are going to move into that sphere it is covered by this provision of the bill to remove the Supply and Development Act 1939.

At Amberley we are going to have a new contract awarded for the construction of these AEWAC aircraft. In awarding the Boeing contract, I understand that, of the seven Boeing 737s that are to be built and delivered—the first of which will be delivered in 2004-05 at a total project cost of $2 billion—five are to be built on site at Amberley. That will bring the highest of high-tech industries right into the centre of the Ipswich area. The work will go on in a big hangar—I think it is 6,000 or 9,000 square metres. They are establishing a very large area of hangar space. The end result will be a huge boost for the surveillance capability of Australia. I really do believe the capabilities of these aircraft should have been taken into account way back when they were looking at the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar. We have finally got around to taking the bull by the horns and going right down the track of having these airborne early warning and control aircraft. They are so much more efficient at doing the job than anything, as far as I can see, you could base in Alice Springs or Longreach to keep watch over the sea gap north of Australia.

There will be massive industry spin-offs in my area. I am pleased to see that, in allocating the Boeing contract, the minister has said that the government has learnt from the bitter experiences of the Labor Party with the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar and the Collins class submarines and that we will have much better contract management in this case.

Moving on to the urine analysis testing program, this is part of the rigour of running a modern defence force. The people who are to undertake the test are members of the ADF operating defence machines worth tens of hundreds of millions of dollars. It is estimated that a Collins class submarine is worth $838 million, although I am sure that figure is jackpotting at the moment faster than you might see watching Sale of the Century. Anzac frigates are worth something like $610 million and AEWAC aircraft of the type I was just discussing are worth $286 million. Even the new C130J, which is being sought at the present time, is worth $85 million. So these people are in command of very high-tech and very expensive equipment and we naturally expect them to be able to function at their top level. If they did not do their job then that huge taxpayers' investment would be at risk, other Defence personnel could certainly be placed at risk, civilians could be at risk and, at the end of it all, the security of our country is also at risk if we do not have people operating at their absolute top level. So there is no room for drugs in the Defence Force.

What really got me reading the Bills Digest on this particular issue was the incredible dead hand of bureaucracy that gripped this whole process when the former Privacy Commissioner, Kevin O'Connor, got involved. I do not think there would be a member in this House who could not see the good reason behind the need for urine testing of people in the Defence Force. It is a plain point. In fact, the opposition spokesman conceded that three years were lost under the Labor administration and more time has been lost in the early part of the coalition government because of the intervention of that Privacy Commissioner. It is typical, I suppose, that under that Labor administration at the time we should have a Privacy Commissioner going and sticking his nose into the drug tests that we need in our Defence Force. I am not surprised to see that at all. In those days we had the politically correct police running amok, and the Privacy Commissioner is a very good example of it.

I looked up the 10th annual report of the Privacy Commissioner—that of the replacement for Kevin O'Connor, Moira Scollay—and I am pleased to see that not a single reference is made to this issue of drug testing in the Defence Force. It is good to see that the Privacy Commissioner has got into areas that are probably more suitable than messing around with the Defence Force. Anyway, that is a good point that we should be pleased to welcome. It is good to see, though, that the coalition did in the end overcome that dead hand of bureaucracy and on 1 April 1997 the coalition approved this legislation that we are discussing tonight.

To look at the way testing will work, it is going to occur on a random basis. People in the Defence Force will give their sample in private and be given a notice explaining what is going to happen to that sample. They will be told the result and, if it is positive and they cannot give a medical explanation as to why it would be positive, they must go on to a doctor for assessment. They then get 28 days to state the reasons why they should not be discharged if they are not an officer or why their appointment should not be terminated if they are an officer. That 28-day process and the whole development of the process of the handling of these samples cannot be delayed by recourse to any of those appeal mecha nisms that are so friendly to people who are confronted with an allegation like this. They cannot go to the ombudsman to seek a delay in that process. I suppose they can go to the ombudsman, but the process continues, and that is important.

If, heaven forbid, the person involved in this kind of allegation was above the rank of major general, only the Governor-General can terminate their appointment. That is how serious it can be, I suppose, if you want to take it that far. Terminations for people involved in this are issued in writing. Apart from being exited from the Defence Force, there are possibilities there that we could have penalties by a reduction in rank or even a warning. I suppose that depends on the written response that the people are able to be given and the circumstances that apply. This whole process is to be administered by someone within the Army of the rank of brigadier or higher, in the Navy a commodore or higher and in the Air Force an air commodore or higher.

All that said, I think we should bear in mind that Defence Force personnel are not like elite athletes. Their job is to defend Australia, and it is not our responsibility to do anything other than ensure that they are able to do it to the best of their ability. There are drugs and treatments that can improve the performance of soldiers as well as the performance of elite athletes. For example, in the research I did looking at this particular issue I found that apparently the Russian military have been using a stimulant called Bromatan to keep their troops alert. They had been doing that under their administrative structure. They probably use other drugs as well, but those are actually allocated to their troops. I understand from looking at some of the information that similar tactics are now also being used in the Australian Defence Force and in New Zealand's SAS unit. I alert the House to that and draw the attention of members to an article in the Daily Telegraph of 5 April 1999 on this allocation of drugs, in effect, to members of the armed forces. It says:

Under these guidelines, members of the Special Air Service Regiment in Australia, the 1 Commando Regiment and some infantry units will be exposed to chemicals to improve endurance and a procedure called `blood loading'. That involves the removal of up to a litre of blood which is put back into the soldier's body just before a battle or exercise. Some of the chemicals being evaluated include modafinil, ephedrine and caffeine which all enhance endurance.
Apparently there is the possibility that some naturally occurring substances may also be allocated in that regard.

I think it behoves members of this House to take an interest in that process. Clearly there is a fine line that none of us would want to see crossed in this regard, because there has been a history in the past of troops being used in experiments and subsequently we discover that there have been some horrendous consequences of those sorts of investigations. There have been allegations that blood loading has become fairly common among athletes. If it is deemed by medical authorities to be a safe process, it could probably be of great assistance to soldiers in the field. But we do need to take a close look at this process, because what is now happening is that the involvement of members of those elite regiments, the Special Air Services Regiment and the 1 Commando Regiment, as well as some infantry units in Australia, is being looked at.

In the same article it was also noted that a survey that had been conducted found that more than 50 per cent of elite troops were already using performance enhancing aids and energy boosters. Those things can be as simple and as basically harmless as ginseng and some specially developed carbohydrate type foods, but it is an issue that we need to keep a close watch on. Of course, that is not the same thing as we have been looking at in relation to this other problem of drugs, marijuana or other recreational drugs. Those are the ones that will be picked up by the process of urine testing.

In closing, I would like to congratulate the government on its decision to award the AEWACs contracts. There has been a concern that arose, with the sudden arrival of various groups of boat people on the shores, that the existing resources available to our armed forces were being tested. It is good to see that we are grasping the nettle—if at some quite considerable cost; it will cost $2 billion to get these AEWACs aircraft—and that we are going to take on a capability that really does catapult Australia forward a long way in terms of its overall capability.

Two of those aircraft are to be based at Tindal in the Northern Territory and the rest are going to be based permanently at Williamtown. Their capability will really count significantly when it comes to detecting inappropriate movements of traffic not only in the air but also on the surface—I think they can do that kind of thing. That will be significant, as will be the capability to be able to direct our forces far more effectively than what we can possibly do at the present time. I pay tribute to the minister for this development. He has grasped some very difficult issues within the Defence portfolio.

Clearly, in the time since the coalition has come to power we have faced a lot of changes in the world. It is entirely correct to say that no-one in the world foresaw the Asian economic crisis. Whether they were military experts or anybody else, they had no great extra special capacity beyond the great capacity of the universities and everybody else that was wrong-footed on the Asian economic crisis. The impact, however, of the need to expand our Defence Force has been taken up very strongly by this government and the capabilities gained through the allocation of this AEWACs contract will be significant. It is good to see them being handled in such an effective and efficient manner.

talk.start.para: —The previous speaker, the member for Blair, who had obviously done some research on various drugs and their use in sport et cetera, referred to practices in the Russian armed forces. I would have wished, however, that he had done a bit more research on the Privacy Commissioner and his role in regard to the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1999 . Unfortunately, he tortured us all with a conventional attack upon privacy commissioners, basically accusing people of having thought police, and using all that kind of conservative rhetoric that we have heard over the last few years. The irony was that, having attacked the Privacy Commissioner for his supposed role in delaying this legislation, he went on to enumerate positive facets of this bill which are derived from the activity of the Privacy Commissioner. He told the parliament how great some of these provisions were, not knowing for one moment that they stemmed from the Privacy Commissioner.

speech.para: In fact, most of the delays, whether they have been by the Labor Party or the current government, really are not attributable to the Privacy Commissioner. Even today we have people in here crying crocodile tears with references to some senator's husband being mentioned by an opposition member of parliament, and then the member for Blair comes around complaining that we have privacy commissioners to protect people and their rights.

The other point that he did not quite understand was that there were clear indications that this legislation could not even come before the parliament because it needed other legislation. The Privacy Commissioner pointed out that you could not enforce this without legislation. That was not understood by the previous speaker at one stage, so I think it was a matter of coming in here and mindlessly just deciding, `I'll have a bit of a shot at somebody. It sounds good back in voterland and it might sound good at the local branch of the Liberal Party.'

In reality, in this legislation the Privacy Commissioner has played a very important role in protecting individuals in the armed forces who, as we all know, do not have union representation and have very limited employee rights. Quite frankly, if there is any group in this society that needs a bit of external protection, it is the members who serve this country in the armed forces.

This bill chiefly seeks to implement a process for random urine testing to detect drug use by Australian Defence Force personnel who are employed in combat or combat related duties. It also repeals the Supply and Development Act 1939 and makes a number of housekeeping amendments to a range of other pieces of defence legislation. Under the current government it is indeed an extremely rare event for a parliament to consider defence legislation. Such matters are clearly a low priority for the coalition. For example, we still await the changes to the Military Compensation Act 1994 that were announced in June 1997. We also keenly await the coalition's response to the recently completed inquiry into the military justice system. The minister opposite is a leading practitioner of government by inquiry. I have personally lost count of how many inquiries he has launched in regard to the end of war list, various awards, the Far Eastern Strategic Reserve—

talk.start.para: —Ones you know nothing about.

—I will give you some commendation because even your inquiries are an improvement upon the activities of your predecessor and I agree, quite frankly, that you have had quite a few problems dumped in your lap by your predecessor. However, it is a question of government by inquiry and certainly the department—and probably the minister as well—has lost count of how many inquiries have been launched.

speech.para: While the coalition has not managed to incorporate such matters into its legislation program, we have seen it inflict collateral damage on serving personnel as a result of its other policy agendas. Examples include defence leave for reservists being removed as an allowable award matter. Quite frankly, in a practical sense we are already seeing around Australia in a variety of awards and agreements attempts by employers to delete this right for employees.

I have had the opportunity to go to a variety of bases around this country with the shadow minister for defence, as he noted earlier. Quite clearly, on the ground—I think many coalition members are aware of this—we have a very big problem in regard to recruitment levels at the moment. Whether it is because of the unattractiveness of military life or actually of the reserves or because of changes in the work force—casualisation et cetera—we are having trouble attracting people. Yet this is an environment in which the government is saying that we need them.

In the context of a society where there are decreasing numbers of people at various work sites and where employees have more objection to their workmates taking time off and putting more pressure on them, we obviously need people to have award protection for their right to pursue this reserve work. To remove it as an allowable instrument is clearly a problem in regard to reserves at the moment.

You do not need to listen to me. Quite frankly, we know that the Premier of Victoria had a long-term interest in reserves and the Victorian State Council of the Liberal Party called for their reintroduction. Peter Reith's comment in this House was `Big deal' when the Victorian State Council of the Liberal Party passed a motion calling for its reintroduction. Another instance is ADF personnel being disproportionately slugged under the new fringe benefit tax reporting legislation, and the future of the pay-setting system for the ADF remains under a cloud.

I turn now to specific provisions of the bill. The ADF has had a no-drugs policy for many years. Under this policy, disciplinary or administrative action is initiated against any serving member who is found to be selling, possessing, dealing in or administering an illegal drug either to himself or herself or to someone else. The administrative sanctions against those who breach this policy include termination of appointment for officers, discharge from the service for non-officers or a reduction in rank. On enlistment, new recruits to the armed forces are required to sign a written acknowledgment that they have been made aware of the ADF's no-drugs policy.

In September 1993, the Chief of Defence Force approved a drug testing program entailing analysis of sample urine samples from randomly selected uniformed personnel. This program was to focus on operational personnel and on basic training units with an emphasis on the detection of narcotic substances. It was due to commence in July 1995. This drug testing program was supported by the then Labor government but could not be implemented without legislation because of concerns that were raised by the Privacy Commissioner and by the Attorney-General's Department.

The point we are making is that, whether people want to stand around wasting the time of this parliament by attacking the Privacy Commission, the strict legal situation in this country was that what the Privacy Commission said had to be done had to be done. In particular, the Privacy Commissioner expressed concern that the policy was unnecessarily intrusive, was not justified by evidence of extensive drug use in the ADF, captured drug use that was not particularly relevant in an operational sense to an individual's function in the armed forces and ignored legal drug use that could equally hamper a person's discipline, safety and efficiency.

As a result of these concerns, the government agreed that random drug testing should proceed only if it were explicitly authorised by legislation. Cabinet endorsed the preparation of such legislation in April 1997, but it was not introduced until March this year. The testing program authorised in this bill is designed to detect illicit drug usage that might otherwise hamper the ability of serving personnel to carry out their combat or combat related duties in a safe, efficient and effective manner. Combat and combat related duties are broadly defined for the purposes of this testing. It will occur on a random basis and will focus on the detection of cocaine, opiate, cannabis or heroin use.

The bill sets out procedures for the conduct of tests to address privacy and other concerns. Where possible, the collection of samples is to be supervised by a qualified medical practitioner. Personnel whose urine samples display evidence of them using these drugs will face administrative action including possible discharge. The first step will be for Defence to arrange for a doctor to provide an assessment of whether the person is fit or suitable for further military service. If the doctor considers that he or she is unfit or unsuitable for further service, the serving member is then to be given the opportunity to show cause why he or she should not be discharged or have his or her appointment terminated.

The Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, Mr Scott, has said that personnel whose random urine samples reveal illicit drug use will not face formal charges under section 59 of the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 under which such use is punishable by a fine or a term of imprisonment or under the Crimes Act 1914. The bill does provide, however, that a refusal to provide a urine sample, or tampering with a sample, is a serious offence attracting a maximum penalty of six months imprisonment. Any member whose service is retained despite a positive test result will be placed on a regular follow-up testing regime. Performance enhancing drugs, such as those reportedly used by the SAS and some other Army units, are excluded from the testing program.

I note that the key defence lobby groups do not oppose the principle of urine analysis drug testing. Some have said, however, that the drug testing regime should apply to all uniformed personnel irrespective of their duties. Given the earlier concerns of the Privacy Commissioner, much denounced by the previous speaker and others, it is probably sensible to commence the testing program on the restricted basis provided for in the bill. The results of the testing program can then be used to assess just how widespread and serious drug use actually is in the ADF.

I note that Australia is far from alone in introducing random drug testing of military personnel. Similar programs of urine testing are already in place in key allied countries such as the US, the UK, Canada and New Zealand. Random testing was introduced in the British forces in late 1994. According to the Times of 16 May 1995, the first quarter of testing in 1995 produced positive results in half a per cent of cases or in one in 200 personnel.

In response to the widespread and fairly notorious use of illicit drugs by servicemen in Vietnam, the US military developed policies to combat drug abuse in its forces from the late 1960s. It is noticeable that Congress insisted that prevention of alcohol abuse be incorporated into Defence Department drug use prevention programs.

The risks of undetected drug use were highlighted in a serious accident that occurred in 1981 when a US Navy jet crashed on the aircraft carrier Nimitz. Tragically, 14 sailors were killed in this incident. An official autopsy revealed that the pilot was using non-prescription antihistamines, and six of the others on board showed traces of cannabis use. This incident led to the introduction in that same year of urine testing to detect drug use by American personnel. Breathalyser tests have also been conducted.

It is interesting to note that since 1980 the US military has also conducted a series of surveys on drug and alcohol use by enlisted personnel. As well as illicit drugs, these self-report surveys have covered alcohol use, the use of inhalants and the non-medical use of psychotherapeutic drugs such as stimulants, tranquillisers, sedatives and analgesics.

It is acknowledged that self-reported studies are likely to somewhat underestimate drug use compared with urine, breathalyser and blood tests. With this qualification, a 1992 paper by Bray, Marsden, Herbold and Peterson in the journal Armed Forces and Society reveals that reported illicit drug use in the preceding 30 days declined steadily from 27.6 per cent in 1980—at the beginning of US activity in this field in their armed forces—to 4.8 per cent in 1998. Heavy alcohol use, on the other hand, rose to 24.1 per cent in 1982 and then fell to 17 per cent in 1988.

Bray et al cautioned that these changes could not be simply attributed to the introduction of education and testing programs. During the same period, the composition of the military's work force also changed, becoming older, better educated and more likely to be married—all characteristics associated with lower levels of drug and alcohol use. The Bray paper also refers to published comparisons of military and civilian drug and alcohol use in the United States. Note that these were standardised studies, adjusted for demographic differences between the two groups. The authors conclude:

Military policy directed against drug abuse has resulted in lower drug use among military personnel than among civilians; in contrast, military life may be conducive to a greater likelihood of abusive levels of alcohol among military personnel than among civilians in general.

In quoting these results, I am not implying that drug use in the military is not of concern. It is obvious that defence personnel engage in more hazardous activities and are responsible for the safety of others to a greater extent than occurs in the civilian work force, with the exception of pilots, air traffic controllers and train drivers. This justifies the application of testing procedures and discipline requirements that would be unacceptable in other work situations. Equally, heavy drinking is clearly a problem in the armed forces that can also cause safety and fitness problems. One wonders how effective are current programs within the ADF to address this problem.

I now turn to the other aspects of the bill. The bill provides a more efficient mechanism to enable the Chief of the Defence Force, the Chief of Army, the Chief of Navy and officers on limited tenure promotion to transfer to the Army Reserve and Navy Reserve when their term of appointment ends. The proposal was designed to retain the service of skilled and experienced senior officers once they left the full-time service by making it easier for them to transfer to the reserves. In parallel with this amendment, Air Force regulations will also be amended to implement a similar mechanism for RAAF officers. Currently, a service chief or an officer on limited tenure promotion who wishes to transfer to the reserves is required to first retire and then seek appointment to the reserves. Given that the reserves are an integral part of the ADF, this is an unnecessarily cumbersome and inefficient procedure.

Other measures in the bill are largely of an administrative or technical nature. They include a new provision allowing service chiefs to delegate their powers to retire or terminate the appointment of officers, an amendment extending the time limitation on charging persons under the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 from three to five years and the repeal of the Supply and Development Act 1939, which is now redundant because the relevant defence production facilities have all since been corporatised, privatised or closed.

As indicated by my colleague the member for Cunningham, the opposition will not be opposing the bill. In conclusion, however, I take the opportunity to join with him in expressing our concern, obtained from on-the-ground visits to a number of bases over the last fortnight, about the impact of fringe benefits tax upon morale in the armed forces and about the significant numbers of people leaving. I do not need to reiterate at length the points that the minister quite clearly understands. I think the member for Cunningham is accurate in saying that the minister opposite has a reasonable handle on the feeling of people in the forces. He has been available enough and he has been around the bases enough to know that at the moment we do have a very significant problem.

These people, as I said earlier, are not conventional day-to-day employees in society. They do not have representation. Essentially, they are subject to levels of discipline that the average person is not. They are forced by whatever government of whatever political persuasion at any one time to undertake very difficult activities. They are forced to move their families on many occasions. This has led to a greater level of family strain and—this has statistically been borne out—there is a higher level of divorce. That impacts on child support. This interpretation of fringe benefits tax by the ATO will essentially lead to very great burdens upon a significant number of the people in the armed forces. We must be concerned that the minister does take up with his colleagues the need to ensure that that impact does not lead in the long term to what I feel genuinely is on the ground at the moment—a very low level of morale and concern as to whether a significant number of people would be terminating.

talk.start.para: —I must say that I quite enjoyed listening to the speakers tonight on the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1999 . To the members for Cunningham, Blair and Reid, I thank them from my own personal perspective for their contributions because I thought each in their own way brought different perspectives. They have very well laid down the purposes of the bill.

speech.para: In the few minutes that I will speak on it—I do not intend to use all of my time—I will highlight the government's commitment to the defence capability of Australia and remind those who may be listening to this discussion tonight that we will spend in the current financial year just over $18 billion on defence procurement. The new initiatives approved include the acquisition of the reconnaissance and aerial fast port helicopters for the Army. No doubt that reconnaissance effort was in some of the discussion that the member for Blair shared with us out at Amberley. We have additional air-to-air missiles for the RAAF's FA18 hornets, enhancement of RAN minesweeping and minehunting capabilities, improvements to the electronic countermeasures of our F111s, new Evolved Sea Sparrow ship based missiles and new air-to-air weapons for the F111s.

This capability underscores the reality in the late 20th century of the highly technological nature of defence capacity throughout the world. Recent events in Europe remind us of this remarkable capacity in terms of NATO's sustained air attack against the former Yugoslavia. As I understand it, we saw not one loss of human life in that whole campaign. Sadly, there were losses of life in accidents and misadventure in training exercises, and I think subsequently in Kosovo itself there have been some losses of life in incidents there. But it really highlights the highly technical nature and the highly capitalised nature of the war machine of our era.

I am reminded of issues around the Collins submarine which will no doubt require, in the current budget allocation, some hundreds of millions of dollars to upgrade. I heard earlier that it cost $838 million for one piece of equipment, and this just highlights the issue of drug testing. It is said that you can replace a machine—even though it is a fairly elaborate and expensive machine—but the prime consideration for a commanding officer and others in positions of leadership in the armed forces must be the danger to personnel. It is very important for our service personnel to be able to minimise risks associated with the taking of drugs. The member for Reid reminded us of the Privacy Commissioner's role and the things that happened in the US and other countries, and these are quite useful in helping us to understand some of the issues of drug testing.

Other matters of the bill have been well covered by other speakers, including the transfer of officers to the Reserves and the delegation of powers. The legislation seeks to extend the time limitation for the laying of charges from three to five years under the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982, following recommendations of a Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee inquiry into the crash of a RAAF Nomad aircraft. The Supply and Development Act 1939 has been mentioned, and there is a technical amendment to the defence homes legislation.

I want to emphasise my support for those who choose the defence forces as a profession and the value that this parliament puts upon it. The demands on defence personnel have been well described earlier such as the extra demands on family life. Comparisons have also been made of the difference between military life and civilian life. All these things need to be recognised in the way we treat our service personnel. One of my very sad memories in coming into this place is the Black Hawk disaster near Townsville back in 1996. It reminds us of the very narrow margins and the very high risks that our defence forces work under. Even though this is reasonably procedural legislation, it reminds us of the importance of giving maximum support and practical backup to our defence personnel.

In conclusion, I compliment Minister Scott and Minister Moore. When we have had such a long period of peacetime, it is very difficult to keep the defence forces focused in a way which reflects our national interest. It must be an absolute challenge for the leadership of our defence forces, for the defence department and for the ministers to keep our national interest very much in the forefront. With those few words, I congratulate the government and wish this legislation speedy passage.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1999 , and I do so because it is important to defence personnel. One of our defence bases is in the Paterson electorate, and I support it because it is important to the morale and future careers of some of the 3,000 RAAF personnel who live in and around the Paterson electorate.

speech.para: It is unfortunate that over recent weeks we have heard a lot about management, or mismanagement, of our defence forces—particularly by the minister. With a force that is affected by cutbacks in staff, and with the total number of our defence personnel plummeting to the lowest level since pre-World War II, the morale in our defence forces is certainly not good. But the measures in this legislation are good for the morale of our defence forces. We on this side of the House are proud of the fact that a considerable part of this legislation was started by us back in 1995 when Senator Robert Ray and Senator John Faulkner were the relevant ministers.

We need to understand that Defence personnel are immensely proud of their drug-free status, and they want this legislation to be in place to support their reputation. Mind you, I sometimes think we are overzealous with respect to drugs in our Defence Force. I particularly remember making a submission for an insulin-dependent diabetic. He was devastated because he was compulsorily forced to withdraw from the RAAF on medical grounds. It was particularly harsh because he had just signed up for his final term of duty, at the end of which he would have been eligible to receive a Defence pension. The point was that he was quite a skilled person. He was a fellow who used to maintain the ejection seats and the parachutes in fighter aircraft. He was considerably skilled at that and he trained others. The reason that he was forced to withdraw from the RAAF was that, in a theatre of war, insulin may have been denied to him and therefore he would not have been able to perform his duties. I found that a very harsh and fairly inhumane end to the career of a person who actually loved what he was doing and was very good at it.

That point leads on to another part of the legislation. That piece of the legislation that I refer to is the piece that now allows regular or permanent members of the Defence Force at the end of their tour of duty to pass into the reserves. That is very important, because in the modern Defence Force with modern weaponry, modern communications and all the planning that goes into warfare, it is important that those skills be retained and that those people do not simply have to drop out at the end of the period for which they signed up. It certainly makes sense, and I agree with the legislation. If they can then transfer to the reserves, that is a very good thing.

We should also be mindful that, under the Hawke-Keating government, Australia made a quantum leap to develop its own defence industry. We are building our own frigates, our own mine hunters and our own submarines and, in my own electorate of Paterson, British Aerospace will very soon be building the Hawk lead-in fighter trainer. They certainly hope that will lead to bigger and better things when the FA18 is phased out of service, and hopefully Australia will be capable of building its own fighter aircraft. This is a new industry, with all the technology and all the skills that are required.

It is interesting that, earlier this evening, a number of people referred to the Collins class submarine rather apologetically. I do not see it that way. Sure, everyone knows that we will probably have to spend another half a billion dollars to bring these submarines up to scratch, but if as a nation we had not embarked on that project—we still wanted submarines and we would have brought in already constructed submarines from elsewhere and they may have been lemons too—we would not have developed a new industry. The way I see it is that the project is not over yet. If, with the expenditure of that extra half a billion dollars, we develop a top-class submarine, then we will have an industry that we can probably sell to the world and we will also have the potential to train our own young Australians in this highly skilled area of developing our own weapons.

As a matter of fact, in my own electorate, particularly in the Hunter region with the mine hunters currently being built in Newcastle, with the lead-in fighter being built there and with the AEWAC aircraft going to be based there—although we had hoped that all of the work to do with the AEWAC would have been done at Williamtown but unfortunately that is not to be so—I certainly see that Defence has an enormous opportunity. This is particularly so when we consider that the demise of our BHP as we know it is certainly going to occur in the next six weeks. There is enormous potential for Defence in the Hunter region to employ our young people, to give them skills and to give them a career path that will be ongoing as Australia moves into the 21st century with its very own defence industry.

One of the reasons that I am here to speak tonight is that we do support this legislation. It is bipartisan legislation and it has been developed in a bipartisan way over a number of years. It is very important that we have the highest level of skills and the highest level of trained personnel in our Defence Force. I also believe that it is great that Australia is now moving to be self-sufficient in its own defence industry—something that only two decades ago we certainly could not have looked to.

Traditionally, we were a country that went overseas every couple of years. We bought the F111s and the Oberon class submarines—you name it, we bought it. Currently, of course, there are a couple of American warships that—perhaps inadvertently or perhaps otherwise; time will tell—were bought from the United States Navy and are being refurbished in the Forgacs dockyard in Newcastle. Unfortunately, there have been a couple of overruns, but I have no doubt that, at the end of it, the Australian Navy will finish up with two top-class warships and we will have learned from those mistakes. I would have preferred that we had, right from day one, built those warships here in Australia. As an island nation we needed them, and it is important that we develop those industries ourselves here in this country rather than depending on others.

That is the positive thing that I see happening in Defence today. It is important that the morale of the Australian Defence Force be lifted and I believe that this legislation is going to go a long way towards doing that.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Prior to the 1998 federal election, all members and senators received a letter from the General Manager of the Department of Finance and Administration outlining the arrangements covering the use of entitlements and facilities after the dissolution of parliament. I seek leave to table a copy of that later.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —Paragraph 5 states:

speech.para: Senators and members' entitlements to staff and facilities, including information delivery service and travel . . . are to assist you to carry out your parliamentary and electorate responsibilities, but are not available for party business. Long standing convention is to regard electorate business as including activities in support of one's own re-election.
It goes on to say, with regard to members' travel claims:
As the House of Representatives has been dissolved, it would be difficult to rely on parliamentary business as a justification for travel.

Last November I placed on the Notice Paper a question designed to compare election campaign travel and overtime by members' staff with the average monthly bill. What the answer shows is that, during the month of the 1998 election, federal members of parliament—mostly government, I should say—authorised staff overtime and travel allowance amounting to almost a million dollars more than the 1997-98 financial year monthly average. The figures I quote here are rounded down, but full details are available in Hansard in the answer received on 7 July to question No. 90.

While the total average monthly travel allowance bill for the personal staff of members of parliament for the 1997-98 financial year was $225,000, during the election month this increased by more than 3½ times to $817,000. It was largely the same story for overtime. During the election month at least $156,000 was authorised for personal staff overtime as opposed to a monthly average of $88,000, while for electorate staff $660,000 was authorised compared with a monthly average of $300,000.

A quick look at the figures from some prominent offices tells the story. During the election month the Prime Minister authorised $160,000, or nearly 10 times his office's average monthly staff travel allowance bill, and $22,000, more than three times its average, in personal staff overtime. The Leader of the Opposition authorised $79,000, or more than six times his office's monthly average for personal staff travel. And so it goes on.

Another prominent office holder authorised $28,000 in staff travel allowance as opposed to an office monthly average of $6,000 and another $29,000 as opposed to $5,000. Again it goes on. But none of these was even up for re-election, being mid-term senators. Of course, none of these figures includes air fares which are also likely to run to tens of thousands of dollars. Why, I ask, should the taxpayer fork out this extra funding for personal staff participation in election campaigns—no doubt targeted at marginal seats—when they already pay for it through generous public funding laws? In recent times, there have been ever burgeoning numbers of spin doctors and advisory staff and these figures will only increase unless the tribunal gets real teeth.

talk.start.para: —What was yours?

—Have a look. The question these office holders must answer is why, when the departmental guidelines clearly state such allowances may only be used for parliamentary or electorate work—not party business—they authorised claims during the 1998 election period far in excess of what they would have authorised during any normal month. Do they expect the public to believe that last September was a particularly busy parliamentary month although parliament had dissolved or that, as permitted by the longstanding convention, all of the personal staff of mid-term senators were working towards their bosses' re-elections when they were not even running?

speech.para: The answers point to widespread misuse of taxpayers' funds during the last election, largely for party political purposes as opposed to parliamentary or electorate work as set out by the tribunal. The guidelines are clearly inadequate. The Prime Minister must ensure they are tightened. These figures make the much publicised travel rorts of 1997 pale into insignificance and the worry is that it has probably been going on for years.

talk.start.para: —I rise in the House this evening to speak on the republic. There is a well-known quote, `What price hast thy soul?' I ask in the same vein: what benefits will a republic bring to the people of Australia? We were told by the member for Werriwa that to be an Australian head of state is something to which our children can aspire. The member also told us that he does not agree with the content of the legislation that is before the parliament. He believes in a directly elected President but, because he is a true republican, he will vote yes in the referendum. He believes that all Australians should vote yes in the referendum, even though the wording is not right. He believes we should worry about the fine print later: that is just detail—simple things like who can be a head of state or an Australian President, whether a person has to be born in Australia, what resources it will take to implement this and how much the total cost will be in fulfilling the promise of a republic. I ask the member for Werriwa whether he would sign a contract to sell his house, his business, his livelihood and not know the purchase price—in fact, know that the contract in its written form does not reflect his wishes, but he should sign it and worry about all of these issues later: that is in the fine print.

speech.para: Do you really believe that Australians have so little intelligence or are so foolish that they will not want to know some of these details? In addition, Australians would need to understand how this alternative is better than what currently exists in Australia. When Australians ask these questions there is no answer. I repeat: there is no answer. There is no alternative better than what we have currently. Can anyone tell us that overseas countries refuse to trade with us because we are not a free country? Can anyone tell us that we are being penalised because we are not a republic? Can anyone tell us that having a republic will address issues like health, aged care and education?

We are told by the opposition that being a republic will make us a better people; it will give our children something to aspire to—to become the Australian head of state, our President. I guess it will. It will create one job, but then again it will replace one job. I suggest there are many hundreds of thousands of our kids out there who would aspire to have just one job, any job, in this current climate.

I begrudge the money that has been spent and that will be spent in the future on this issue. There are many things that need reform and action within Australia before we reform our Constitution. It is not the Constitution that jeopardises the future or the survival of rural and regional Australia. It is not our Constitution that prevents us from dealing with our growing drug problems. It is not our Constitution that prevents us from offering a quality of care for our aged, our children and our mentally and physically disabled. It is not our Constitution which prevents us from having world-class education, roads, infrastructure and jobs for Australians.

The opposition speaks of emotion ruling this debate. They speak of the emotion coming from our side of the House. I suggest that the emotion comes from the opposition benches and is clearly a memory of 1975 when Gough Whitlam was sacked by the Governor-General, Sir John Kerr. The opposition will never accept nor forget this. I have sat here and listened to the opposition speak. The one thing that was consistent and dominant in the whole debate was the use of the Whitlam catchcry `It's time.' Most speakers said, `It's time.' I ask again: `What price hast thou soul' that they would sacrifice our country's stability in order to deliver their so-called justice?

talk.start.para: —The issue of genetically modified food, or GMF, is of fundamental concern to all Australians and indeed the world. It is no exaggeration to say that GMF constitutes one of the greatest single biological issues yet faced by the human race. It is an issue that affects everyone. GMF is more than a mere `scientific' issue; it invokes serious ethical, health, environmental and trade dilemmas.

speech.para: There are many misconceptions about GMF. Therefore, a definition of GMF is required. GMF is defined as `food produced using gene technology which has been derived from an organism which has been modified by gene technology but does not include any substance regulated as a food additive or a processing aid'—standard A18, Food Standards Code.

Right from the outset, we are not talking about food additives or other `processing aids'. GMF is something entirely different. It specifically relates to the modification of the genes within the food itself. I stress this distinction so that this House is absolutely clear as to what we are talking about. Many members of this House and members of the public will assert that food has been modified for years. For those who then point to additives or other processing techniques as if it were the same as GMF, this is simply incorrect.

This raises the first of the ethical issues. Adolf Hitler is quoted as saying, `A bird flies because it is a bird.' This philosophy asserts that, because we can do a thing, therefore we must do a thing. Contrary to some reports in the media implying that all GM food will be labelled, I raise the issue of labelling and quote the Australian Medical Association's press release of 4 August 1999, which states;

Suggestions were made on 3 August 1999 at the Ministers' meeting to include a minimum threshold level of genetically modified foods that would be exempt from labelling. Determining that `loophole' threshold level, if there is to be one, will be of utmost concern to the AMA. The standards must be stringently monitored to ensure food companies do not abuse the labelling system. Any loopholes could provide companies with opportunities to misinform the public about their product which would severely water down the extended labelling that the health ministers have strongly endorsed. The just jury is still out on the benefits and risks of genetically modified foods on public health and the environment.

I note the common food industry arguments for not labelling; that is, it is too costly and damages consumer confidence. I further note a report in the Australian newspaper on 4 August 1999 that GM foods `have not been tested on human beings'. The immediate concern is the implementation of the FSC in the forthcoming Australia New Zealand Food Authority Amendment Bill 1999 . The bill proposes to permit the Australia New Zealand Food Authority to administer what they consider to be minor issues without consulting the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Council, although ANZFSC retains the right to veto such decisions.

There is also concern about the future of Commonwealth government administrative arrangements. In an increasing age of philosophy of reduced government regulatory involvement and self-regulating industry, these concerns are more than justified. The single most pressing issue is the justified fear that, like so many other government regulatory powers, the market is driving policy towards a universal laissez-faire philosophy at any cost. Fears are being expressed that the Foods Standards Code will be watered down to meet competition policy principles and manufacturer and trade imperatives rather than consumer specifications, including public health and the right to know and choose. Specifically, the World Trade Organisation talks in November will deal with discussion about free trade of genetically modified products.

However, the Biosafety Protocol—trade in living genetically modified organisms—has mysteriously stalled. This is a clear indication of the manipulation by powerful trade groups and stakeholders in squashing the truth about GMF. Further evidence of this worldwide gagging of the implications is to be found in the United Nation's Codex Alimentarius meeting in May 1999 in which Australia and others rejected the United States led resistance to compulsory labelling of GMF in the first stage vote on the proposed international draft labelling standard for GM foods.
I end this speech by quoting the precautionary principle from section 6(2)(a) of the Protection of the Environment Administration Act (NSW) which states, inter alia:
If there are threats of serious or irreversible environmental damage, lack of full scientific certainty should be used as a reason for postponing measures to prevent environmental degradation.
GMF is a clear case of such a threat. We cannot therefore postpone measures to prevent such environmental degradation. I urge this House to stop GMF entering the market.

talk.start.para: —It is always great for the Chief Government Whip to get the call in the adjournment debate. There is great competition. I recently received an email from a constituent, Jamie Bedson. It was from Banja Luka. It says:

speech.para: My name is Jamie Bedson and I am writing to you from Banja Luka in Bosnia and Herzegovina. I have been living here since the start of February this year, and I am teaching English for a local branch of the Cambridge School of English. I am a Ballaratian—
and a very fine one too, I might say—
having been overseas for the majority of the last four years. I'm living in Bosnia until I come home early next year.

The reason I am writing to you is for some suggestions and possibly some help in relation to the current refugee crisis in Albania, a result of the conflict in Yugoslavia. Currently volunteers are needed in Albania with my specific skills, and I now have the opportunity to provide this help. Being here has put me in the unique position of being very close to the current state of events in the former Yugoslavia and surrounding areas.

As I am coming home next year and am able to report back to any interested organisations at home, I thought there might be the opportunity to involve local Ballarat charitable organisations in an international project, especially those concerned with youth. It is with this in mind that I write to you now.

During the course of the bombing in Yugoslavia it is estimated that 600,000 refugees from the Kosovo region made their way to Albania, and they have been living there under extremely uncomfortable circumstances. Many of these have been in refugee camps run by Non Government Organisations, while others have found room with host families.

This young man, who is working for the Sunflower group, is doing what a lot of young people want to do; that is, doing something for someone else. There are plenty of Jamie Bedsons not just in Ballarat but all over Australia and I think all the world who are trying to do something for someone else.

I have written to a number of Ballarat organisations—the city council, the Ballarat secondary college where my constituent went to school and other organisations—to assist this young man to live in these camps and help these young people. These young people of course have very few skills in English or anything else. This young man is also a musician and he is involving himself in helping children to express themselves. After what they have been through, I think they deserve every bit of assistance they can get.

I thought the response of the Australian community to the Kosovo refugees was an indication of the absolute backbone of this country. We have always been prepared to fight for someone who was getting a raw deal. We have done that for a long time. We have proved ourselves in various theatres of war and we have proved ourselves in peacetime to be a nation that is prepared to get in and have a go. We are a nation that is prepared to break what might seem to be the rules to achieve those ends. We have done so with great pride and we have done so with great gusto.

In the very short time that is left to me tonight I would like to speak on another topic. Time constraints yesterday with the urgency to get the Constitution Alteration (Establishment of Republic) Bill 1999 across to the Senate meant that I could not have an opportunity to say what I wanted to say. I have made it clear in the past that the present system has served this country well and, if needed to, could do so just as well for the next 100 years. Many months ago, I made it quite clear that I would consider supporting a republic if and only if it was a model that allowed the Australian people to be a direct part of the presidential election process rather than excluding them as the referendum model does.
