That requirement I think is one that has widespread support throughout the Australian community.

I am one of those who believe this is the people's referendum, and I will not be actively campaigning, but I will start campaigning if I hear any of this patent and blatant nonsense from some quarters that someone who supports the present system or supports another model is in some way un-Australian or unpatriotic. I hope this debate is a sensible one. The Australian people—politicians and others involved—deserve a proper and sensible debate that is not based on emotion and I hope all members will respect that. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I would like to take the opportunity of providing the House with information on a tremendous initiative operating in Western Australia. This initiative sees members of parliament `adopted' by families where a family member has a disability. The Politician Adoption Scheme, which is an initiative of the Developmental Disability Council, aims to support members of parliament in representing the needs of people with disabilities in their electorates by providing a more personal insight into the impact of disabilities on people's lives. This occurs through regular contact with their `adopting family'. Politicians therefore develop a better understanding of why support services are so desperately needed and are therefore better informed so as to advocate for the necessary funds to be provided for this vitally important sector.

speech.para: I was honoured to be invited to participate in this program. On 18 June, I was adopted by the Gotti family of Victoria Park. This ceremony occurred at Government House, WA, and was presided over by the Governor of Western Australia, Major General Michael Jeffery. I am pleased to advise that this program received bipartisan support, with both members of the coalition and Labor being adopted.

The problems faced by families where a member has a disability are enormous. For many, even the most routine of tasks, which many of us take for granted, become major projects. To illustrate this I would like the House to consider the Gotti family and their circumstances. In order to achieve this I will quote from the speech made by Mrs Gotti at the adoption ceremony. Mrs Gotti describes the difficulties faced by people in these circumstances far more eloquently than I would ever be able to by quoting from personal experience:
My name is Rosa Gotti. I am married to Danny. We have two boys, Ben, sixteen and Jamie nine and a half.

Ben is our special needs child. He was born with cytomegalovirus, has microcephaly, cerebral palsy (quad spastic), is functionally blind, unable to speak, epileptic and a mild asthmatic. In a nutshell Ben is my sixteen year old "baby".

A teenager with all the normal feelings and emotions of anyone his age unfortunately trapped in a body that physically requires the care given to a baby. How frustrating it must feel for him when his carers, his parents, have to feed him, dress him, toilet him etc. etc.

Ben is unable to turn himself at night. When uncomfortable he wakes and wakes me, I turn him and go back to bed and hopefully we go back to sleep, not always. This happens three to four times a night, sometimes more. Some nights we are all awake.

Ben is taller and stronger than me with extremely strong muscle tone and this is taking a toll on me physically. The hoist we have is of some help but still requires two people to use it. It is not functional in all the rooms where lifting is necessary.

Having a disabled child has been draining, physically, emotionally, socially, monetarily and totally frustrating. It does not improve with age nor time. As he gets older we are continuously running into more and more bureaucratic superfluous red tape.
Having Ben, as difficult as it is, is continuously compounded by the system which is totally orientated to addressing the peripherals and not the problems of the disabled.

Ben is a very clever young man who has achieved significant goals regardless of all the impediments, thanks to a lot of hard work on his part and the vision of a dedicated few. He uses an augmented communication system, a Macaw to speak.
With the help of an army of volunteers during his first six years of therapy there was born the witty charming and lovable, social Ben of today.
It is this person and his family who is adopting Kim Wilkie M.P. Federal Member for Swan as advocate for all disabled Australians.

This is an example of one family's courageous struggle. That they have been prepared to open their lives to scrutiny in order that I may obtain an insight into the plight of people in these circumstances is a selfless act which is to be highly commended.

Some members have asked what they can do to assist. Firstly, members need to gain an insight into the impact on families of caring for a family member with a disability. Members should also be involved in any Politician Adoption Scheme in their electorate if one is operating. Members need to advocate for people with disabilities and keep their electorates informed about disability issues. For my part, I thank the Gottis for their trust and look forward to the challenge of keeping parliament informed regarding disability issues.

talk.start.para: —The town of Forbes's first Peace Ambassador Award has recently been awarded. A local man, Don Sewell, who now manages the Jemalong Retirement Village, spent 6½ years in Vietnam during the Vietnam War. He says that the time has left a lasting impression on him and that those memories will never go away. This was the man who was awarded this first Peace Ambassador Award.

speech.para: The town of Forbes is amongst several go-ahead towns in my electorate. Some well-known events are held in the town: Carnivale, an Australia Day and many other social events for which the town has become very well known. The people of Forbes have taken it upon themselves to set up this Peace Ambassador Award.

Don Sewell had volunteered to work in a 90-bed hospital in Vietnam that was caring for Vietnamese civilians who were victims of the war. Patients comprised war victims: those injured or mutilated by war activities, those starving from lack of food, those horrifically burned, countless orphans from the four large orphanages in the district and countless thousands of refugees afflicted and dying from almost every known disease and illness. I quote from the Forbes Advocate:

On arrival at the hospital, Mr Sewell's job was as Assistant Director and jack of all trades. Supervising office work, scrounging from U.S. army bases, overseeing the provision and supply of equipment and supplies to the various areas of the hospital.

He became so involved in the work that, despite volunteering to go for one year, he eventually stayed for six years and left when he was evacuated just before the communists arrived in the city. Early in 1975 the communist forces began to take over the country and he was advised by American security to evacuate as many of his international staff as possible. Don Sewell ordered 10 others to fly to Saigon, leaving four behind to try and keep the hospital going. On Good Friday, 28 March 1975, Don received a phone call saying that they had 1½ hours to get themselves on the last plane out of Qui Nhon before the communist forces took over the town. They were allowed to take only one small bag and had to leave most of their personal belongings behind.

Records of experiences of special people like Don Sewell should be written for following generations to read and learn about, so that they will appreciate history that hopefully will never be repeated. Don Sewell now manages the Jemalong Retirement Village in Forbes and shows the same care to the elderly residents and is a fierce advocate for those unable to care for themselves. Mr Don Sewell has now settled into Forbes, and Forbes has settled in with Don Sewell—Forbes's first Peace Ambassador recipient.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebateinfo.title: Defence Science and Technology Organisations: Tender for Contracts
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 762)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 June 1999:

question.para: (1) Has the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO) tendered for contracts in the field of applied dynamics since 1989; if so, in each case, (a) what was the contract for, (b) who were the successful tenderers and (c) what sum was involved.
(2) What total sum has DSTO spent on procuring library material concerning applied dynamics since 1989.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: This response has to be qualified to the extent that the area covered by the question is very broad (it has been interpreted here as referring to non-linear dynamic finite- element analysis) and because some records might have been destroyed. Under the Commonwealth Archives Act 1983, DSTO, as part of a Commonwealth Agency, is not obliged to keep records of routine tenders for more than six years after the tender action is completed, in this case from before 1993. Nevertheless, DSTO has no recollection of such tenders having been placed in the period 1989-92.
(2) $191,421.00 (estimated; figure includes cost of monographs, reports and serials which could be expected to include reference to, or papers on, applied dynamics).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 22 June 1999:

question.para: Has he received an expert report by Professor John Kaldor reviewing the methodology used by the Scotland-based Australian researcher Sue Rabbitt Roff on the health of British and New Zealand nuclear veterans and their families; if so, (a) on what date, (b) has Ms Rabbitt Roff been provided with a copy and given a chance to respond; if not, why not, (c) what was the cost of the report, (d) are copies available to the public; if not, why not, and (e) has he accepted Professor Kaldor's recommendations; if so, will he provide details of further action to be taken to address the situation of Australian military and civilian personnel who participated in British nuclear tests in Australia.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Veterans' Affairs; Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Yes.
(a) Thursday 15 July 1999.
(b) Professor Kaldor had discussions with Ms Rabbitt Roff during the preparation of his report. A copy of his report will be provided to Ms Rabbitt Roff. She may choose to comment.
(c) Professor Kaldor is still to submit his account.

(e) I have announced the compilation of a nominal roll of ex-service personnel involved in the testing and also civilians, aborigines and pastoralists, for whom information is available. This will enable the Government to determine if current compensation and assessment arrangements are sufficient.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 23 June 1999:

question.para: (1) Does Australia support microfinance institutions such as the Grameen Bank in Bangladesh, CARD in the Philippines and SEWA in India.
(2) What sum in foreign aid has Australia channelled to microcredit programs in each year since 1990 (a) in total and (b) to each country receiving this form of aid.

(3) Has Australia adopted a strategy to maximise aid in the microcredit sector; if so, does the strategy include (a) formal linkages with official initiatives such as the ERAP Trust Fund in the Philippines and (b) supporting South-South technical cooperation in this area.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Australian overseas aid program supports a number of microfinance organisations in developing countries. Australia has supported the work of the Center for Agriculture and Rural Development (CARD) through the Philippines Australia Community Assistance Program (PACAP), which is administered by the Australian Embassy in Manila. Since 1988 assistance provided to CARD through this scheme amounts to approximately $345,000. In 1998-99 Australia provided approximately $145,000 through PLAN International Australia to assist CARD to expand its Landless People's Development Fund in Marinduque and Mindoro Oriental.

Australia has funded the Self Employed Women's Association Cooperative Bank (SEWA) in India over the last three financial years for a project involving salt workers. Approximately $164,000 has been provided through the Small Activities Scheme managed by the Australian High Commission in New Delhi.

The Australian aid program has not provided direct support to the Grameen Bank in Bangladesh. However, AusAID provided $6,337 for travel costs for Professor Muhummad Yunus, founder and managing director of the Grameen Bank, to visit Australia from 16 to 24 March 1997.
(2) Amounts provided by Australia in support of microfinance for the period 1990-91 to 1998-99, by recipient country and in total, are set out in the attachment.

(3) The Government is committed to doubling expenditure on microfinance through the overseas aid program within the life of the current Parliament, consistent with ensuring a high quality portfolio of activities. In line with this commitment, the 1999-2000 budget includes a three-year $3 million microfinance initiative to serve as a catalyst for further microfinance activities in the aid program. Funds under the initiative will be used to identify and strengthen the capacity and outreach of microfinance organisations which demonstrate the potential to become long-term providers of financial services to the poor on a significant scale. Following initial identification and/or support through the seed fund, it is anticipated that further
assistance to selected microfinance organisations will be provided through normal bilateral programming channels.

(a) At this stage no formal linkages are envisaged with initiatives such as the ERAP Trust Fund in the Philippines. Evidence from around the world suggests that specialist microfinance programs have on the whole been more effective in meeting the twin goals of sustainability and outreach to the poor.

(b) Technical cooperation is central to Australia's support for microfinance. The aid program will continue to draw on Australia's expertise and experience in management and banking, which can be of great value to microfinance organisations as they seek to expand their operations and improve their financial performance. At the same time, the Government recognises there is a substantial pool of microfinance experience in the developing world. We will consider ways of making use of this experience where appropriate, consistent with maintaining the Australian identity of the overseas aid program.

subdebateinfo.title: Royal Australian Navy: Garden Island Facility
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 775)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 June 1999:

question.para: Has the number of staff employed at the RAN's Garden Island facility at Cowper Wharf Road and Macleay Street, Woolloomooloo decreased in recent years; if so, will the RAN allow public use of its Woolloomooloo car park; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: In recent years, there has been an increase of the number of Defence personnel at Garden Island. This has resulted from the rationalisation of a number of owned and leased properties in the Sydney metropolitan area, the upgrading of office accommodation on the Island and the contraction of ADI's ship maintenance and support activities. Depending on how many ships are in port, the number of Defence staff at Garden Island can exceed one thousand. ADI currently employee in excess of 400 personnel on the site.

The car park provides parking for Defence fleet vehicles in central Sydney; parking for Defence staff in the Potts Point precinct; secure parking for Navy personnel manning ships at sea; and parking for ADI employees. The car park is required for Defence and ADI purposes, and there is no potential for public use.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 23 June 1999:

question.para: (1) Did his Department advise the Joint Committee on Migration in 1995 that there were approximately 78,000 names on the Person Alert List (PAL).
(2) How many names are currently included on the PAL.
(3) How many visitor visa applications have been rejected since June 1998 because the applicant was listed on the PAL.
(4) How many visitor visa applications have been rejected in total since June 1998.
(5) What is the estimated cost of maintaining the PAL.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes, the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration on Australia's Visa System for Visitors, of January 1996, states at 5.33 that "DIEA indicated that the Person Alert List presently contains approximately 78,000 names".
(2) As at 29 June 1999, there were 99,208 names included on the PAL. The PAL is part of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA) Movement Alert List (MAL).

(3) Visitor visa applications are rejected on the basis of adverse information held on an applicant. The PAL, and more broadly the MAL, of which it is a part, are the key tools for alerting departmental decision-makers to this adverse information. In short, an entry on the PAL does not in itself lead to a rejection.
(4) Between 1 June 1998 and 30 June 1999, a total of 87,824 visitor visa applications were rejected.

(5) The estimated total costs of maintaining the PAL in the 1998/99 financial year was $880,100, with accrued liabilities of $11,300 and accrued assets of $848,300. This estimate is made under the assumption that 85% of all MAL work is done on the PAL. "Maintenance" has been taken to include communication with overseas posts and data entry, hardware/software maintenance, as well as policy and quality assurance. This estimated sum incorporates the work of the MAL subsection of the Law Enforcement Liaison and Movement Alerts section, the Entry Operations Centre and Business Solutions Group in DIMA, as well as Computer Sciences Corporation Australia Pty Ltd, which provides computer services to DIMA.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 29 June 1999:

question.para: (1) What security and confidentiality measures are in effect to protect the identity, assets and information provided by applicants for business migration.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to an advertisement by a private company called Business Match at page 3 of the issue of Business Forum for June 1999 claiming that it can provide customers with an international network of business migration applicants of high net worth; if so, is he able to say on what basis the company can make that claim.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The security and confidentiality measures in place to protect information collected by my Department relating to the identity, assets and other particulars of applicants for business migration are consistent with the requirements of the Privacy Act 1988 (the Act). The Act is the key law designed to prevent misuse of personal information collected by government agencies and it prevents the Department from passing personal information to others except where:
. the applicant is reasonably likely to have been aware of the Department's disclosure practices; or
. the applicant consents to it; or
. the Department believes it is reasonable to disclose information to prevent or lessen a serious or imminent threat to the applicant's life or health or to that of another person; or
. disclosure is authorised or required by law; or disclosure is necessary to enforce the criminal law, law imposing a financial penalty, or to protect public revenue.

The Department has produced an information form entitled Safeguarding your personal information—Form 993i which explains its authority to collect personal information, how it can be used and how it is protected.
(2) I am aware of the advertisement placed by a company called Business Match in the June issue of Business Forum. My Department has contacted the company and the company has advised that:

. it has developed, independently of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, a network of business migration applicants through direct promotion of the company in business migration markets as well as referrals from various lawyers, accountants and industry associations; and
. applicants have given their consent to their details being included in the database.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice on 30 June 1999:

question.para: (1) Is it a fact that (a) the Steggles company has applied to his Department to bring two Korean chicken sexers to Australia and (b) all chicken sexers employed by Steggles are working part-time.
(2) Will he ensure that overseas chicken sexers are not allowed into Australia simply to force wages down.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) Yes. Steggles Limited has lodged nominations for two chick sexer positions with my department's Parramatta Business Centre. A particular consideration in determining these nominations is whether Australian chick sexers are available to undertake this work. My department is consulting with both Steggles and the Australian Chick Sexers Association on sponsorship related matters.

(b) Chick sexing is a demanding occupation and I understand it is normal for sexers to work between 20—25 hours per week in sexing chickens. Ex-contract Australian staff currently employed by Steggles to undertake chick sexing have been offered full time employment with the requisite weekly hours taken up with general hatchery duties on non-hatching days. No Australian chick sexer has accepted that offer to date.

Steggles Limited has negotiated an industrial agreement with the Australian Workers' Union (AWU) in regard to employed chick sexing staff. The agreement is currently with the NSW Industrial Relations Commission. In the agreement Steggles and the AWU acknowledge the difficult nature of the work and decided that "should the hours worked in the hatchery exceed an average of 28 hours per week over a reasonable period of time, the company and the union will meet to discuss the matter . . .to review manning levels".

(2) No further applications to recruit Korean chick sexers will be approved without first satisfying employer sponsorship and related labour market testing requirements. In order to gain approval as a business sponsor, Steggles was required to demonstrate a benefit to Australia in recruiting from overseas and to give formal undertakings that they will, among other things, comply with Australian industrial relations laws and conditions of employment.

The company needs to demonstrate as part of its current nomination of overseas skilled workers that they are unable to recruit suitably qualified Australian sexers. Steggles has been asked by the department to provide this information.

The Government's sponsorship arrangements and employer undertakings are designed to ensure that the employment and training opportunities of Australian citizens and permanent residents are not compromised.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice on 30 June 1999:

question.para: Did Passports Australia cease sending mailed passports by either registered or certified mail; if so, (a) when did it cease to do so, (b) how many passports sent by ordinary mail have had to be replaced because of loss or theft in the mailing process since the decision to cease sending passports by registered or certified mail took effect, (c) how many passports sent by mail were replaced because of loss or theft in the mailing process in each of the 5 financial years before the decision took effect and (d) was the decision made on cost considerations; if so, what are the details of cost savings in each financial year since the decision took effect.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows;

answer.para: Yes. Passports Australia ceased sending mailed passports by receipted mail on 31 December 1997 in order to reduce expenditure and to provide a more convenient delivery system to its clients. The previous system required a person to be at home at the time of passport delivery. This did not prevent the passport falling into the wrong hands, as the person signing receipt did not have to be the person to whom the item was addressed.

1,343 passports have been reported as missing in the mail in the 18 months since the new system was introduced. 355 of these have been recovered and returned for normal use. The remainder are still missing and have been replaced.

The Passport Information and Control System has only recorded passports reported as missing in the mail since April 1996, and records are based on calendar years. Between April and December 1996, 1,075 passports were reported as missing in the mail.
During the 1997 calendar year, 302 passports were reported missing in the mail.
Use of ordinary mail has cut the operating costs of the Passports Service by approximately $1m per year without affect.
